key_definitions.child: A natural person below the age of 16 years, or lower if set by Member State law, but not below 13 years.
key_definitions.holder of parental responsibility: A person or entity legally recognized as responsible for the child, typically a parent or legal guardian.
key_definitions.controller: The natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which, alone or jointly with others, determines the purposes and means of the processing of personal data.

cleaned_regulations.source_section: ## Conditions applicable to child's consent in relation to information society services

cleaned_regulations.regulation_name: General Data Protection Regulation (EU) 2016/679, Article 9: Processing of special categories of personal data

industry_sectors: Any sector processing sensitive personal data

description.brief_summary: Article 9 of the GDPR prohibits the processing of special categories of personal data except under specific, enumerated exceptions and with appropriate safeguards.
description.detailed_explanation: The regulation establishes a general prohibition on processing personal data that reveals racial or ethnic origin, political opinions, religious or philosophical beliefs, trade union membership, genetic data, biometric data for unique identification, health data, or data concerning a person's sex life or sexual orientation. It provides a closed list of exceptions where such processing is permitted, such as explicit consent, employment and social protection law, vital interests, legitimate activities of non-profit bodies, data made public by the data subject, legal claims, substantial public interest, preventive or occupational medicine, public health, and archiving or research purposes. Additional safeguards and conditions apply, including professional secrecy obligations and the possibility for Member States to introduce further restrictions.
description.purpose: To protect individuals' fundamental rights and freedoms, particularly their right to data protection, by imposing strict controls on the processing of sensitive personal data.
description.legislative_intent: Lawmakers intended to ensure that processing of sensitive personal data is strictly limited to situations where it is absolutely necessary and subject to robust safeguards, thereby minimizing risks to individuals' privacy and fundamental rights.

what_it_covers: Processing of personal data revealing racial or ethnic origin
Processing of personal data revealing political opinions
Processing of personal data revealing religious or philosophical beliefs
Processing of personal data revealing trade union membership
Processing of genetic data
Processing of biometric data for unique identification
Processing of data concerning health
Processing of data concerning a natural person's sex life or sexual orientation

entity_types: Any entity processing special categories of personal data
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Entities established in the EU or processing data of individuals in the EU

what_it_does_not_cover: Processing of non-special categories of personal data
Processing outside the scope of EU law
Processing not involving the listed special categories

mandatory_obligations: Do not process special categories of personal data unless an exception applies
Implement appropriate safeguards for the fundamental rights and interests of the data subject when processing under exceptions
Ensure professional secrecy when processing health data under certain exceptions
Comply with further conditions or limitations imposed by Member State law
prohibited_actions: Processing of special categories of personal data unless an exception applies
Disclosing special category data outside a non-profit body without consent of data subjects (when processed under the non-profit exception)
conditional_requirements: Obtain explicit consent from the data subject for processing, unless prohibited by Union or Member State law
Processing for employment, social security, or social protection must be authorized by Union or Member State law or collective agreement and provide appropriate safeguards
Processing to protect vital interests only when the data subject is physically or legally incapable of giving consent
Processing by non-profit bodies must relate solely to members, former members, or regular contacts and not be disclosed outside the body without consent
Processing of data manifestly made public by the data subject
Processing necessary for legal claims or when courts are acting in judicial capacity

Processing for substantial public interest must be based on Union or Member State law, be proportionate, respect the essence of the right to data protection, and provide suitable and specific measures to safeguard fundamental rights and interests

Processing for preventive or occupational medicine, medical diagnosis, health or social care, or management of health or social care systems must be based on law or contract with a health professional and subject to professional secrecy
Processing for public health must be based on law and provide suitable and specific measures to safeguard rights and freedoms, in particular professional secrecy

Processing for archiving in the public interest, scientific or historical research, or statistical purposes must be in accordance with Article 89(1) and based on law, be proportionate, respect the essence of the right to data protection, and provide suitable and specific measures to safeguard fundamental rights and interests
documentation_requirements: Maintain records of processing activities involving special categories of personal data
Document the legal basis and safeguards for processing under exceptions

general_restrictions: General prohibition on processing special categories of personal data
data_restrictions: Processing of genetic data, biometric data, or health data may be subject to further conditions or limitations by Member States
operational_restrictions: Non-profit bodies may only process data of members, former members, or regular contacts and may not disclose data outside the body without consent
technical_restrictions: Processing for certain purposes must be subject to professional secrecy
geographic_restrictions: Member States may introduce additional restrictions

individual_rights: Right not to have special categories of personal data processed except under strict conditions
Right to give or withhold explicit consent for processing
Right to be informed of the legal basis for processing
Right to safeguards for fundamental rights and interests
organizational_rights: Right to process special categories of personal data under specified exceptions
how_to_exercise_rights: Data subjects may provide explicit consent for processing
Data subjects may withhold consent where required
Data subjects may request information about processing and safeguards

general_exceptions: Processing is permitted if one of the listed exceptions applies
conditional_exemptions: Explicit consent of the data subject, unless prohibited by law
Processing necessary for employment, social security, or social protection law obligations
Processing necessary to protect vital interests where consent cannot be given
Processing by non-profit bodies for legitimate activities with safeguards
Processing of data manifestly made public by the data subject
Processing necessary for legal claims or judicial acts
Processing necessary for substantial public interest based on law
Processing necessary for preventive or occupational medicine, health or social care, or management of health or social care systems
Processing necessary for public interest in public health
Processing necessary for archiving, research, or statistical purposes in the public interest
public_interest_exceptions: Processing necessary for substantial public interest
Processing necessary for public health
Processing necessary for archiving, research, or statistical purposes in the public interest

technical_measures: Implement suitable and specific measures to safeguard fundamental rights and interests
Ensure professional secrecy where required
organizational_measures: Adopt policies and procedures for processing special categories of personal data
Ensure processing is authorized by law or collective agreement where required
security_measures: Apply appropriate safeguards for data protection
training_requirements: Train staff on handling special categories of personal data and applicable exceptions
audit_requirements: Conduct audits of processing activities involving special categories of personal data

enforcement.regulatory_authority: Supervisory authorities designated by each EU Member State (e.g., Data Protection Authorities)

penalties.financial_penalties: Administrative fines up to 20,000,000 EUR or up to 4% of the total worldwide annual turnover of the preceding financial year, whichever is higher (GDPR Article 83(5))
penalties.administrative_penalties: Orders to cease processing, corrective orders, suspension of data flows
penalties.reputational_consequences: Public disclosure of violations, reputational damage

related_articles: GDPR Article 89 (Safeguards and derogations relating to processing for archiving, research, or statistical purposes)
complementary_regulations: EU Member State data protection laws

implementation_steps: Identify whether processing involves special categories of personal data
Determine if an exception applies and document the legal basis
Obtain explicit consent where required
Implement appropriate safeguards and professional secrecy obligations
Review and comply with any additional Member State requirements
Maintain records of processing activities
Train staff on handling sensitive data
common_violations: Processing special categories of personal data without a valid exception
Failure to obtain explicit consent where required
Inadequate safeguards for sensitive data
Non-compliance with Member State-specific conditions
best_practices: Minimize processing of special categories of personal data
Use data protection impact assessments for high-risk processing
Regularly review legal bases and safeguards
Engage with Data Protection Officers and legal counsel
compliance_checklist: Is the data processed a special category under Article 9?
Is there a valid exception for processing?
Are appropriate safeguards in place?
Is explicit consent documented where required?
Are Member State-specific requirements met?
Are records of processing maintained?

key_definitions.special categories of personal data: Personal data revealing racial or ethnic origin, political opinions, religious or philosophical beliefs, or trade union membership, and the processing of genetic data, biometric data for the purpose of uniquely identifying a natural person, data concerning health or data concerning a natural person's sex life or sexual orientation.
key_definitions.explicit consent: A freely given, specific, informed and unambiguous indication of the data subject's wishes by which he or she, by a statement or by a clear affirmative action, signifies agreement to the processing of personal data relating to him or her.
key_definitions.data subject: An identified or identifiable natural person to whom personal data relates.
key_definitions.controller: The natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which, alone or jointly with others, determines the purposes and means of the processing of personal data.
key_definitions.processor: A natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which processes personal data on behalf of the controller.
key_definitions.professional secrecy: An obligation imposed by Union or Member State law or rules established by national competent bodies to keep certain information confidential.

cleaned_regulations.source_section: ## Processing of special categories of personal data

cleaned_regulations.regulation_name: General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) Article 10: Processing of personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences

industry_sectors: All sectors processing criminal conviction data

description.brief_summary: Regulates the processing of personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences, restricting such processing to official authorities or when specifically authorized by Union or Member State law with appropriate safeguards.
description.detailed_explanation: GDPR Article 10 stipulates that processing of personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences or related security measures, when based on Article 6(1) (lawfulness of processing), is only lawful if carried out under the control of official authority or if authorized by Union or Member State law that provides for appropriate safeguards for the rights and freedoms of data subjects. Furthermore, any comprehensive register of criminal convictions may only be maintained under the control of official authority. This ensures that such sensitive data is subject to strict oversight and legal safeguards.
description.purpose: To protect the rights and freedoms of individuals whose data relates to criminal convictions and offences, by restricting processing to official authorities or under strict legal authorization with safeguards.
description.legislative_intent: To prevent misuse or unauthorized processing of sensitive criminal conviction data, ensuring such data is handled only by competent authorities or under strict legal frameworks with appropriate protections.

what_it_covers: Processing of personal data relating to criminal convictions
Processing of personal data relating to offences
Processing of personal data relating to related security measures
Maintenance of comprehensive registers of criminal convictions

target_entities: Organizations authorized by Union or Member State law
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Entities operating within the EU or EEA

what_it_does_not_cover: Processing of criminal conviction data not authorized by law or not under official authority
Registers of criminal convictions not under official authority

mandatory_obligations: Processing of personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences must be carried out only under the control of official authority or when authorized by Union or Member State law providing for appropriate safeguards.
Any comprehensive register of criminal convictions must be kept only under the control of official authority.
prohibited_actions: Processing of criminal conviction data by entities not under official authority or not authorized by law
Keeping a comprehensive register of criminal convictions outside the control of official authority
conditional_requirements: Processing is permitted if authorized by Union or Member State law that provides appropriate safeguards for the rights and freedoms of data subjects.

general_restrictions: Processing of criminal conviction and offence data is restricted to official authorities or entities authorized by law.
data_restrictions: Comprehensive registers of criminal convictions must be kept only under the control of official authority.
operational_restrictions: Entities not under official authority cannot process or maintain comprehensive registers of criminal convictions unless specifically authorized by law.
geographic_restrictions: Applies within the EU and EEA

individual_rights: Right to protection of personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences
Right to appropriate safeguards for rights and freedoms when data is processed

general_exceptions: Processing is permitted when authorized by Union or Member State law providing for appropriate safeguards.
conditional_exemptions: Entities may process such data if authorized by law and appropriate safeguards are in place.
public_interest_exceptions: Official authorities may process and maintain registers for public interest purposes as defined by law.

organizational_measures: Ensure processing is under the control of official authority or authorized by law with safeguards.
security_measures: Appropriate safeguards for the rights and freedoms of data subjects must be in place.

enforcement.regulatory_authority: Supervisory Authorities designated under GDPR in each EU Member State

penalties.financial_penalties: Administrative fines up to 20,000,000 EUR or up to 4% of the total worldwide annual turnover, whichever is higher, for non-compliance with GDPR requirements.
penalties.administrative_penalties: Orders to cease processing, deletion of unlawfully processed data, other corrective powers.
penalties.reputational_consequences: Public disclosure of violations, potential reputational damage.

related_articles: GDPR Article 9 (Processing of special categories of personal data)

implementation_steps: Verify if processing of criminal conviction data is necessary.
Ensure processing is under the control of official authority or authorized by law.
Implement appropriate safeguards for data subjectsâ€™ rights and freedoms.
Restrict access to comprehensive registers to official authorities.
Document legal basis and safeguards for processing.
common_violations: Processing criminal conviction data without proper legal authorization.
Maintaining registers of criminal convictions outside official authority.
Failure to implement appropriate safeguards.
best_practices: Limit processing to what is strictly necessary.
Regularly review legal authorizations and safeguards.
Train staff on handling sensitive criminal data.
Maintain clear documentation of processing activities.
compliance_checklist: Is processing of criminal conviction data under official authority?
Is there explicit legal authorization for processing?
Are appropriate safeguards in place?
Is any register of criminal convictions kept only under official authority?

key_definitions.personal data: Any information relating to an identified or identifiable natural person.
key_definitions.criminal convictions and offences: Data relating to criminal acts, convictions, or related security measures.
key_definitions.official authority: A public body or entity vested with legal powers by Union or Member State law.
key_definitions.comprehensive register: A systematic collection or database of criminal conviction data.

cleaned_regulations.source_section: ## Processing of personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences

cleaned_regulations.regulation_name: General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) Article 11 â€“ Processing which does not require identification

description.brief_summary: GDPR Article 11 specifies that controllers are not required to maintain, acquire, or process additional information to identify a data subject if identification is not necessary for the processing purposes. If the controller cannot identify the data subject, certain rights do not apply unless the data subject provides additional information for identification.
description.detailed_explanation: This article addresses situations where the processing of personal data does not require the identification of data subjects by the controller. It relieves controllers from the obligation to collect or process extra information solely to identify individuals for the purpose of complying with the GDPR. If the controller can demonstrate that it cannot identify the data subject, it must inform the data subject if possible. In such cases, the rights to access, rectification, erasure, restriction, data portability, and objection (Articles 15-20) do not apply unless the data subject provides information enabling identification.
description.purpose: To prevent unnecessary collection or processing of personal data solely for the purpose of compliance, thereby supporting data minimization and privacy by design.
description.legislative_intent: Lawmakers intended to balance data subject rights with the principle of data minimization, ensuring controllers are not forced to process more data than necessary.

what_it_covers: Processing of personal data where identification of the data subject is not required
Obligations of controllers regarding identification for compliance purposes
Applicability of data subject rights when identification is not possible

who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Entities established in the EU or processing data of individuals in the EU

what_it_does_not_cover: Processing where identification of the data subject is required for the purposes of processing
Situations where the controller already possesses information enabling identification

mandatory_obligations: Controllers must not be obliged to maintain, acquire or process additional information in order to identify the data subject for the sole purpose of complying with the Regulation if identification is not required for processing purposes.
If the controller can demonstrate it is not in a position to identify the data subject, it must inform the data subject accordingly, if possible.
prohibited_actions: Controllers must not process additional information solely for the purpose of identification for compliance if not otherwise required.
conditional_requirements: If the data subject provides additional information enabling identification, Articles 15 to 20 apply.
documentation_requirements: Controllers must be able to demonstrate that they are not in a position to identify the data subject.
reporting_requirements: Inform the data subject if the controller is not in a position to identify them, if possible.

general_restrictions: Controllers are restricted from being obliged to process additional information solely for identification for compliance purposes.
data_restrictions: No obligation to collect or process additional personal data for identification if not required for processing purposes.

individual_rights: Right to be informed if the controller cannot identify the data subject, if possible.
organizational_rights: Right for controllers not to be obliged to process additional information solely for identification for compliance.
how_to_exercise_rights: Data subjects may provide additional information to enable identification and exercise rights under Articles 15-20.

general_exceptions: Articles 15 to 20 (data subject rights to access, rectification, erasure, restriction, data portability, and objection) do not apply if the controller cannot identify the data subject.
conditional_exemptions: If the data subject provides additional information enabling identification, the rights under Articles 15 to 20 apply.

organizational_measures: Procedures to assess whether identification is required for processing purposes
Procedures to inform data subjects if identification is not possible
audit_requirements: Ability to demonstrate inability to identify the data subject

enforcement.regulatory_authority: Supervisory Authorities designated under GDPR (e.g., national Data Protection Authorities in EU Member States)

penalties.financial_penalties: Subject to GDPR administrative fines for non-compliance, up to â‚¬20 million or 4% of annual global turnover, whichever is higher, depending on the infringement.
penalties.administrative_penalties: Corrective orders, reprimands, or temporary/permanent bans on processing.
penalties.reputational_consequences: Potential public disclosure of non-compliance by authorities.

complementary_regulations: National data protection laws implementing GDPR

implementation_steps: Assess whether identification of data subjects is necessary for processing purposes.
Document the assessment and rationale if identification is not required.
Establish procedures to inform data subjects if identification is not possible.
Ensure mechanisms are in place to allow data subjects to provide additional information for identification if they wish to exercise their rights.
Maintain records demonstrating inability to identify data subjects where applicable.
common_violations: Processing additional personal data solely for compliance when not required for processing purposes.
Failing to inform data subjects when identification is not possible.
Not having documentation to demonstrate inability to identify data subjects.
best_practices: Apply data minimization and privacy by design principles.
Regularly review processing activities to determine necessity of identification.
Train staff on handling requests from unidentified data subjects.
compliance_checklist: Is identification of the data subject necessary for processing?
Are you refraining from collecting additional data solely for compliance?
Do you have a process to inform data subjects if identification is not possible?
Can you demonstrate inability to identify the data subject if challenged?
Do you allow data subjects to provide additional information to exercise their rights?

key_definitions.controller: The natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which, alone or jointly with others, determines the purposes and means of the processing of personal data.
key_definitions.data subject: An identified or identifiable natural person whose personal data is processed.
key_definitions.personal data: Any information relating to an identified or identifiable natural person.
key_definitions.Articles 15-20: GDPR provisions granting data subjects rights to access, rectification, erasure, restriction, data portability, and objection.

cleaned_regulations.source_section: ## Processing which does not require identification

cleaned_regulations.regulation_name: General Data Protection Regulation (EU) 2016/679, Article 12: Transparent information, communication and modalities for the exercise of the rights of the data subject

description.brief_summary: Article 12 of the GDPR sets out how data controllers must provide information to data subjects and facilitate the exercise of their rights, including requirements for clarity, accessibility, timelines, and conditions for charging fees or refusing requests.
description.detailed_explanation: This article requires controllers to provide information and communications to data subjects in a concise, transparent, intelligible, and easily accessible form, using clear and plain language, especially for children. Information must be provided in writing or electronically, and orally if requested and identity is verified. Controllers must facilitate the exercise of data subject rights under Articles 15-22, and cannot refuse requests unless they cannot identify the data subject. Responses to requests must be provided without undue delay and within one month, extendable by two months if necessary, with reasons for delay communicated. If no action is taken, the data subject must be informed of reasons and their right to complain or seek judicial remedy. Information and actions must be free of charge unless requests are manifestly unfounded or excessive, in which case a reasonable fee may be charged or the request refused, with the burden of proof on the controller. Controllers may request additional information to verify identity if in doubt. Information may be provided with standardized icons, which must be machine-readable if electronic. The Commission may adopt delegated acts to define icon standards.
description.purpose: To ensure data subjects are fully informed of their rights and how to exercise them, and to guarantee transparency and fairness in the handling of personal data.
description.legislative_intent: To empower individuals with control over their personal data, ensure transparency in data processing, and provide clear, enforceable procedures for exercising data protection rights.

what_it_covers: Provision of information to data subjects (Articles 13 and 14)
Communications relating to data subject rights (Articles 15-22, 34)
Facilitation of data subject rights requests
Timelines and procedures for responding to requests
Conditions for charging fees or refusing requests
Identity verification procedures
Use of standardized icons for information
Empowerment of the Commission to define icon standards

entity_types: Any organization acting as a data controller
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Entities established in the EU or processing data of individuals in the EU

what_it_does_not_cover: Processing by individuals for purely personal or household activities
Processing by competent authorities for law enforcement purposes (covered by separate directive)
Processing outside the material scope of the GDPR

mandatory_obligations: Provide information referred to in Articles 13 and 14 and communications under Articles 15-22 and 34 to the data subject in a concise, transparent, intelligible and easily accessible form, using clear and plain language
Provide information in writing or by other means, including electronic means; orally if requested and identity is proven
Facilitate the exercise of data subject rights under Articles 15-22
Respond to data subject requests without undue delay and within one month of receipt
Inform the data subject of any extension within one month, with reasons for delay
Provide information by electronic means if the request was made electronically, unless otherwise requested
Inform the data subject without delay and at the latest within one month if no action is taken, with reasons and information on complaint/judicial remedy
Provide information and actions free of charge
Bear the burden of demonstrating manifestly unfounded or excessive requests if charging a fee or refusing
Request additional information to confirm identity if there are reasonable doubts
Information may be provided with standardized icons; icons must be machine-readable if electronic
Comply with delegated acts adopted by the Commission regarding icon standards
prohibited_actions: Refusing to act on a data subject's request under Articles 15-22 unless unable to identify the data subject
Charging fees for information or actions unless the request is manifestly unfounded or excessive
conditional_requirements: Extension of response period by two months is allowed if necessary due to complexity or number of requests, with notification and reasons provided within one month
Charging a reasonable fee or refusing a request is allowed only if the request is manifestly unfounded or excessive, particularly if repetitive
Oral provision of information is allowed if identity is proven by other means
Additional information for identity verification may be requested if there are reasonable doubts
reporting_requirements: Inform data subject of extension and reasons for delay within one month
Inform data subject of reasons for not taking action and right to complain or seek judicial remedy within one month
timeline_requirements: Respond to data subject requests without undue delay and within one month of receipt
Extension by up to two further months allowed if necessary, with notification within one month
Inform data subject of refusal or inaction within one month

general_restrictions: Requests may be refused only if manifestly unfounded or excessive, or if the controller cannot identify the data subject
data_restrictions: Additional information may be requested only to confirm identity if there are reasonable doubts
operational_restrictions: Information must be provided in a concise, transparent, intelligible and easily accessible form, using clear and plain language
technical_restrictions: Standardized icons presented electronically must be machine-readable

individual_rights: Right to receive information about data processing in a clear and accessible manner
Right to exercise rights under Articles 15-22 (access, rectification, erasure, restriction, data portability, objection, not to be subject to automated decision-making)
Right to receive responses to requests within statutory timelines
Right to receive information free of charge (unless request is manifestly unfounded or excessive)
Right to be informed of reasons for refusal or inaction and to lodge a complaint or seek judicial remedy
organizational_rights: Right to request additional information to confirm identity if there are reasonable doubts
how_to_exercise_rights: Submit request to controller (in writing, electronically, or orally if identity is proven)
Controller must respond within one month (extendable by two months with notification)
If refused, data subject must be informed of reasons and complaint/judicial remedy options

general_exceptions: Without prejudice to Article 11 (controllers not required to maintain, acquire or process additional information to identify the data subject if not already possessed)
conditional_exemptions: Controller may refuse to act on a request if unable to identify the data subject (Article 11(2))
Controller may charge a reasonable fee or refuse requests if manifestly unfounded or excessive

technical_measures: Implement systems to provide information in writing, electronically, or orally as required
Ensure standardized icons are machine-readable if presented electronically
organizational_measures: Establish procedures for handling data subject requests
Maintain processes for verifying identity where necessary
Develop policies for charging fees or refusing requests in compliance with requirements
security_measures: Verify identity before providing information orally or when in doubt
training_requirements: Train staff on handling data subject requests, timelines, and communication requirements

enforcement.regulatory_authority: Supervisory authorities designated by each EU Member State (e.g., Data Protection Authorities)

penalties.financial_penalties: Administrative fines up to â‚¬20 million or 4% of total worldwide annual turnover, whichever is higher, for non-compliance with data subject rights obligations
penalties.administrative_penalties: Orders to comply, reprimands, temporary or definitive bans on processing
penalties.reputational_consequences: Public disclosure of violations, potential loss of customer trust

enforcement_mechanisms: Complaints by data subjects to supervisory authorities
Investigations and audits by supervisory authorities
Judicial remedies initiated by data subjects

related_articles: Article 11 (Processing which does not require identification)
Articles 13 and 14 (Information to be provided to data subject)
Article 34 (Communication of a personal data breach to the data subject)

implementation_steps: Develop clear, plain-language privacy notices and communications
Implement request handling procedures to meet one-month response deadlines
Establish identity verification processes for oral or uncertain requests
Monitor and document requests to identify manifestly unfounded or excessive patterns
Prepare to provide information electronically and with standardized icons if required
Train staff on data subject rights and communication requirements
common_violations: Failure to respond to data subject requests within statutory timelines
Providing unclear or inaccessible information
Charging fees without justification
Refusing requests without proper demonstration of inability to identify the data subject
Not informing data subjects of their right to complain or seek judicial remedy
best_practices: Use layered privacy notices with standardized icons
Automate request tracking and response workflows
Maintain clear records of requests and responses
Regularly review and update communication templates
Proactively inform data subjects of their rights
compliance_checklist: Are privacy notices concise, transparent, intelligible, and easily accessible?
Are all communications with data subjects in clear and plain language?
Is there a documented process for handling data subject requests?
Are requests responded to within one month (or extended with notification)?
Are fees only charged when requests are manifestly unfounded or excessive, with justification documented?
Is identity verification performed where necessary?
Are standardized icons used and machine-readable if electronic?
Are data subjects informed of their right to complain or seek judicial remedy if requests are refused?

key_definitions.controller: The natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which, alone or jointly with others, determines the purposes and means of the processing of personal data.
key_definitions.data subject: An identified or identifiable natural person whose personal data is processed.
key_definitions.manifestly unfounded request: A request that is clearly without basis or made with malicious intent.
key_definitions.excessive request: A request that is unreasonably repetitive or burdensome.
key_definitions.standardized icons: Visual symbols used to provide easily visible, intelligible and clearly legible information about data processing.

cleaned_regulations.source_section: ## Transparent information, communication and modalities for the exercise of the rights of the data subject

cleaned_regulations.regulation_name: General Data Protection Regulation (EU) 2016/679, Article 13 â€“ Information to be provided where personal data are collected from the data subject

description.brief_summary: Article 13 of the GDPR requires data controllers to provide specific information to data subjects at the time personal data is collected from them, ensuring transparency and enabling data subjects to exercise their rights.
description.detailed_explanation: This article mandates that when personal data is collected directly from a data subject, the controller must provide a comprehensive set of information at the time of collection. This includes the controller's identity and contact details, the data protection officer's contact details (if applicable), the purposes and legal basis for processing, recipients of the data, details of international transfers, storage periods, data subject rights (including access, rectification, erasure, restriction, objection, portability, and withdrawal of consent), the right to lodge complaints, whether data provision is mandatory, and the existence of automated decision-making. If the controller intends to process the data for a new purpose, the data subject must be informed beforehand. These obligations do not apply if the data subject already has the information.
description.purpose: To ensure transparency in data processing and empower data subjects to understand and control how their personal data is used.
description.legislative_intent: Lawmakers intended to enhance individuals' control over their personal data by mandating clear, timely, and comprehensive information provision by data controllers.

what_it_covers: Collection of personal data directly from data subjects
Provision of information at the time of data collection
Disclosure of processing purposes and legal basis
Notification of recipients and international transfers
Information on data retention, rights, and automated decision-making
Notification of further processing for new purposes

who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Entities established in the EU or offering goods/services to, or monitoring, EU data subjects

what_it_does_not_cover: Situations where the data subject already has the information

mandatory_obligations: Provide the following information at the time personal data are obtained from the data subject:
The identity and contact details of the controller and, where applicable, of the controller's representative
The contact details of the data protection officer, where applicable
The purposes of the processing for which the personal data are intended as well as the legal basis for the processing
Where processing is based on point (f) of Article 6(1), the legitimate interests pursued by the controller or by a third party
The recipients or categories of recipients of the personal data, if any

Where applicable, the fact that the controller intends to transfer personal data to a third country or international organisation and the existence or absence of an adequacy decision by the Commission, or in the case of transfers referred to in Article 46 or 47, or the second subparagraph of Article 49(1), reference to the appropriate or suitable safeguards and the means by which to obtain a copy of them or where they have been made available
The period for which the personal data will be stored, or if that is not possible, the criteria used to determine that period

The existence of the right to request from the controller access to and rectification or erasure of personal data or restriction of processing concerning the data subject or to object to processing as well as the right to data portability
Where processing is based on consent, the existence of the right to withdraw consent at any time, without affecting the lawfulness of processing based on consent before its withdrawal
The right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority

Whether the provision of personal data is a statutory or contractual requirement, or a requirement necessary to enter into a contract, as well as whether the data subject is obliged to provide the personal data and of the possible consequences of failure to provide such data

The existence of automated decision-making, including profiling, referred to in Article 22(1) and (4) and, at least in those cases, meaningful information about the logic involved, as well as the significance and the envisaged consequences of such processing for the data subject
If further processing for a new purpose is intended, provide information on that other purpose and any relevant further information prior to such processing
prohibited_actions: Do not omit required information unless the data subject already has it
conditional_requirements: Provide information on legitimate interests only if processing is based on Article 6(1)(f)
Provide information on international transfers and safeguards only if applicable
Provide information on the right to withdraw consent only if processing is based on consent (Article 6(1)(a) or Article 9(2)(a))
Provide information on automated decision-making only if such processing occurs
documentation_requirements: Maintain records of information provided to data subjects

If further processing for a new purpose is intended, information must be provided prior to that processing

Data subjects may exercise rights by submitting requests to the controller

key_definitions.controller: The natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which, alone or jointly with others, determines the purposes and means of the processing of personal data.
key_definitions.data subject: An identified or identifiable natural person whose personal data are processed.
key_definitions.personal data: Any information relating to an identified or identifiable natural person.

cleaned_regulations.source_section: ## Information to be provided where personal data are collected from the data subject

cleaned_regulations.regulation_name: General Data Protection Regulation (EU) 2016/679, Article 14: Information to be provided where personal data have not been obtained from the data subject

industry_sectors: All sectors processing personal data within the EU or targeting EU data subjects

description.brief_summary: GDPR Article 14 requires controllers to provide specific information to data subjects when personal data have not been obtained directly from them, ensuring transparency and enabling data subjects to exercise their rights.
description.detailed_explanation: When a controller acquires personal data from sources other than the data subject, they must provide the data subject with detailed information about the processing, including the controller's identity, contact details, purposes and legal basis for processing, categories of data, recipients, international transfers, storage periods, data subject rights, source of data, and existence of automated decision-making. The information must be provided within specified timeframes, and there are defined exceptions where these obligations do not apply. Additional safeguards and references to related GDPR articles are included for specific scenarios such as international transfers and research purposes.
description.purpose: To ensure transparency and protect the rights and freedoms of data subjects when their personal data are processed without their direct involvement.
description.legislative_intent: Lawmakers intended to guarantee that individuals are informed about the processing of their personal data, even when collected indirectly, so they can exercise their rights and understand how their data are used.

what_it_covers: Provision of information to data subjects when personal data are not obtained directly from them
Disclosure of controller and DPO contact details
Explanation of processing purposes and legal basis
Categories of personal data processed
Recipients or categories of recipients
International data transfers and safeguards
Storage periods or criteria
Data subject rights (access, rectification, erasure, restriction, objection, portability)
Right to withdraw consent
Right to lodge a complaint
Source of personal data
Existence of automated decision-making and profiling

entity_types: Any organization acting as a data controller
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Entities established in the EU or processing data of individuals in the EU

what_it_does_not_cover: Situations where the data subject already has the information
Cases where providing information is impossible or involves disproportionate effort (e.g., archiving, research, statistical purposes under Article 89(1))
Processing where obtaining or disclosure is expressly laid down by Union or Member State law with appropriate safeguards
Processing where data must remain confidential due to professional secrecy obligations regulated by law

mandatory_obligations: Provide the following information to the data subject: identity and contact details of the controller and, if applicable, the controller's representative; contact details of the data protection officer, if applicable; purposes and legal basis for processing; categories of personal data; recipients or categories of recipients; information on international transfers and safeguards; storage period or criteria; legitimate interests if applicable; data subject rights (access, rectification, erasure, restriction, objection, portability); right to withdraw consent; right to lodge a complaint; source of data; existence of automated decision-making and profiling, including meaningful information about the logic, significance, and consequences.

Provide the information within a reasonable period after obtaining the data, but at the latest within one month, or at the time of first communication with the data subject, or at the time of first disclosure to another recipient, whichever occurs first.
If further processing for a different purpose is intended, provide information on that other purpose and any relevant further information before such processing.
prohibited_actions: Do not fail to provide required information unless an exception applies.
conditional_requirements: If processing is based on legitimate interests (Article 6(1)(f)), specify the legitimate interests pursued.
If processing is based on consent (Article 6(1)(a) or Article 9(2)(a)), inform about the right to withdraw consent at any time.
If international transfers are involved, provide information on adequacy decisions, safeguards, and how to obtain copies.
documentation_requirements: Maintain records of information provided to data subjects.
Document reasons for relying on exceptions (e.g., disproportionate effort).
reporting_requirements: Provide information to data subjects as specified.
Make information publicly available if relying on the disproportionate effort exception.
timeline_requirements: Within a reasonable period after obtaining the data, but at the latest within one month.
At the time of first communication with the data subject, if applicable.
At the time of first disclosure to another recipient, if applicable.
Prior to further processing for a new purpose.

general_restrictions: Provision of information is not required if the data subject already has the information.
Provision of information is not required if impossible or involves disproportionate effort, subject to safeguards.
Provision of information is not required if obtaining or disclosure is laid down by law with appropriate safeguards.
Provision of information is not required if data must remain confidential due to professional secrecy obligations.
data_restrictions: Transfers to third countries or international organizations require disclosure of adequacy decisions or safeguards.
operational_restrictions: Must not process data for a new purpose without providing additional information.
geographic_restrictions: Transfers outside the EU/EEA require additional information and safeguards.

individual_rights: Right to be informed about processing when data are not obtained directly
Right to access personal data
Right to rectification
Right to erasure
Right to restriction of processing
Right to object to processing
Right to data portability
Right to withdraw consent at any time (where applicable)
Right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority
Right to meaningful information about automated decision-making and profiling
how_to_exercise_rights: Contact the controller or data protection officer using provided contact details
Submit requests for access, rectification, erasure, restriction, objection, or portability
Withdraw consent by notifying the controller
Lodge complaints with the relevant supervisory authority

general_exceptions: The data subject already has the information.
conditional_exemptions: Provision of information proves impossible or would involve a disproportionate effort, particularly for archiving, scientific or historical research, or statistical purposes, subject to Article 89(1) safeguards.
Obtaining or disclosure is expressly laid down by Union or Member State law with appropriate measures to protect the data subject's legitimate interests.
Personal data must remain confidential due to an obligation of professional secrecy regulated by law.
legitimate_interest_exceptions: Disproportionate effort exception applies, but controller must take appropriate measures to protect data subject's rights and interests, including making information publicly available.
public_interest_exceptions: Processing for archiving in the public interest, scientific or historical research, or statistical purposes, subject to Article 89(1).

technical_measures: Implement systems to track and provide required information to data subjects within specified timeframes.
Ensure mechanisms for identifying and managing international data transfers and related safeguards.
organizational_measures: Establish procedures for providing information to data subjects when data are not obtained directly.
Develop policies for handling exceptions and documenting decisions.
security_measures: Protect personal data in accordance with GDPR Article 32 (not explicitly mentioned in this section but implied by overall GDPR context).
training_requirements: Train staff on information provision obligations and exception handling.
audit_requirements: Regularly review compliance with information provision requirements and exception documentation.

enforcement.regulatory_authority: Supervisory authorities designated by each EU Member State (e.g., Data Protection Authorities)

penalties.financial_penalties: Administrative fines up to â‚¬20,000,000 or up to 4% of the total worldwide annual turnover of the preceding financial year, whichever is higher (per GDPR Article 83).
penalties.administrative_penalties: Orders to comply, restrictions on processing, or bans on processing.
penalties.reputational_consequences: Public disclosure of violations and enforcement actions.

amendment_history: Adopted on 27 April 2016, applicable from 25 May 2018

related_articles: GDPR Article 13 (Information to be provided where personal data are collected from the data subject)
GDPR Article 9 (Processing of special categories of personal data)
GDPR Article 22 (Automated individual decision-making, including profiling)
GDPR Article 46 (Transfers subject to appropriate safeguards)
GDPR Article 89(1) (Safeguards and derogations relating to processing for archiving, research, or statistical purposes)
complementary_regulations: National data protection laws implementing GDPR
superseded_regulations: Data Protection Directive 95/46/EC (for EU Member States)

implementation_steps: Identify all instances where personal data are obtained from sources other than the data subject.
Prepare standardized information notices covering all required elements.
Establish processes to deliver information within the required timeframes.
Document any reliance on exceptions and the measures taken to protect data subject rights.
Ensure mechanisms for updating data subjects if further processing for new purposes is planned.
Train staff on obligations and exception handling.
common_violations: Failure to provide required information to data subjects.
Providing incomplete or unclear information.
Not meeting the specified timeframes for information provision.
Improper reliance on exceptions without adequate safeguards.
Failure to document exception decisions.
best_practices: Use layered privacy notices for clarity.
Automate notification processes where possible.
Regularly review and update information notices.
Maintain clear records of all communications with data subjects.
Make information publicly available when relying on the disproportionate effort exception.
compliance_checklist: Have you identified all indirect data collection activities?
Do your notices include all required information?
Are you providing information within one month or at the first communication/disclosure?
Are exception cases documented and justified?
Are staff trained on these requirements?
Is there a process for updating data subjects about further processing?

key_definitions.controller: The natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which, alone or jointly with others, determines the purposes and means of the processing of personal data.
key_definitions.data subject: An identified or identifiable natural person whose personal data are processed.
key_definitions.personal data: Any information relating to an identified or identifiable natural person.
key_definitions.data protection officer: A person designated by the controller or processor to oversee data protection strategy and compliance.
key_definitions.recipient: A natural or legal person, public authority, agency or another body, to which the personal data are disclosed.
key_definitions.third country: A country outside the European Economic Area (EEA).
key_definitions.automated decision-making: Making decisions about individuals solely by automated means without human involvement.
key_definitions.profiling: Any form of automated processing of personal data to evaluate certain personal aspects relating to a natural person.

cleaned_regulations.source_section: ## Information to be provided where personal data have not been obtained from the data subject

cleaned_regulations.regulation_name: General Data Protection Regulation (EU) 2016/679, Article 15 â€“ Right of access by the data subject

description.brief_summary: GDPR Article 15 grants data subjects the right to access their personal data and obtain specific information about its processing from controllers.
description.detailed_explanation: This article requires controllers to confirm whether they process personal data relating to a data subject and, if so, to provide access to that data and detailed information about the processing. This includes the purposes, categories, recipients (especially in third countries or international organisations), storage periods, rights to rectification/erasure/restriction/objection, complaint mechanisms, data sources, and the existence of automated decision-making. Where data is transferred internationally, data subjects must be informed of safeguards. Controllers must provide a copy of the data, may charge a reasonable fee for additional copies, and must provide data in electronic form if requested electronically. The right to access must not adversely affect the rights and freedoms of others.
description.purpose: To ensure transparency and empower individuals to understand and control how their personal data is processed.
description.legislative_intent: To provide individuals with meaningful control over their personal data and to promote accountability and transparency among data controllers.

what_it_covers: Right of access to personal data
Obligation to provide confirmation of processing
Disclosure of processing purposes
Disclosure of data categories
Disclosure of recipients (including third countries/international organisations)
Disclosure of storage periods or criteria
Information on rights to rectification, erasure, restriction, objection
Information on complaint mechanisms
Disclosure of data sources (if not collected from data subject)
Information on automated decision-making and profiling
Information on safeguards for international data transfers
Provision of copies of personal data

who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Entities established in the EU or processing data of individuals in the EU

what_it_does_not_cover: Access to data that would adversely affect the rights and freedoms of others

mandatory_obligations: Provide confirmation to data subject whether personal data is being processed
Provide access to personal data if processed

Provide the following information upon request: purposes of processing, categories of data, recipients or categories of recipients (including third countries/international organisations), envisaged storage period or criteria, rights to rectification/erasure/restriction/objection, right to lodge complaint with supervisory authority, source of data if not collected from data subject, existence of automated decision-making (including profiling), meaningful information about logic, significance, and consequences
Inform data subject of appropriate safeguards for international transfers (pursuant to Article 46)
Provide a copy of personal data undergoing processing
Provide information in a commonly used electronic form if requested electronically (unless otherwise requested)
prohibited_actions: Do not provide access in a way that adversely affects the rights and freedoms of others
conditional_requirements: May charge a reasonable fee based on administrative costs for further copies requested by the data subject

general_restrictions: The right to obtain a copy shall not adversely affect the rights and freedoms of others
data_restrictions: Limitations on providing data if it would adversely affect others' rights and freedoms
operational_restrictions: Reasonable fee may be charged for additional copies
technical_restrictions: Information must be provided in a commonly used electronic form if requested electronically, unless otherwise requested

individual_rights: Right to obtain confirmation of processing
Right to access personal data

Right to receive information on processing purposes, data categories, recipients, storage periods/criteria, rights to rectification/erasure/restriction/objection, complaint mechanisms, data sources, automated decision-making
Right to be informed of safeguards for international transfers
Right to receive a copy of personal data
Right to receive information in electronic form if requested electronically
organizational_rights: Right to charge a reasonable fee for additional copies
how_to_exercise_rights: Submit a request to the data controller
Specify if information should be provided electronically

general_exceptions: Right to obtain a copy does not apply if it would adversely affect the rights and freedoms of others
conditional_exemptions: Controller may charge a reasonable fee for additional copies

technical_measures: Ability to provide data in a commonly used electronic form
organizational_measures: Procedures for handling data subject access requests

enforcement.regulatory_authority: Supervisory authorities designated by EU Member States (e.g., Data Protection Authorities)

penalties.financial_penalties: Administrative fines up to â‚¬20,000,000 or up to 4% of the total worldwide annual turnover, whichever is higher (see GDPR Article 83)
penalties.administrative_penalties: Orders to comply, reprimands, temporary or definitive bans on processing
penalties.reputational_consequences: Public disclosure of violations, potential loss of customer trust

enforcement_mechanisms: Complaints by data subjects to supervisory authorities
Investigations and audits by supervisory authorities
Imposition of administrative fines and corrective measures

related_articles: Article 12 (Transparent information, communication and modalities for the exercise of the rights of the data subject)
Article 13 (Information to be provided where personal data are collected from the data subject)
Article 14 (Information to be provided where personal data have not been obtained from the data subject)
Article 19 (Notification obligation regarding rectification or erasure of personal data or restriction of processing)
complementary_regulations: EU Charter of Fundamental Rights Article 8

implementation_steps: Establish procedures for receiving and verifying data subject access requests
Ensure systems can retrieve and export personal data in a commonly used electronic format
Train staff on handling access requests and identifying when exceptions apply
Document responses and maintain records of requests and responses
Implement mechanisms to identify and protect the rights and freedoms of others when providing data
common_violations: Failure to respond to access requests
Providing incomplete or incorrect information
Charging excessive fees for additional copies
Not providing information in electronic form when requested
Disclosing data that infringes on the rights and freedoms of others
best_practices: Respond promptly and transparently to access requests
Use secure methods to transmit personal data
Clearly communicate any fees for additional copies
Regularly review and update access request procedures
Assess and document potential impacts on third parties before disclosing data
compliance_checklist: Is there a documented process for handling access requests?
Can the organization confirm whether personal data is being processed?
Can the organization provide all required information listed in Article 15(1)?
Are procedures in place to provide data in electronic form if requested?
Is there a process to assess and protect the rights and freedoms of others?
Are fees for additional copies reasonable and based on administrative costs?
Are staff trained to recognize and handle access requests?

key_definitions.data subject: An identified or identifiable natural person whose personal data is processed.
key_definitions.controller: The natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which, alone or jointly with others, determines the purposes and means of the processing of personal data.
key_definitions.personal data: Any information relating to an identified or identifiable natural person.
key_definitions.processing: Any operation or set of operations which is performed on personal data or on sets of personal data, whether or not by automated means.
key_definitions.supervisory authority: An independent public authority established by a Member State pursuant to Article 51.
key_definitions.third country: A country outside the European Union and the European Economic Area.
key_definitions.international organisation: An organisation and its subordinate bodies governed by public international law, or any other body which is set up by, or on the basis of, an agreement between two or more countries.

cleaned_regulations.source_section: ## Right of access by the data subject

cleaned_regulations.regulation_name: General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)

description.brief_summary: GDPR Article 16 grants data subjects the right to obtain rectification of inaccurate personal data and to have incomplete data completed, including by providing a supplementary statement.
description.detailed_explanation: This regulation requires data controllers to rectify inaccurate personal data concerning a data subject without undue delay upon request. It also obliges controllers to complete incomplete personal data, considering the purposes of processing, which may include accepting a supplementary statement from the data subject. The right is unconditional and must be facilitated promptly by the controller.
description.purpose: To ensure the accuracy and completeness of personal data processed by organizations, thereby protecting the rights and freedoms of individuals.
description.legislative_intent: Lawmakers intended to empower individuals to maintain control over their personal data and to prevent harm or disadvantage resulting from inaccurate or incomplete data.

what_it_covers: Rectification of inaccurate personal data
Completion of incomplete personal data
Submission of supplementary statements by data subjects

who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Entities established in the EU or processing data of individuals in the EU

what_it_does_not_cover: Data not classified as personal data
Entities or processing activities outside the scope of GDPR

mandatory_obligations: Controllers MUST rectify inaccurate personal data concerning the data subject without undue delay.
Controllers MUST complete incomplete personal data, including by means of a supplementary statement, if requested by the data subject and relevant to the purposes of processing.
prohibited_actions: Controllers MUST NOT ignore or unduly delay rectification requests from data subjects.
conditional_requirements: Rectification and completion must take into account the purposes of the processing.
documentation_requirements: Controllers SHOULD document requests for rectification and actions taken (implied by GDPR accountability principle, though not explicit in this section).
timeline_requirements: Rectification must be carried out 'without undue delay' (no specific timeframe, but generally interpreted as within one month under GDPR Article 12(3)).

general_restrictions: Rectification is limited to personal data that is inaccurate or incomplete.
data_restrictions: Only personal data as defined by GDPR is subject to rectification.
geographic_restrictions: Applies to processing activities within the EU or targeting EU data subjects.

individual_rights: Right to obtain rectification of inaccurate personal data
Right to have incomplete personal data completed, including by providing a supplementary statement
how_to_exercise_rights: Data subject submits a request to the controller for rectification or completion of their personal data.

technical_measures: Implement systems to allow prompt rectification and completion of personal data.
organizational_measures: Establish procedures for handling rectification requests.
training_requirements: Train staff on handling data subject rectification requests.

enforcement.regulatory_authority: Supervisory Authorities in each EU Member State (e.g., Data Protection Authorities)

penalties.financial_penalties: Administrative fines up to â‚¬20 million or 4% of annual global turnover, whichever is higher, for non-compliance with data subject rights under GDPR.
penalties.administrative_penalties: Orders to comply, reprimands, temporary or definitive bans on processing.
penalties.reputational_consequences: Public disclosure of infringements, potential loss of customer trust.

related_regulations.parent_legislation: EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, Article 8

implementation_steps: Establish a process for receiving and verifying rectification requests.
Update data promptly upon verification of inaccuracy or incompleteness.
Allow data subjects to provide supplementary statements.
Document actions taken in response to requests.
common_violations: Failure to respond to rectification requests in a timely manner.
Refusal to correct or complete personal data without valid justification.
Lack of procedures for handling such requests.
best_practices: Maintain clear communication channels for data subjects.
Regularly review and update personal data for accuracy.
Train staff on data subject rights and procedures.
compliance_checklist: Is there a documented procedure for rectification requests?
Are requests processed without undue delay?
Can data subjects provide supplementary statements?
Are actions taken documented and auditable?

key_definitions.data subject: An identified or identifiable natural person to whom personal data relates.
key_definitions.controller: The natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which, alone or jointly with others, determines the purposes and means of the processing of personal data.
key_definitions.personal data: Any information relating to an identified or identifiable natural person.
key_definitions.rectification: The act of correcting inaccurate or incomplete personal data.

cleaned_regulations.regulation_name: General Data Protection Regulation (EU) 2016/679, Article 17 â€“ Right to erasure (â€˜right to be forgottenâ€™)

description.brief_summary: Article 17 of the GDPR grants individuals the right to request the erasure of their personal data under specific circumstances and obliges data controllers to erase such data without undue delay, subject to certain exceptions.
description.detailed_explanation: The regulation establishes the right of data subjects to obtain from the controller the erasure of personal data concerning them without undue delay. Controllers are obligated to erase personal data without undue delay when certain grounds apply, such as when the data is no longer necessary, consent is withdrawn, the data subject objects to processing, the data has been unlawfully processed, erasure is required by law, or the data was collected in relation to information society services offered to children. If the data has been made public, controllers must take reasonable steps to inform other controllers processing the data of the erasure request. The right to erasure is subject to exceptions, including freedom of expression, legal obligations, public interest in public health, archiving, research, statistical purposes, and legal claims.
description.purpose: To empower individuals with control over their personal data and to ensure that personal data is not retained longer than necessary or processed unlawfully.
description.legislative_intent: To strengthen data subject rights, enhance privacy protections, and harmonize data protection laws across the EU by providing clear mechanisms for individuals to have their personal data erased and by setting out the responsibilities of data controllers.

what_it_covers: Erasure of personal data upon request by the data subject
Obligations of data controllers to erase personal data
Notification to other controllers when data has been made public
Grounds for erasure
Exceptions to the right to erasure

who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Entities established in the EU or processing personal data of individuals in the EU

what_it_does_not_cover: Processing necessary for freedom of expression and information
Processing required by law or for public interest tasks
Processing for public health, archiving, research, or statistical purposes where erasure would impair objectives
Processing for establishment, exercise, or defence of legal claims

mandatory_obligations: Erase personal data without undue delay when one of the specified grounds applies
Take reasonable steps, including technical measures, to inform other controllers processing the data if the data was made public
Assess and respond to erasure requests from data subjects
prohibited_actions: Retaining personal data when there is no legal ground for processing and a valid erasure request has been made
Refusing erasure without a valid exception
conditional_requirements: Erasure is required only if one of the grounds in Article 17(1) applies
Notification to other controllers is required only if the data has been made public
Exceptions apply if processing is necessary for specified purposes
documentation_requirements: Maintain records of erasure requests and actions taken
Document grounds for refusal if erasure is denied
reporting_requirements: Inform data subjects of actions taken in response to their erasure requests
timeline_requirements: Erasure must be carried out 'without undue delay'

general_restrictions: Right to erasure does not apply where processing is necessary for specified exceptions
data_restrictions: Personal data must not be retained beyond necessity or legal grounds
operational_restrictions: Controllers must implement processes to handle erasure requests promptly
technical_restrictions: Controllers must take reasonable technical measures to inform other controllers when data has been made public
geographic_restrictions: Applies to processing of personal data of individuals in the EU, regardless of controller location

individual_rights: Right to obtain erasure of personal data ('right to be forgotten')
Right to request erasure from all controllers processing the data if made public
how_to_exercise_rights: Data subject submits a request to the controller for erasure
Controller must assess the request and respond accordingly
If data has been made public, controller must inform other controllers

general_exceptions: Processing necessary for exercising the right of freedom of expression and information
Processing necessary for compliance with a legal obligation or for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest or in the exercise of official authority
Processing necessary for reasons of public interest in the area of public health

Processing necessary for archiving purposes in the public interest, scientific or historical research purposes, or statistical purposes where erasure would render impossible or seriously impair objectives
Processing necessary for the establishment, exercise, or defence of legal claims
conditional_exemptions: Partial exemption for archiving, research, or statistical purposes if erasure would impair objectives
legitimate_interest_exceptions: If there are overriding legitimate grounds for processing under Article 21(1)
public_interest_exceptions: Processing for public interest in public health
Processing for public interest tasks or exercise of official authority

technical_measures: Implement technical measures to erase data and inform other controllers when data is public
organizational_measures: Establish procedures for handling erasure requests
Maintain documentation of requests and responses
security_measures: Ensure secure erasure of personal data
training_requirements: Train staff on handling data subject rights and erasure requests

enforcement.regulatory_authority: Supervisory authorities designated by each EU Member State (e.g., Data Protection Authorities)

penalties.financial_penalties: Administrative fines up to â‚¬20,000,000 or up to 4% of the total worldwide annual turnover of the preceding financial year, whichever is higher (GDPR Article 83)
penalties.administrative_penalties: Orders to comply, reprimands, temporary or definitive bans on processing
penalties.reputational_consequences: Public disclosure of non-compliance, potential loss of customer trust

complementary_regulations: National data protection laws of Member States

implementation_steps: Establish and document a process for receiving and verifying erasure requests
Assess whether any of the grounds for erasure apply
Erase personal data without undue delay if required
If data was made public, take reasonable steps to inform other controllers
Document all actions taken and reasons for any refusal
Train staff on erasure procedures and exceptions
common_violations: Failure to erase data in a timely manner
Failure to inform other controllers when data was made public
Improper denial of erasure requests
Lack of documentation of requests and responses
best_practices: Automate erasure processes where possible
Maintain clear records of all requests and actions
Regularly review data retention policies
Ensure all staff are trained on data subject rights
compliance_checklist: Is there a documented erasure request process?
Are requests assessed and responded to without undue delay?
Are exceptions properly documented when invoked?
Is there a process to notify other controllers if data was made public?
Are staff trained on the right to erasure?
