cleaned_regulations.regulation_name: General Data Protection Regulation (EU) 2016/679, Article 18 â€“ Right to restriction of processing

industry_sectors: All sectors processing personal data within the EU or of EU data subjects

description.brief_summary: GDPR Article 18 grants data subjects the right to obtain restriction of processing of their personal data under certain conditions and imposes obligations on controllers regarding the handling and notification of such restrictions.
description.detailed_explanation: This regulation provides that data subjects can request the restriction of processing of their personal data in specific situations: when the accuracy of the data is contested, when processing is unlawful but erasure is opposed, when the controller no longer needs the data but the data subject requires it for legal claims, or when the data subject has objected to processing pending verification of overriding legitimate grounds. During restriction, processing is limited to storage except with the data subject's consent or for legal claims, protection of others' rights, or important public interest. Controllers must inform data subjects before lifting the restriction.
description.purpose: To empower individuals to control the processing of their personal data and to ensure fair and lawful processing, especially in cases of dispute or legal necessity.
description.legislative_intent: To provide a mechanism for individuals to pause or limit processing of their data in situations where their rights or interests may be at risk, and to ensure transparency and accountability from data controllers.

what_it_covers: Restriction of processing of personal data
Circumstances under which restriction can be requested
Permitted processing activities during restriction
Notification obligations before lifting restriction

who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Entities established in the EU or processing data of EU data subjects

what_it_does_not_cover: Processing of non-personal data
Entities not subject to GDPR
Processing outside the scope of GDPR

mandatory_obligations: Controllers MUST restrict processing of personal data upon valid request by the data subject under specified conditions.
Controllers MUST inform the data subject before lifting the restriction of processing.
prohibited_actions: Controllers MUST NOT process restricted personal data except for storage or as otherwise permitted under the exceptions.
conditional_requirements: Restriction MUST be granted if: (a) accuracy of data is contested, (b) processing is unlawful and erasure is opposed, (c) data is no longer needed by controller but required by data subject for legal claims, (d) data subject has objected to processing pending verification of legitimate grounds.
documentation_requirements: Controllers SHOULD document requests for restriction and actions taken (implied by accountability principle, not explicit in this section).
reporting_requirements: Controllers MUST notify the data subject before lifting the restriction.
timeline_requirements: Restriction applies for a period enabling the controller to verify the accuracy of the personal data (when accuracy is contested).

general_restrictions: Processing of restricted personal data is limited to storage except under specified exceptions.
data_restrictions: Personal data under restriction may only be processed with the data subject's consent, for legal claims, to protect rights of another person, or for important public interest.
operational_restrictions: Controllers must not use restricted data for other processing purposes.

individual_rights: Right to obtain restriction of processing of personal data under specified conditions.
Right to be informed before the restriction is lifted.
how_to_exercise_rights: Data subject submits a request to the controller specifying the grounds for restriction.
Controller must assess and implement restriction if conditions are met.
Controller must notify data subject before lifting restriction.

general_exceptions: Restriction does not apply if none of the specified conditions are met.
conditional_exemptions: Processing of restricted data is permitted with the data subject's consent, for legal claims, to protect rights of another person, or for important public interest.
legitimate_interest_exceptions: Processing may continue pending verification of whether the controller's legitimate grounds override those of the data subject (when objection is made under Article 21(1)).
public_interest_exceptions: Processing of restricted data is permitted for reasons of important public interest of the Union or of a Member State.

technical_measures: Implement technical controls to restrict processing of personal data as required.
organizational_measures: Establish procedures for handling restriction requests.
Ensure notification processes are in place for informing data subjects before lifting restriction.
security_measures: Ensure restricted data is protected from unauthorized processing.
training_requirements: Train staff on handling restriction of processing requests and related obligations.

enforcement.regulatory_authority: Supervisory Authorities designated under GDPR (e.g., national Data Protection Authorities)

penalties.financial_penalties: Administrative fines up to â‚¬20 million or 4% of annual global turnover, whichever is higher, for non-compliance with data subject rights.
penalties.administrative_penalties: Orders to comply, temporary or definitive limitation including a ban on processing.
penalties.reputational_consequences: Public disclosure of violations, potential loss of customer trust.

related_articles: GDPR Article 19 (Notification obligation regarding rectification or erasure of personal data or restriction of processing)
complementary_regulations: National data protection laws implementing GDPR

implementation_steps: Establish and document a process for receiving and evaluating restriction requests.
Implement technical and organizational measures to restrict processing as required.
Train staff on recognizing and handling restriction requests.
Ensure mechanisms are in place to notify data subjects before lifting restrictions.
common_violations: Failure to restrict processing when required.
Processing restricted data for unauthorized purposes.
Not informing data subjects before lifting restriction.
best_practices: Maintain clear records of restriction requests and actions taken.
Regularly review and update procedures for handling data subject rights.
Ensure transparency with data subjects regarding their rights and the status of their requests.
compliance_checklist: Are procedures in place for handling restriction requests?
Are technical controls implemented to enforce restrictions?
Is staff trained on these requirements?
Is there a process to notify data subjects before lifting restrictions?

cleaned_regulations.regulation_name: General Data Protection Regulation (EU) 2016/679 Article 19 â€“ Notification obligation regarding rectification or erasure of personal data or restriction of processing

industry_sectors: All sectors processing personal data within the EU/EEA or targeting EU/EEA data subjects

description.brief_summary: GDPR Article 19 requires data controllers to notify all recipients of personal data about any rectification, erasure, or restriction of processing, unless this is impossible or involves disproportionate effort. Controllers must also inform data subjects about these recipients upon request.
description.detailed_explanation: This article mandates that whenever a data controller rectifies, erases, or restricts the processing of personal data in accordance with Articles 16 (rectification), 17(1) (erasure), or 18 (restriction), the controller must communicate these actions to every recipient to whom the personal data has been disclosed. The only exceptions are if such communication is impossible or would require disproportionate effort. Furthermore, if the data subject requests, the controller is obliged to inform them about the recipients who have received the personal data.
description.purpose: To ensure transparency and accountability in the handling of personal data, and to allow data subjects to track the dissemination and correction of their personal data.
description.legislative_intent: Lawmakers intended to strengthen data subject rights by ensuring that corrections, deletions, or restrictions are propagated to all parties who have received the data, thereby preventing continued processing of outdated or incorrect information.

what_it_covers: Notification to recipients of personal data about rectification
Notification to recipients of personal data about erasure
Notification to recipients of personal data about restriction of processing
Informing data subjects about recipients upon request

entity_types: Any organization acting as a data controller
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Entities established in the EU/EEA or processing data of EU/EEA data subjects

what_it_does_not_cover: Notification to recipients when it is impossible
Notification to recipients when it involves disproportionate effort
Processors (unless acting as controllers)

mandatory_obligations: Communicate any rectification, erasure, or restriction of processing to each recipient to whom the personal data have been disclosed
Inform the data subject about those recipients if the data subject requests it
prohibited_actions: Failing to notify recipients unless impossible or disproportionate effort applies
Refusing to inform data subjects about recipients upon request
conditional_requirements: Notification to recipients is not required if it proves impossible or involves disproportionate effort
documentation_requirements: Maintain records of disclosures to recipients
Document reasons if notification to recipients is not carried out due to impossibility or disproportionate effort
reporting_requirements: Provide information to data subjects about recipients upon request

general_restrictions: Notification to recipients is not required if it is impossible or involves disproportionate effort
data_restrictions: Rectification, erasure, or restriction must be communicated only to recipients of the personal data
operational_restrictions: Controllers must assess and justify if notification is impossible or disproportionate

individual_rights: Right to be informed about recipients of personal data upon request
organizational_rights: Right for controllers to refrain from notification if impossible or disproportionate effort
how_to_exercise_rights: Data subject submits a request to the controller to be informed about recipients

general_exceptions: Notification to recipients is not required if it proves impossible or involves disproportionate effort
conditional_exemptions: Controller must assess and document impossibility or disproportionate effort

technical_measures: Systems to track disclosures of personal data to recipients
organizational_measures: Procedures for notifying recipients of rectification, erasure, or restriction
Procedures for responding to data subject requests regarding recipients
training_requirements: Staff training on notification obligations and handling data subject requests
audit_requirements: Periodic review of notification processes and records

enforcement.regulatory_authority: Supervisory Authorities designated under GDPR (e.g., national Data Protection Authorities in EU Member States)

penalties.financial_penalties: Administrative fines up to â‚¬10,000,000 or up to 2% of the total worldwide annual turnover, whichever is higher, as per GDPR Article 83(4)
penalties.administrative_penalties: Orders to comply, reprimands, temporary or definitive bans on processing
penalties.reputational_consequences: Public disclosure of non-compliance, potential loss of trust

amendment_history: No substantive amendments since entry into force

related_articles: Article 12 (Transparent information, communication and modalities for the exercise of the rights of the data subject)
complementary_regulations: National data protection laws implementing GDPR

implementation_steps: Maintain an up-to-date record of all recipients of personal data
Establish procedures for notifying recipients of rectification, erasure, or restriction
Develop a process for responding to data subject requests regarding recipients
Document cases where notification is impossible or involves disproportionate effort
common_violations: Failure to notify recipients of rectification, erasure, or restriction
Failure to inform data subjects about recipients upon request
Inadequate documentation of impossibility or disproportionate effort
best_practices: Automate tracking of data disclosures
Train staff on notification and request handling procedures
Regularly review and update notification processes
compliance_checklist: Are all recipients of personal data tracked and recorded?
Is there a documented process for notifying recipients of changes?
Are data subject requests for recipient information handled promptly?
Are exceptions (impossibility/disproportionate effort) documented and justified?

key_definitions.controller: The natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which, alone or jointly with others, determines the purposes and means of the processing of personal data.

cleaned_regulations.regulation_name: General Data Protection Regulation (EU) 2016/679 Article 20 â€“ Right to data portability

industry_sectors: All sectors processing personal data of EU data subjects

description.brief_summary: GDPR Article 20 grants data subjects the right to receive their personal data in a structured, commonly used, and machine-readable format and to transmit those data to another controller, subject to certain conditions and exceptions.
description.detailed_explanation: This article provides data subjects with the right to data portability, allowing them to obtain and reuse their personal data across different services. The right applies when processing is based on consent or contract and is carried out by automated means. It includes the right to have data transmitted directly between controllers where technically feasible. The right does not apply to processing necessary for tasks in the public interest or the exercise of official authority, and must not adversely affect the rights and freedoms of others. The exercise of this right is without prejudice to the right to erasure (Article 17).
description.purpose: To empower individuals with control over their personal data and facilitate the free flow of personal data across services and providers.
description.legislative_intent: To enhance data subject autonomy, promote competition and innovation, and ensure interoperability and user control in the digital economy.

what_it_covers: Right to receive personal data provided to a controller
Right to receive data in a structured, commonly used, and machine-readable format
Right to transmit personal data to another controller without hindrance
Right to have data transmitted directly between controllers where technically feasible

who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Entities processing personal data of individuals in the EU/EEA

what_it_does_not_cover: Processing necessary for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest
Processing in the exercise of official authority vested in the controller
Processing not based on consent or contract
Processing not carried out by automated means
Processing where data portability would adversely affect the rights and freedoms of others

mandatory_obligations: Controllers must provide personal data to the data subject in a structured, commonly used, and machine-readable format upon request
Controllers must allow data subjects to transmit their personal data to another controller without hindrance
Controllers must transmit personal data directly to another controller if technically feasible
prohibited_actions: Controllers must not hinder the transmission of personal data to another controller
Controllers must not process data portability requests in a way that adversely affects the rights and freedoms of others
conditional_requirements: Right applies only where processing is based on consent (Article 6(1)(a) or Article 9(2)(a)) or contract (Article 6(1)(b))
Right applies only where processing is carried out by automated means
Direct transmission between controllers is required only where technically feasible

general_restrictions: Exercise of the right to data portability must not prejudice Article 17 (right to erasure)
Right does not apply to processing necessary for public interest tasks or official authority
Right must not adversely affect the rights and freedoms of others
data_restrictions: Applies only to personal data provided by the data subject
Does not apply to derived or inferred data
operational_restrictions: Direct transmission is only required where technically feasible
technical_restrictions: Data must be provided in a structured, commonly used, and machine-readable format

individual_rights: Right to receive personal data provided to a controller
Right to receive data in a structured, commonly used, and machine-readable format
Right to transmit personal data to another controller without hindrance
Right to have personal data transmitted directly between controllers where technically feasible

Data subject may request direct transmission to another controller if technically feasible

security_measures: Ensure secure transfer of personal data during portability

penalties.administrative_penalties: Corrective orders, reprimands, temporary or definitive bans on processing
penalties.reputational_consequences: Public disclosure of non-compliance, reputational damage

enforcement_mechanisms: Complaints by data subjects to supervisory authorities
Investigations and audits by supervisory authorities
Imposition of administrative fines and corrective measures

implementation_steps: Develop and maintain export functionality for personal data in required formats
Establish and document procedures for receiving and responding to data portability requests
Assess technical feasibility for direct transmission to other controllers
Train staff on handling data portability requests
Ensure security measures for data transfers
common_violations: Failure to provide data in a structured, commonly used, and machine-readable format
Unjustified refusal to transmit data to another controller
Imposing undue hindrance on data portability requests

best_practices: Use interoperable data formats (e.g., CSV, JSON, XML)
Provide clear instructions to data subjects on how to exercise their rights
Document all data portability requests and responses
Regularly review and update data portability procedures
compliance_checklist: Is there a process for data subjects to request data portability?
Can personal data be exported in a structured, commonly used, and machine-readable format?
Is there a procedure for direct transmission to another controller?
Are requests handled without undue delay and without hindrance?
Are exceptions and limitations properly documented and applied?

cleaned_regulations.regulation_name: General Data Protection Regulation (EU) 2016/679, Article 21 â€“ Right to object

industry_sectors: All sectors processing personal data within the EU or targeting EU residents

description.brief_summary: Article 21 of the GDPR grants data subjects the right to object to the processing of their personal data under certain legal bases, including for direct marketing and profiling, and sets out the obligations of controllers to respect such objections unless specific exceptions apply.
description.detailed_explanation: This article establishes that data subjects can object, at any time and on grounds relating to their particular situation, to the processing of their personal data when such processing is based on the controllerâ€™s legitimate interests (Article 6(1)(f)) or the performance of a task carried out in the public interest or in the exercise of official authority (Article 6(1)(e)), including profiling based on these grounds. Upon objection, the controller must cease processing unless they can demonstrate compelling legitimate grounds that override the interests, rights, and freedoms of the data subject, or the processing is necessary for legal claims. For direct marketing purposes, including related profiling, the data subject has an unconditional right to object, and the controller must stop processing for these purposes. The right to object must be explicitly communicated to the data subject at the latest at the time of first communication and must be presented clearly and separately. In the context of information society services, the right may be exercised by automated means. For processing for scientific, historical, or statistical purposes under Article 89(1), the right to object applies unless processing is necessary for public interest tasks.
description.purpose: To empower individuals to control the use of their personal data and to provide a mechanism to prevent unwanted or inappropriate processing, especially for direct marketing and profiling.
description.legislative_intent: To strengthen data subject rights, ensure transparency, and provide effective means for individuals to object to data processing that may impact their privacy or interests, while balancing legitimate interests and public interest needs.

what_it_covers: Right to object to processing based on Article 6(1)(e) or (f)
Right to object to profiling based on Article 6(1)(e) or (f)
Right to object to processing for direct marketing purposes
Right to object to profiling related to direct marketing
Right to object to processing for scientific, historical research, or statistical purposes under Article 89(1)
Obligation to inform data subjects of their right to object
Means of exercising the right to object, including automated means

who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Entities established in the EU or processing data of individuals in the EU

what_it_does_not_cover: Processing not based on Article 6(1)(e) or (f)
Processing where overriding compelling legitimate grounds exist
Processing necessary for the establishment, exercise, or defence of legal claims
Processing for scientific, historical, or statistical purposes necessary for public interest tasks

mandatory_obligations: Data controllers must cease processing personal data upon objection unless exceptions apply
Data controllers must inform data subjects of their right to object at the latest at the time of first communication
The right to object must be presented clearly and separately from other information
Data controllers must stop processing for direct marketing purposes upon objection
Controllers must allow the right to object to be exercised by automated means in the context of information society services
prohibited_actions: Continuing to process personal data for direct marketing purposes after objection
Failing to inform data subjects of their right to object

Processing may continue if necessary for the establishment, exercise, or defence of legal claims
For scientific, historical, or statistical purposes, processing may continue if necessary for public interest tasks

general_restrictions: Processing must stop upon valid objection unless exceptions apply
data_restrictions: No further processing for direct marketing purposes after objection

operational_restrictions: Controllers must implement processes to handle objections and cease processing as required
technical_restrictions: Controllers must enable automated means for exercising the right to object in information society services

Right to object to profiling based on Article 6(1)(e) or (f)
Right to object to processing for direct marketing purposes at any time

Right to object to processing for scientific, historical, or statistical purposes under certain conditions
organizational_rights: Right to continue processing if compelling legitimate grounds exist or for legal claims
Right to continue processing for research/statistics if necessary for public interest tasks
how_to_exercise_rights: By submitting an objection to the controller
By automated means using technical specifications in the context of information society services

general_exceptions: Processing may continue if controller demonstrates compelling legitimate grounds overriding the data subjectâ€™s interests, rights, and freedoms
Processing may continue if necessary for the establishment, exercise, or defence of legal claims
conditional_exemptions: For scientific, historical, or statistical purposes, processing may continue if necessary for public interest tasks
legitimate_interest_exceptions: Compelling legitimate grounds for processing override the data subjectâ€™s objection
public_interest_exceptions: Processing necessary for the performance of a task carried out for reasons of public interest

technical_measures: Implement systems to allow automated objections in information society services
Ensure technical capability to cease processing upon objection
organizational_measures: Policies and procedures for handling objections
Clear communication of the right to object
training_requirements: Staff training on handling objections and data subject rights
audit_requirements: Periodic review of objection handling processes

enforcement.regulatory_authority: Supervisory Authorities in each EU Member State (e.g., Data Protection Authorities)

penalties.financial_penalties: Administrative fines up to â‚¬20 million or 4% of total worldwide annual turnover, whichever is higher, for non-compliance with data subject rights
penalties.administrative_penalties: Orders to cease processing, corrective orders, warnings, reprimands
penalties.reputational_consequences: Public disclosure of violations, potential loss of customer trust

related_articles: GDPR Article 12 (Transparent information, communication and modalities for the exercise of the rights of the data subject)

key_definitions.data subject: An identified or identifiable natural person whose personal data is processed.

key_definitions.processing: Any operation or set of operations which is performed on personal data or on sets of personal data, whether or not by automated means.

cleaned_regulations.regulation_name: General Data Protection Regulation (EU) 2016/679, Article 22: Automated individual decision-making, including profiling

description.brief_summary: GDPR Article 22 grants individuals the right not to be subject to decisions based solely on automated processing, including profiling, that produce legal or similarly significant effects, except in certain cases. It also requires safeguards and sets restrictions on the use of special categories of data.
description.detailed_explanation: This article prohibits organizations from subjecting individuals to decisions based solely on automated processing, including profiling, if those decisions produce legal effects or similarly significantly affect the individual. There are exceptions if the decision is necessary for a contract, authorized by law with safeguards, or based on explicit consent. In such cases, organizations must implement measures to safeguard the individual's rights, including the right to human intervention, to express their point of view, and to contest the decision. Additional restrictions apply when processing special categories of personal data, requiring further legal basis and safeguards.
description.purpose: To protect individuals from potentially harmful effects of automated decision-making and profiling, ensuring transparency, fairness, and the ability to challenge such decisions.
description.legislative_intent: Lawmakers intended to prevent adverse consequences for individuals from automated decisions, promote accountability in data processing, and ensure individuals retain meaningful control over decisions that affect them.

what_it_covers: Automated individual decision-making
Profiling
Decisions producing legal effects or similarly significant effects on individuals

who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Entities established in the EU or offering goods/services to or monitoring individuals in the EU

what_it_does_not_cover: Decisions not based solely on automated processing
Decisions without legal or similarly significant effects
Processing outside the scope of GDPR

mandatory_obligations: Do not subject individuals to decisions based solely on automated processing, including profiling, which produce legal effects or similarly significantly affect them, except as provided in exceptions.
Implement suitable measures to safeguard the data subject's rights and freedoms and legitimate interests in cases where exceptions apply.
Provide at least the right to obtain human intervention, to express their point of view, and to contest the decision in cases under exceptions (a) and (c).
prohibited_actions: Making decisions based solely on automated processing, including profiling, that produce legal or similarly significant effects on individuals, unless an exception applies.
Basing such decisions on special categories of personal data unless Article 9(2)(a) or (g) applies and suitable safeguards are in place.
conditional_requirements: Automated decisions are permitted if necessary for entering into or performance of a contract, authorized by Union or Member State law with safeguards, or based on explicit consent.
If based on special categories of data, must comply with Article 9(2)(a) or (g) and implement suitable safeguards.

general_restrictions: Automated decision-making with legal or similarly significant effects is generally prohibited unless an exception applies.
data_restrictions: Decisions must not be based on special categories of personal data unless specific legal bases and safeguards are met.
operational_restrictions: Organizations must implement measures to allow human intervention, expression of viewpoint, and contestation of decisions in applicable cases.

individual_rights: Right not to be subject to a decision based solely on automated processing, including profiling, which produces legal or similarly significant effects.
Right to obtain human intervention from the controller.
Right to express their point of view.
Right to contest the decision.
how_to_exercise_rights: Individuals may request human intervention, express their viewpoint, or contest the decision through the data controller's established processes.

general_exceptions: Paragraph 1 shall not apply if the decision is necessary for entering into, or performance of, a contract between the data subject and a data controller.

Paragraph 1 shall not apply if the decision is authorized by Union or Member State law to which the controller is subject and which also lays down suitable measures to safeguard the data subject's rights and freedoms and legitimate interests.
Paragraph 1 shall not apply if the decision is based on the data subject's explicit consent.
conditional_exemptions: For decisions based on special categories of personal data, exemption applies only if Article 9(2)(a) (explicit consent) or (g) (substantial public interest) applies and suitable safeguards are in place.
public_interest_exceptions: Authorized by Union or Member State law with suitable safeguards.

technical_measures: Implement systems to allow human intervention in automated decision-making processes.
organizational_measures: Establish procedures for individuals to express their viewpoint and contest decisions.
Implement policies to identify and manage automated decision-making activities.

enforcement.regulatory_authority: Supervisory Authorities designated under GDPR in each EU Member State

penalties.financial_penalties: Administrative fines up to â‚¬20,000,000 or up to 4% of the total worldwide annual turnover of the preceding financial year, whichever is higher, for infringements of the rights of data subjects.
penalties.administrative_penalties: Orders to cease processing, corrective orders, or other administrative actions.
penalties.reputational_consequences: Public disclosure of violations, potential reputational damage.

related_articles: Article 9 (Processing of special categories of personal data)

implementation_steps: Identify all automated decision-making and profiling activities.
Assess whether such decisions produce legal or similarly significant effects.
Determine if any exceptions apply (contract, law, explicit consent).
Implement procedures for human intervention, expression of viewpoint, and contestation.
Ensure additional safeguards for special categories of data.
Document decision-making processes and safeguards.
common_violations: Failing to provide human intervention in automated decisions.
Relying on automated decisions without a valid exception.
Using special categories of data without proper legal basis and safeguards.
Not informing data subjects of their rights.
best_practices: Minimize reliance on automated-only decision-making.
Clearly inform individuals of automated processing and their rights.
Regularly review and test automated decision systems for fairness and accuracy.
Maintain clear documentation of processes and safeguards.
compliance_checklist: Are any decisions made solely by automated means?
Do these decisions have legal or similarly significant effects?
Is there a valid exception (contract, law, explicit consent)?
Are suitable safeguards in place (human intervention, viewpoint, contestation)?
Are special categories of data involved, and if so, is Article 9(2)(a) or (g) satisfied?
Are individuals informed of their rights and how to exercise them?

key_definitions.automated processing: Processing of personal data by automated means without human involvement.
key_definitions.profiling: Any form of automated processing of personal data consisting of the use of personal data to evaluate certain personal aspects relating to a natural person.
key_definitions.data subject: An identified or identifiable natural person whose personal data is processed.
key_definitions.controller: The natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which, alone or jointly with others, determines the purposes and means of the processing of personal data.
key_definitions.special categories of personal data: Personal data revealing racial or ethnic origin, political opinions, religious or philosophical beliefs, or trade union membership, and the processing of genetic data, biometric data for the purpose of uniquely identifying a natural person, data concerning health or data concerning a natural person's sex life or sexual orientation.

cleaned_regulations.regulation_name: General Data Protection Regulation (EU) 2016/679, Article 23 â€“ Restrictions

description.brief_summary: Article 23 of the GDPR allows Union or Member State law to restrict certain data protection rights and obligations via legislative measures, provided such restrictions are necessary and proportionate to safeguard specific public interests.
description.detailed_explanation: This article permits the EU or its Member States to enact laws that restrict the scope of rights and obligations under Articles 12 to 22 and Article 34 of the GDPR, as well as Article 5 where relevant. Such restrictions must be enacted by legislative measure, respect the essence of fundamental rights and freedoms, and be necessary and proportionate in a democratic society. The permissible grounds for restriction include national security, defence, public security, prevention/investigation of crimes, important public interests (including economic/financial interests, public health, social security), judicial independence, breaches of ethics for regulated professions, regulatory functions, protection of data subjects or others' rights, and enforcement of civil law claims. Any legislative measure must specify the purposes, categories of data, scope, safeguards, controllers, storage periods, risks, and information rights regarding the restriction.
description.purpose: To allow for the restriction of certain data protection rights and obligations in order to protect overriding public interests or the rights and freedoms of others, while ensuring such restrictions are lawful, necessary, and proportionate.
description.legislative_intent: To balance the fundamental rights to data protection with other essential public interests and legal obligations, ensuring that restrictions are only imposed where justified and with appropriate safeguards.

what_it_covers: Restriction of data subject rights under Articles 12-22 and Article 34
Restriction of obligations of data controllers/processors under the same articles
Restriction of Article 5 provisions as they relate to Articles 12-22

who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Entities subject to Union or Member State law

what_it_does_not_cover: Restrictions not based on legislative measures
Restrictions that do not respect the essence of fundamental rights and freedoms
Restrictions that are not necessary and proportionate in a democratic society

mandatory_obligations: Any restriction must be established by a legislative measure
Restriction must respect the essence of fundamental rights and freedoms
Restriction must be necessary and proportionate in a democratic society

Legislative measure must contain specific provisions at least as to: purposes of processing, categories of personal data, scope of restrictions, safeguards to prevent abuse or unlawful access/transfer, specification of controller(s), storage periods and safeguards, risks to data subjects' rights and freedoms, and the right to be informed about the restriction (unless prejudicial to the purpose)
prohibited_actions: Imposing restrictions without a legislative basis
Imposing restrictions that do not respect fundamental rights and freedoms
Imposing restrictions that are not necessary and proportionate
conditional_requirements: The right of data subjects to be informed about the restriction may be withheld if informing them would be prejudicial to the purpose of the restriction
documentation_requirements: Legislative measure must specify: purposes, categories of data, scope, safeguards, controllers, storage periods, risks, and information rights
timeline_requirements: Storage periods must be specified in the legislative measure

general_restrictions: Restriction of rights and obligations under Articles 12-22, Article 34, and relevant parts of Article 5
data_restrictions: Restriction on access, rectification, erasure, restriction of processing, data portability, objection, and notification obligations
operational_restrictions: Restriction on the obligation to notify data subjects of data breaches (Article 34)
technical_restrictions: Safeguards must be implemented to prevent abuse or unlawful access or transfer
geographic_restrictions: Restrictions must be based on Union or Member State law

individual_rights: Data subjects retain the right to be informed about the restriction, unless this would be prejudicial to the purpose of the restriction
how_to_exercise_rights: Data subjects may be informed about the restriction unless informing them would prejudice the purpose

general_exceptions: Restrictions do not apply unless established by legislative measure
conditional_exemptions: The right to be informed about the restriction does not apply if it would be prejudicial to the purpose of the restriction
public_interest_exceptions: Restrictions may be imposed to safeguard: national security, defence, public security, prevention/investigation/detection/prosecution of criminal offences, execution of criminal penalties, important objectives of general public interest (including economic/financial interests, public health, social security), judicial independence, breaches of ethics for regulated professions, regulatory functions, protection of data subject or others' rights, enforcement of civil law claims

technical_measures: Safeguards to prevent abuse or unlawful access or transfer of personal data
organizational_measures: Specification of controller(s) or categories of controllers
Policies for storage periods and applicable safeguards
security_measures: Safeguards appropriate to the nature, scope, and purposes of processing

enforcement.regulatory_authority: Supervisory authorities designated by each Member State under the GDPR

penalties.financial_penalties: Fines as specified under GDPR for non-compliance with restrictions or failure to implement required safeguards
penalties.administrative_penalties: Administrative sanctions as provided by supervisory authorities
penalties.reputational_consequences: Potential public disclosure of non-compliance

implementation_steps: Review applicable Union or Member State laws for any legislative restrictions
Ensure legislative measures meet all specified requirements
Implement safeguards to prevent abuse or unlawful access/transfer
Document purposes, categories of data, scope, controllers, storage periods, and risks
Inform data subjects of restrictions unless prejudicial to the purpose
common_violations: Imposing restrictions without legislative basis
Failing to specify required elements in legislative measures
Not implementing adequate safeguards
Not informing data subjects when required
best_practices: Consult legal counsel before applying any restrictions
Maintain clear documentation of legislative basis and safeguards
Regularly review and update policies in line with legislative changes
compliance_checklist: Is there a legislative measure authorizing the restriction?
Does the measure specify all required elements?
Are safeguards in place to prevent abuse or unlawful access?
Are data subjects informed where required?
Are storage periods and risks documented?

key_definitions.legislative measure: A law or regulation enacted by the Union or a Member State that has binding legal effect.
key_definitions.data subject: An identified or identifiable natural person whose personal data is processed.
key_definitions.controller: The natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which, alone or jointly with others, determines the purposes and means of the processing of personal data.
key_definitions.processor: A natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which processes personal data on behalf of the controller.

cleaned_regulations.regulation_name: General Data Protection Regulation (EU) 2016/679, Article 24 â€“ Responsibility of the controller

description.brief_summary: Article 24 of the GDPR establishes the obligation for data controllers to implement and demonstrate appropriate technical and organisational measures to ensure that personal data processing is compliant with the Regulation, taking into account the nature, scope, context, and purposes of processing, as well as risks to individuals.
description.detailed_explanation: This article requires controllers to assess the risks associated with their data processing activities and to implement suitable technical and organisational measures to ensure and demonstrate compliance with the GDPR. These measures must be reviewed and updated as necessary. Where proportionate, controllers must also implement data protection policies. Adherence to approved codes of conduct (Article 40) or certification mechanisms (Article 42) can be used to demonstrate compliance. The article emphasizes accountability and the need for ongoing review and adaptation of measures.
description.purpose: To ensure that data controllers are accountable for the protection of personal data and that they proactively implement and maintain appropriate safeguards.
description.legislative_intent: To create a culture of accountability among data controllers, requiring them to take responsibility for data protection and to be able to demonstrate compliance to supervisory authorities and data subjects.

what_it_covers: Implementation of technical and organisational measures
Review and update of such measures
Adoption of data protection policies
Adherence to codes of conduct and certification mechanisms
Demonstration of compliance with GDPR

entity_types: Any entity acting as a data controller
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Entities established in the EU or processing data of individuals in the EU

what_it_does_not_cover: Obligations of data processors
Specific technical standards (left to controller's discretion)
Processing outside the scope of GDPR

mandatory_obligations: Implement appropriate technical and organisational measures to ensure and demonstrate that processing is performed in accordance with this Regulation
Review and update those measures where necessary
prohibited_actions: Failing to implement or update appropriate measures
conditional_requirements: Where proportionate in relation to processing activities, implement appropriate data protection policies
Adherence to approved codes of conduct or certification mechanisms may be used to demonstrate compliance
documentation_requirements: Maintain documentation demonstrating compliance with implemented measures
timeline_requirements: Measures must be reviewed and updated 'where necessary' (no fixed timeline specified)

general_restrictions: Measures must be appropriate to the nature, scope, context, and purposes of processing, and to the risks for the rights and freedoms of natural persons
data_restrictions: Processing must be performed in accordance with the Regulation
operational_restrictions: Controllers must be able to demonstrate compliance
technical_restrictions: Technical measures must be appropriate to the risks
geographic_restrictions: Applies to processing in the context of activities of an establishment in the EU or targeting individuals in the EU

individual_rights: Right to have personal data processed in accordance with the GDPR
organizational_rights: Right to use codes of conduct and certification mechanisms to demonstrate compliance
how_to_exercise_rights: Individuals may request evidence of compliance from controllers
Organizations may adhere to approved codes of conduct or certification mechanisms

conditional_exemptions: Implementation of data protection policies is only required where proportionate in relation to processing activities

technical_measures: Implement technical safeguards appropriate to the risks
organizational_measures: Implement organisational safeguards appropriate to the risks
Adopt data protection policies where proportionate
security_measures: Ensure security of processing as part of appropriate measures
audit_requirements: Be able to demonstrate compliance (implies readiness for audits or assessments)
certification_requirements: Adherence to approved certification mechanisms (optional, as a means to demonstrate compliance)

enforcement.regulatory_authority: Supervisory authorities designated by each EU Member State (e.g., Data Protection Authorities)

penalties.financial_penalties: Administrative fines up to â‚¬10,000,000 or up to 2% of the total worldwide annual turnover of the preceding financial year, whichever is higher (per GDPR Article 83(4))
penalties.administrative_penalties: Orders to bring processing operations into compliance, warnings, reprimands
penalties.reputational_consequences: Public disclosure of non-compliance, potential damage to reputation

related_articles: Article 5 (Principles relating to processing of personal data)

implementation_steps: Assess the nature, scope, context, and purposes of processing
Conduct risk assessments for processing activities
Implement appropriate technical and organisational measures
Document measures and compliance efforts
Review and update measures as necessary
Consider adopting data protection policies where proportionate
Consider adherence to approved codes of conduct or certification mechanisms
common_violations: Failure to implement adequate measures
Failure to review and update measures
Inability to demonstrate compliance
Lack of proportionate data protection policies
best_practices: Regularly review and update technical and organisational measures
Maintain clear documentation of compliance efforts
Participate in certification schemes or codes of conduct
Integrate data protection into business processes
compliance_checklist: Risk assessment conducted
Appropriate measures implemented
Measures reviewed and updated
Data protection policies in place (where proportionate)
Documentation available to demonstrate compliance
Consideration of codes of conduct/certification

key_definitions.controller: The natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which, alone or jointly with others, determines the purposes and means of the processing of personal data.
key_definitions.processing: Any operation or set of operations which is performed on personal data or on sets of personal data, whether or not by automated means.
key_definitions.technical and organisational measures: Measures designed to implement data protection principles and safeguard data subjectsâ€™ rights.

cleaned_regulations.regulation_name: General Data Protection Regulation (EU) 2016/679, Article 25: Data protection by design and by default

description.brief_summary: GDPR Article 25 requires data controllers to implement appropriate technical and organizational measures to ensure data protection principles are integrated into processing activities, both at the design stage and by default, limiting data processing to what is necessary and safeguarding data subjectsâ€™ rights.
description.detailed_explanation: This article obliges data controllers to proactively embed data protection into the design of processing systems and operations (data protection by design) and to ensure that, by default, only personal data necessary for each processing purpose are processed (data protection by default). Controllers must consider the state of the art, cost of implementation, nature, scope, context, and purposes of processing, and the risks to individualsâ€™ rights and freedoms. Measures such as pseudonymisation and data minimisation are specifically mentioned. The article also allows the use of approved certification mechanisms (per Article 42) as evidence of compliance.
description.purpose: To ensure that data protection is an integral part of processing activities and systems, minimizing risks to individuals and ensuring compliance with GDPR requirements.
description.legislative_intent: Lawmakers intended to shift data protection from a reactive to a proactive approach, requiring organizations to build privacy and security into their systems and processes from the outset and to limit data processing to what is strictly necessary.

what_it_covers: Implementation of technical and organizational measures for data protection
Integration of data protection principles into processing activities
Limitation of personal data processing to what is necessary
Safeguarding rights and freedoms of data subjects
Use of certification mechanisms to demonstrate compliance

who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Entities established in the EU or processing data of individuals in the EU

what_it_does_not_cover: Processing by individuals for purely personal or household activities
Processing outside the material scope of the GDPR

mandatory_obligations: Implement appropriate technical and organisational measures, such as pseudonymisation, designed to implement data-protection principles (e.g., data minimisation) in an effective manner
Integrate necessary safeguards into processing to meet GDPR requirements and protect data subjectsâ€™ rights
Consider the state of the art, cost of implementation, nature, scope, context, and purposes of processing, and risks to individuals when determining measures
Ensure that, by default, only personal data necessary for each specific purpose are processed
Limit the amount of personal data collected, extent of processing, period of storage, and accessibility to what is necessary
Ensure that, by default, personal data are not made accessible to an indefinite number of natural persons without the individual's intervention
prohibited_actions: Processing more personal data than necessary for the specified purpose
Making personal data accessible by default to an indefinite number of natural persons
conditional_requirements: Use of an approved certification mechanism pursuant to Article 42 may be used as an element to demonstrate compliance
timeline_requirements: Measures must be implemented both at the time of determination of the means for processing and at the time of the processing itself

general_restrictions: Processing must be limited to what is necessary for each specific purpose
data_restrictions: Amount of personal data collected must be limited
Extent of processing must be limited
Period of storage must be limited
Accessibility must be limited
operational_restrictions: Personal data must not be made accessible by default to an indefinite number of natural persons
technical_restrictions: Implementation of technical measures such as pseudonymisation

individual_rights: Right to have personal data protected by design and by default
Right to limitation of data processing to what is necessary
organizational_rights: Right to use approved certification mechanisms to demonstrate compliance

technical_measures: Pseudonymisation
Other appropriate technical measures to implement data protection principles
organizational_measures: Organisational measures designed to implement data protection principles and integrate safeguards
security_measures: Measures to protect the rights of data subjects
certification_requirements: Use of an approved certification mechanism pursuant to Article 42 may be used as an element to demonstrate compliance

enforcement.regulatory_authority: Supervisory authorities designated under GDPR (e.g., national Data Protection Authorities)

penalties.financial_penalties: Administrative fines up to â‚¬10,000,000 or up to 2% of the total worldwide annual turnover of the preceding financial year, whichever is higher (per GDPR Article 83(4))
penalties.administrative_penalties: Corrective orders, reprimands, temporary or definitive limitations including bans on processing
penalties.reputational_consequences: Public disclosure of infringements, potential reputational damage

related_articles: GDPR Article 5 (Principles relating to processing of personal data)

implementation_steps: Assess processing activities for risks to data subjects
Design systems and processes with data protection principles integrated from the outset
Limit data collection, processing, storage, and accessibility to what is necessary
Implement technical measures such as pseudonymisation
Establish organizational policies and procedures for data protection by design and by default
Consider certification under approved mechanisms to demonstrate compliance
common_violations: Collecting more data than necessary
Failing to implement technical or organizational safeguards
Making personal data accessible by default to too many people
Not considering risks to individuals when designing processing activities
best_practices: Conduct Data Protection Impact Assessments (DPIAs)
Adopt privacy engineering principles
Regularly review and update technical and organizational measures
Train staff on data protection by design and by default
compliance_checklist: Are technical and organizational measures implemented at both design and processing stages?
Is data minimisation enforced by default?
Is access to personal data restricted by default?
Are risks to data subjects assessed and mitigated?
Is there documentation of measures taken?
Is certification under Article 42 considered or obtained?

key_definitions.data protection by design: The integration of data protection principles and safeguards into processing activities and systems from the outset.
key_definitions.data protection by default: Ensuring that, by default, only personal data necessary for each specific purpose are processed, stored, and accessible.
key_definitions.pseudonymisation: The processing of personal data in such a manner that the data can no longer be attributed to a specific data subject without the use of additional information.
key_definitions.controller: The natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which, alone or jointly with others, determines the purposes and means of the processing of personal data.

cleaned_regulations.regulation_name: General Data Protection Regulation (EU) 2016/679, Article 26: Joint controllers

description.brief_summary: Article 26 of the GDPR establishes the legal framework for situations where two or more controllers jointly determine the purposes and means of processing personal data, requiring them to transparently define and document their respective responsibilities for compliance, especially regarding data subject rights and information provision.
description.detailed_explanation: This article applies when two or more entities jointly determine why and how personal data is processed. Such entities are considered 'joint controllers' and must, through a transparent arrangement, allocate their respective responsibilities for GDPR compliance, particularly concerning the exercise of data subject rights and the provision of information as required by Articles 13 and 14. The arrangement must reflect the roles and relationships of the joint controllers and its essence must be made available to data subjects. Regardless of the arrangement, data subjects retain the right to exercise their GDPR rights against any joint controller. The arrangement may also designate a contact point for data subjects. If Union or Member State law determines the responsibilities, those legal provisions take precedence.
description.purpose: To ensure clear allocation of compliance responsibilities among joint controllers and to guarantee that data subjects can effectively exercise their rights.
description.legislative_intent: Lawmakers intended to promote transparency, accountability, and effective protection of data subject rights in situations involving joint decision-making over personal data processing.

what_it_covers: Situations where two or more controllers jointly determine the purposes and means of processing personal data
Allocation of compliance responsibilities among joint controllers
Provision of information to data subjects (Articles 13 and 14)
Exercise of data subject rights under the GDPR

entity_types: Any legal or natural person acting as a controller
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Entities established in the EU or processing data of individuals in the EU

what_it_does_not_cover: Controllers acting independently (not jointly determining purposes and means)
Processors (unless they also act as controllers)
Processing activities outside the scope of the GDPR

mandatory_obligations: Joint controllers MUST determine their respective responsibilities for compliance with the GDPR in a transparent manner
Joint controllers MUST specifically address the exercise of data subject rights and provision of information under Articles 13 and 14
Joint controllers MUST set out these responsibilities by means of an arrangement between them, unless Union or Member State law determines otherwise
The arrangement MUST duly reflect the respective roles and relationships of the joint controllers vis-Ã -vis the data subjects
The essence of the arrangement MUST be made available to the data subject
prohibited_actions: Joint controllers MUST NOT prevent data subjects from exercising their rights against any of the controllers, regardless of the arrangement
conditional_requirements: If Union or Member State law determines the respective responsibilities of the controllers, the arrangement is not required to allocate those responsibilities
documentation_requirements: An arrangement documenting the allocation of responsibilities between joint controllers
Documentation must reflect roles and relationships
Essence of the arrangement must be available to data subjects

general_restrictions: Allocation of responsibilities must be transparent
Arrangement must not override data subject rights to act against any controller
operational_restrictions: Joint controllers must act in accordance with the arrangement unless overridden by law

individual_rights: Right to exercise GDPR rights in respect of and against each of the joint controllers
Right to be informed of the essence of the arrangement between joint controllers
organizational_rights: Right to designate a contact point for data subjects in the arrangement
how_to_exercise_rights: Data subjects may contact any joint controller to exercise their rights under the GDPR, regardless of the internal arrangement

general_exceptions: If Union or Member State law determines the respective responsibilities of the controllers, the arrangement is not required to allocate those responsibilities
conditional_exemptions: Partial exemption from the arrangement requirement if responsibilities are set by law

organizational_measures: Establish and document an arrangement between joint controllers
Ensure transparency in allocation of responsibilities
Make the essence of the arrangement available to data subjects

enforcement.regulatory_authority: Supervisory authorities designated under the GDPR in each EU Member State

penalties.financial_penalties: Administrative fines up to â‚¬10,000,000 or up to 2% of the total worldwide annual turnover, whichever is higher, for infringements of obligations of controllers and processors under Articles 8, 11, 25 to 39 and 42 and 43 (see Article 83(4) GDPR)
penalties.administrative_penalties: Orders to comply, restrictions or bans on processing, corrective orders
penalties.reputational_consequences: Public disclosure of infringements, potential reputational damage

related_articles: GDPR Article 13 (Information to be provided where personal data are collected from the data subject)
GDPR Article 14 (Information to be provided where personal data have not been obtained from the data subject)
complementary_regulations: National data protection laws implementing or supplementing the GDPR

implementation_steps: Identify situations where joint controllership exists
Negotiate and document an arrangement allocating GDPR compliance responsibilities
Ensure arrangement addresses data subject rights and information provision
Make the essence of the arrangement available to data subjects
Designate a contact point for data subjects if appropriate
Review and update arrangements as necessary
common_violations: Failure to document joint controllership arrangements
Lack of transparency in allocation of responsibilities
Not making the essence of the arrangement available to data subjects
Preventing data subjects from exercising rights against any joint controller
best_practices: Use clear, accessible language in arrangements
Regularly review and update joint controller arrangements
Provide a single contact point for data subjects
Train staff on joint controllership obligations
compliance_checklist: Are all joint controller relationships identified?
Is there a documented arrangement allocating responsibilities?
Does the arrangement address data subject rights and information provision?
Is the essence of the arrangement available to data subjects?
Are data subjects able to exercise their rights against any joint controller?

key_definitions.joint controllers: Two or more controllers who jointly determine the purposes and means of processing personal data.
key_definitions.controller: The natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which, alone or jointly with others, determines the purposes and means of the processing of personal data.
key_definitions.arrangement: A documented agreement between joint controllers specifying their respective responsibilities for GDPR compliance.

cleaned_regulations.regulation_name: General Data Protection Regulation (EU) 2016/679, Article 27 â€“ Representatives of controllers or processors not established in the Union

industry_sectors: All sectors processing personal data of individuals in the EU

description.brief_summary: Requires controllers or processors not established in the EU, but subject to GDPR under Article 3(2), to appoint a representative in the EU, with certain exceptions.
description.detailed_explanation: Article 27 of the GDPR mandates that controllers or processors who are not established in the EU, but who process personal data of data subjects in the EU in relation to offering goods or services or monitoring their behavior, must designate a representative in writing in the EU. The representative must be established in a Member State where the relevant data subjects are located. The representative acts as a point of contact for supervisory authorities and data subjects on all issues related to processing, to ensure compliance with the GDPR. There are exceptions for occasional processing, processing not on a large scale of special categories of data or criminal data, and for public authorities or bodies. The appointment of a representative does not affect the liability of the controller or processor.
description.purpose: To ensure that non-EU controllers and processors subject to the GDPR have a local point of contact for regulatory oversight and data subject rights.
description.legislative_intent: To facilitate enforcement of the GDPR and the exercise of data subject rights against organizations outside the EU that process EU residents' data.

what_it_covers: Designation of an EU representative by non-EU controllers/processors
Processing of personal data of data subjects in the EU under Article 3(2)
Mandate and responsibilities of the representative
Communication with supervisory authorities and data subjects

who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Entities not established in the EU but processing data of EU data subjects under Article 3(2)

what_it_does_not_cover: Processing which is occasional, does not include, on a large scale, processing of special categories of data as referred to in Article 9(1) or processing of personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences referred to in Article 10, and is unlikely to result in a risk to the rights and freedoms of natural persons
Public authorities or bodies

mandatory_obligations: Controllers or processors subject to Article 3(2) must designate in writing a representative in the Union
The representative must be established in one of the Member States where the data subjects are located
The representative must be mandated to be addressed by supervisory authorities and data subjects on all issues related to processing
prohibited_actions: Failing to designate a representative when required under Article 3(2) and not covered by an exception
conditional_requirements: Obligation to designate a representative does not apply if processing is occasional, does not include, on a large scale, processing of special categories of data or criminal data, and is unlikely to result in a risk to the rights and freedoms of natural persons
Obligation does not apply to public authorities or bodies
documentation_requirements: Written designation of the representative

general_restrictions: Representative must be established in a Member State where the relevant data subjects are located
data_restrictions: Exemption applies if processing does not include, on a large scale, special categories of data or criminal data
operational_restrictions: Representative must be able to be addressed by supervisory authorities and data subjects
geographic_restrictions: Representative must be established in the EU, specifically in a Member State where data subjects are located

individual_rights: Data subjects have the right to address the representative on all issues related to processing, for the purposes of ensuring compliance with the Regulation
how_to_exercise_rights: Data subjects and supervisory authorities may contact the representative in addition to or instead of the controller or processor

general_exceptions: Obligation to designate a representative does not apply to public authorities or bodies
conditional_exemptions: Obligation does not apply to processing which is occasional, does not include, on a large scale, processing of special categories of data or criminal data, and is unlikely to result in a risk to the rights and freedoms of natural persons
public_interest_exceptions: Public authorities or bodies are exempt

organizational_measures: Written appointment of a representative
Mandate for the representative to act as a contact point

enforcement.regulatory_authority: Supervisory authorities of the relevant EU Member States

penalties.financial_penalties: Fines as per GDPR Article 83, up to â‚¬10,000,000 or 2% of total worldwide annual turnover, whichever is higher, for non-compliance
penalties.administrative_penalties: Orders to comply, possible bans on processing
penalties.reputational_consequences: Public disclosure of non-compliance

complementary_regulations: GDPR Article 14 (Information where data not obtained from data subject)

implementation_steps: Assess whether Article 3(2) applies to your processing activities
Determine if any exceptions apply (occasional processing, no large-scale special/criminal data, low risk, or public authority)
If required, select and appoint a representative in writing in an appropriate EU Member State
Mandate the representative to act as a contact point for supervisory authorities and data subjects
Document the appointment and mandate
common_violations: Failure to appoint a representative when required
Appointing a representative in the wrong Member State
Not providing the representative with an adequate mandate
best_practices: Conduct a thorough assessment of processing activities for applicability
Choose a reputable representative with experience in GDPR compliance
Clearly define the representative's mandate and responsibilities in writing
Regularly review the arrangement to ensure ongoing compliance
compliance_checklist: Is the organization established outside the EU?
Does it process personal data of individuals in the EU under Article 3(2)?
Is the processing occasional, non-large scale, and low risk?
Is the organization a public authority or body?
Has a representative been appointed in writing?
Is the representative established in a relevant Member State?
Is the representative mandated to be addressed by supervisory authorities and data subjects?

key_definitions.controller: The natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which, alone or jointly with others, determines the purposes and means of the processing of personal data.
key_definitions.processor: A natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which processes personal data on behalf of the controller.
key_definitions.representative: A natural or legal person established in the Union who, designated in writing by the controller or processor, represents the controller or processor with regard to their respective obligations under the GDPR.
key_definitions.special categories of data: Personal data revealing racial or ethnic origin, political opinions, religious or philosophical beliefs, or trade union membership, and the processing of genetic data, biometric data for the purpose of uniquely identifying a natural person, data concerning health or data concerning a natural person's sex life or sexual orientation (Article 9(1)).
key_definitions.criminal data: Personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences (Article 10).
