cleaned_regulations.regulation_name: General Data Protection Regulation (EU) 2016/679, Article 28 â€“ Processor

description.brief_summary: GDPR Article 28 establishes the legal framework for the use of data processors by controllers, specifying requirements for processor selection, contractual terms, sub-processing, and compliance mechanisms.
description.detailed_explanation: This article mandates that controllers may only use processors providing sufficient guarantees for technical and organizational measures to ensure GDPR compliance and data subject rights protection. It requires that processing by a processor be governed by a binding contract or legal act, specifying the processing's subject-matter, duration, nature, purpose, data types, data subject categories, and the obligations and rights of the controller. The processor must only act on documented instructions, ensure confidentiality, take security measures (per Article 32), assist the controller in fulfilling data subject rights and compliance obligations, delete or return data after processing, and allow audits. Sub-processors may only be engaged with controller authorization, and the same obligations must be imposed on them. Adherence to codes of conduct or certification may demonstrate sufficient guarantees. Standard contractual clauses may be used. If a processor determines processing purposes and means, it is considered a controller. Contracts must be in writing, including electronic form.
description.purpose: To ensure that personal data processed on behalf of controllers is handled securely, lawfully, and in accordance with the GDPR, protecting data subjects' rights.
description.legislative_intent: To create clear, enforceable obligations for processors and controllers, ensure accountability, and prevent misuse or mishandling of personal data by third parties.

what_it_covers: Selection of data processors by controllers
Processor obligations and guarantees
Contractual requirements for processing
Engagement of sub-processors
Technical and organizational measures
Assistance with data subject rights
Compliance with Articles 32-36
Data deletion or return after processing
Audit and inspection rights
Use of codes of conduct and certification
Standard contractual clauses
Liability for sub-processors
Distinction between processor and controller roles

who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Entities established in the EU or processing data of individuals in the EU

what_it_does_not_cover: Processing not on behalf of a controller
Processing outside the scope of the GDPR
Purely personal or household activities

mandatory_obligations: Controllers must use only processors providing sufficient guarantees for technical and organizational measures.
Processors must not engage another processor without prior specific or general written authorization of the controller.
Processors must inform controllers of intended changes to sub-processors and allow objections.
Processing must be governed by a binding contract or legal act under Union or Member State law.
The contract must set out subject-matter, duration, nature, purpose, type of personal data, categories of data subjects, and obligations and rights of the controller.
Processors must process data only on documented instructions from the controller.
Processors must ensure confidentiality of authorized persons.
Processors must take all measures required by Article 32 (security of processing).
Processors must respect conditions for engaging sub-processors.
Processors must assist controllers in fulfilling data subject rights (Chapter III).
Processors must assist controllers in compliance with Articles 32-36.
Processors must delete or return all personal data after processing, unless required by law to retain.
Processors must make available all information necessary to demonstrate compliance and allow/contribute to audits.
Processors must immediately inform controllers if an instruction infringes the GDPR or other data protection provisions.
Same data protection obligations must be imposed on sub-processors by contract or legal act.
Initial processor remains fully liable for sub-processor obligations.
Contracts may be based on standard contractual clauses adopted by the Commission or supervisory authority.
Contracts must be in writing, including electronic form.
prohibited_actions: Processors must not engage another processor without controller's written authorization.
Processors must not process data except on documented instructions from the controller, unless required by law.
Processors must not retain personal data after processing unless required by law.
conditional_requirements: If general written authorization is used, processors must inform controllers of changes to sub-processors and allow objections.
If required by Union or Member State law to process data, processors must inform controllers unless prohibited by law.
Adherence to approved codes of conduct or certification mechanisms may be used to demonstrate sufficient guarantees.
If a processor determines purposes and means of processing, it is considered a controller for that processing.
documentation_requirements: Written contract or legal act between controller and processor (including electronic form).
Documentation of subject-matter, duration, nature, purpose, data types, data subject categories, obligations, and rights.
Records of sub-processor engagements and authorizations.
Information necessary to demonstrate compliance.
reporting_requirements: Processors must inform controllers of intended changes to sub-processors.
Processors must immediately inform controllers if an instruction infringes the GDPR or other data protection provisions.
timeline_requirements: Processors must delete or return personal data after the end of processing services, unless retention is required by law.

general_restrictions: Processors may only act on documented instructions from the controller.
Processors may only engage sub-processors with controller authorization.
Processors must not retain data after processing unless required by law.
data_restrictions: Processors must ensure confidentiality of personal data.
Processors must implement appropriate technical and organizational measures.
Processors must delete or return data after processing.
operational_restrictions: Processors must allow and contribute to audits and inspections by the controller or mandated auditor.
technical_restrictions: Processors must take all measures required by Article 32 (security of processing).
geographic_restrictions: Transfers of personal data to third countries or international organizations must be on documented instructions or required by law.

individual_rights: Data subjects' rights under Chapter III of the GDPR (e.g., access, rectification, erasure, restriction, data portability, objection).
organizational_rights: Controllers have the right to object to changes in sub-processors.
Controllers have the right to audit and inspect processors.
Controllers have the right to require deletion or return of data after processing.
how_to_exercise_rights: Controllers exercise audit rights via contract.
Controllers object to sub-processor changes upon notification.
Data subjects exercise rights through the controller, with processor assistance.

general_exceptions: Processors may process data without controller instructions if required by Union or Member State law, but must inform the controller unless prohibited by law.
conditional_exemptions: Processors may retain data after processing if required by Union or Member State law.
public_interest_exceptions: Processors may be prohibited from informing controllers of legal requirements to process data on important grounds of public interest.

technical_measures: Implement appropriate technical measures to ensure data security (per Article 32).
organizational_measures: Implement appropriate organizational measures to ensure GDPR compliance.
Ensure confidentiality commitments or statutory obligations for authorized persons.
Maintain written contracts with controllers and sub-processors.
security_measures: Take all measures required by Article 32 (security of processing).
audit_requirements: Allow and contribute to audits and inspections by the controller or mandated auditor.
certification_requirements: Adherence to approved codes of conduct (Article 40) or certification mechanisms (Article 42) may be used to demonstrate sufficient guarantees.

enforcement.regulatory_authority: Supervisory authorities in each EU Member State; European Data Protection Board; European Commission (for standard contractual clauses).

penalties.financial_penalties: Administrative fines up to â‚¬10,000,000 or up to 2% of total worldwide annual turnover, whichever is higher, for infringements of processor obligations (per Article 83(4)).
penalties.administrative_penalties: Orders to comply, suspension of data processing, or other corrective powers.
penalties.reputational_consequences: Public disclosure of violations; potential loss of business relationships.

related_articles: Article 5 (Principles relating to processing of personal data)
Article 83 (General conditions for imposing administrative fines)

implementation_steps: Select processors with sufficient guarantees for GDPR compliance.
Draft and execute a binding contract or legal act with all required elements.
Obtain and document controller authorization for sub-processors.
Implement technical and organizational measures for data security.
Ensure confidentiality commitments for authorized personnel.
Assist controllers with data subject rights and compliance obligations.
Delete or return personal data after processing, unless retention is required by law.
Maintain documentation and make information available for audits.
Monitor sub-processor compliance and remain liable for their actions.
Consider adherence to codes of conduct or certification mechanisms.
common_violations: Engaging sub-processors without controller authorization.
Processing data without documented instructions.
Failure to implement adequate security measures.
Not deleting or returning data after processing.
Refusing or failing to allow audits.
Lack of proper contractual terms.
best_practices: Use standard contractual clauses where possible.
Regularly review and update processor contracts.
Maintain a register of sub-processors and notify controllers of changes.
Conduct due diligence on all processors and sub-processors.
Provide regular training to staff on data protection obligations.
Document all compliance activities.
compliance_checklist: Processor provides sufficient guarantees.
Written contract or legal act in place.
All required contract elements included.
Sub-processor authorization documented.
Technical and organizational measures implemented.
Confidentiality ensured for authorized persons.
Assistance with data subject rights provided.
Data deleted or returned after processing.
Audit rights enabled.
Compliance with Articles 32-36 supported.
Adherence to codes of conduct/certification considered.

key_definitions.controller: The natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which, alone or jointly with others, determines the purposes and means of the processing of personal data.
key_definitions.processor: A natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which processes personal data on behalf of the controller.
key_definitions.sub-processor: A processor engaged by another processor to carry out specific processing activities on behalf of the controller.
key_definitions.personal data: Any information relating to an identified or identifiable natural person ('data subject').
key_definitions.documented instructions: Instructions from the controller to the processor, provided in writing or other documented form, regarding the processing of personal data.

cleaned_regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation), Article 29

description.brief_summary: This article restricts processors and persons acting under the authority of the controller or processor from processing personal data except on documented instructions from the controller, unless required by Union or Member State law.
description.detailed_explanation: GDPR Article 29 mandates that processors and any person acting under the authority of the controller or processor (including employees and sub-processors) who have access to personal data must not process those data except on documented instructions from the controller. The only exception is where processing is required by Union or Member State law. This ensures that data processing is controlled and only occurs under lawful instructions, thereby protecting data subjects' rights and ensuring accountability.
description.purpose: To ensure that personal data is only processed under the explicit instructions of the data controller, thereby safeguarding data subjects' rights and maintaining accountability in data processing operations.
description.legislative_intent: Lawmakers intended to prevent unauthorized or uncontrolled processing of personal data by processors or persons under their authority, ensuring that all processing is traceable to the controller's instructions or a clear legal obligation.

what_it_covers: Processing of personal data by processors
Processing of personal data by persons acting under the authority of the controller or processor
Access to personal data

target_entities: Persons acting under the authority of the controller
Persons acting under the authority of the processor
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Entities established in the EU or processing data of EU data subjects

what_it_does_not_cover: Processing activities not involving personal data
Processing by controllers themselves (unless acting as processors for another controller)
Processing outside the scope of Union or Member State law

mandatory_obligations: Processors and persons under the authority of the controller or processor MUST process personal data only on instructions from the controller.
prohibited_actions: Processors and persons under the authority of the controller or processor MUST NOT process personal data except on instructions from the controller.
conditional_requirements: Processing may occur without controller's instructions ONLY if required by Union or Member State law.
documentation_requirements: Controllers should provide documented instructions to processors.

general_restrictions: Processing of personal data is restricted to controller's instructions unless otherwise required by law.
data_restrictions: No processing of personal data without controller's instructions except where legally required.
operational_restrictions: Processors and authorized persons are operationally limited to acting only on controller's instructions.
geographic_restrictions: Processing must comply with Union or Member State law if outside controller's instructions.

organizational_rights: Controllers have the right to determine and instruct how processors handle personal data.
how_to_exercise_rights: Controllers issue documented instructions to processors.

general_exceptions: Processing required by Union or Member State law is exempt from the instruction requirement.
conditional_exemptions: If Union or Member State law requires processing, processors may act without controller's instructions.
public_interest_exceptions: Processing required by law for public interest purposes may be exempt.

organizational_measures: Establish procedures to ensure processors act only on controller's instructions.
training_requirements: Train staff and authorized persons on the requirement to process data only on controller's instructions.
audit_requirements: Controllers should audit processors for compliance with instruction requirements.

enforcement.regulatory_authority: Supervisory Authorities in each EU Member State (e.g., Data Protection Authorities)

penalties.financial_penalties: Administrative fines up to â‚¬10,000,000 or up to 2% of the total worldwide annual turnover, whichever is higher, for non-compliance with controller instructions (per GDPR Article 83(4)).
penalties.administrative_penalties: Orders to cease processing, corrective orders, or other administrative measures.
penalties.reputational_consequences: Public disclosure of violations and potential reputational damage.

amendment_history: No substantive amendments since initial entry into force.

related_articles: Article 5 (Principles relating to processing of personal data)
complementary_regulations: National data protection laws of Member States

implementation_steps: Controllers must provide clear, documented instructions to processors.
Processors must ensure all staff and sub-processors are aware of and follow controller's instructions.
Establish internal controls to prevent unauthorized processing.
Document any processing required by law outside controller's instructions.
common_violations: Processors acting without or beyond controller's instructions.
Lack of documented instructions from controller.
Failure to restrict access to personal data to authorized persons only.
best_practices: Maintain written records of all instructions from controllers.
Regularly train staff on data processing limitations.
Conduct periodic audits of processor activities.
compliance_checklist: Are all processing activities based on documented controller instructions?
Are exceptions for legal requirements documented and justified?
Are staff and sub-processors trained on these requirements?
Is there an audit trail of instructions and processing activities?

key_definitions.processor: A natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which processes personal data on behalf of the controller.
key_definitions.personal data: Any information relating to an identified or identifiable natural person ('data subject').

cleaned_regulations.regulation_name: General Data Protection Regulation (EU) 2016/679, Article 30: Records of processing activities

description.brief_summary: GDPR Article 30 requires controllers and processors to maintain detailed records of processing activities, specifying the information to be included, the format, and the obligation to provide these records to supervisory authorities upon request, with certain exemptions for small organizations.
description.detailed_explanation: This article mandates that both data controllers and processors keep written (including electronic) records of their processing activities. Controllers must document details such as their identity, purposes of processing, categories of data subjects and data, recipients, transfers to third countries, retention periods, and security measures. Processors must record similar information relevant to their processing on behalf of controllers. The records must be made available to supervisory authorities upon request. There is an exemption for organizations with fewer than 250 employees unless their processing is risky, not occasional, or involves special categories of data or criminal data.
description.purpose: To ensure accountability and transparency in personal data processing, facilitate supervision by authorities, and support compliance with GDPR requirements.
description.legislative_intent: Lawmakers intended to create a clear, auditable trail of data processing activities to enhance data protection, enable effective oversight, and ensure organizations can demonstrate compliance.

what_it_covers: Maintenance of records of processing activities by controllers and processors
Content requirements for such records
Obligation to make records available to supervisory authorities
Documentation of cross-border data transfers and safeguards
Description of technical and organizational security measures

who_it_applies_to.size_thresholds: Enterprises or organizations employing 250 persons or more, or those processing data that is likely to result in a risk to the rights and freedoms of data subjects, is not occasional, or includes special categories of data or criminal data
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Organizations established in the EU or processing data of individuals in the EU

what_it_does_not_cover: Organizations employing fewer than 250 persons, unless their processing is likely to result in a risk to the rights and freedoms of data subjects, is not occasional, or includes special categories of data or criminal data

mandatory_obligations: Controllers must maintain a record of processing activities under their responsibility

Records must be made available to the supervisory authority on request

Where possible, the envisaged time limits for erasure of the different categories of data
Where possible, a general description of the technical and organisational security measures referred to in Article 32(1)

organizational_measures: Maintain records of processing activities
Appoint a data protection officer where applicable
security_measures: Document technical and organisational security measures
audit_requirements: Records must be available for supervisory authority inspection

enforcement.regulatory_authority: Supervisory Authority (Data Protection Authority) of the relevant EU Member State

penalties.financial_penalties: Administrative fines up to â‚¬10,000,000 or up to 2% of the total worldwide annual turnover of the preceding financial year, whichever is higher (per GDPR Article 83(4))
penalties.administrative_penalties: Orders to bring processing into compliance, temporary or definitive limitation including a ban on processing
penalties.reputational_consequences: Public disclosure of non-compliance, possible reputational damage

enforcement_mechanisms: Investigations following complaints or data breaches

key_definitions.controller: The natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which, alone or jointly with others, determines the purposes and means of the processing of personal data.
key_definitions.processor: A natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which processes personal data on behalf of the controller.
key_definitions.processing: Any operation or set of operations which is performed on personal data or on sets of personal data, whether or not by automated means.
key_definitions.data subject: An identified or identifiable natural person whose personal data are processed.
key_definitions.supervisory authority: An independent public authority which is established by a Member State pursuant to Article 51.
key_definitions.special categories of data: Personal data revealing racial or ethnic origin, political opinions, religious or philosophical beliefs, or trade union membership, and the processing of genetic data, biometric data for the purpose of uniquely identifying a natural person, data concerning health or data concerning a natural person's sex life or sexual orientation.

cleaned_regulations.regulation_name: General Data Protection Regulation (EU) 2016/679, Article 31 â€“ Cooperation with the supervisory authority

description.brief_summary: GDPR Article 31 requires controllers, processors, and their representatives to cooperate with the supervisory authority, upon request, in the performance of its tasks.
description.detailed_explanation: This article imposes a legal obligation on data controllers, processors, and, where applicable, their representatives to provide assistance and information to the supervisory authority when requested. The cooperation is required to enable the authority to carry out its regulatory and oversight functions, which may include investigations, audits, or other compliance activities. The obligation is broad and applies whenever the supervisory authority is performing its statutory tasks under the GDPR.
description.purpose: To ensure effective supervision and enforcement of data protection laws by requiring regulated entities to assist supervisory authorities.
description.legislative_intent: Lawmakers intended to empower supervisory authorities with the necessary cooperation from regulated entities to facilitate oversight, investigations, and enforcement actions, thereby strengthening data protection compliance.

what_it_covers: Cooperation with supervisory authority
Assistance in investigations
Provision of information upon request
Facilitation of supervisory tasks

who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Entities established in the EU or processing data of EU data subjects

what_it_does_not_cover: Entities not acting as controllers, processors, or their representatives
Cooperation outside the scope of supervisory authority's tasks

mandatory_obligations: Cooperate, on request, with the supervisory authority in the performance of its tasks
prohibited_actions: Refusing to cooperate with the supervisory authority upon request
conditional_requirements: Cooperation is required only upon request by the supervisory authority

general_restrictions: Cooperation is limited to the performance of the supervisory authority's tasks
geographic_restrictions: Requirement applies within the jurisdiction of the relevant supervisory authority

organizational_measures: Establish procedures for responding to supervisory authority requests
training_requirements: Train relevant staff on obligations to cooperate with supervisory authorities

enforcement.regulatory_authority: Supervisory authority (Data Protection Authority) of the relevant EU Member State

penalties.reputational_consequences: Public disclosure of non-compliance, potential reputational damage

key_definitions.controller: The natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which, alone or jointly with others, determines the purposes and means of the processing of personal data.

cleaned_regulations.regulation_name: General Data Protection Regulation (EU) 2016/679, Article 32 â€“ Security of processing

description.brief_summary: Article 32 of the GDPR requires controllers and processors to implement appropriate technical and organisational measures to ensure a level of security appropriate to the risk associated with personal data processing.
description.detailed_explanation: This article mandates that both data controllers and processors must assess the state of the art, implementation costs, and the nature, scope, context, and purposes of processing, as well as the risks to the rights and freedoms of natural persons. Based on this assessment, they must implement suitable technical and organisational measures, such as pseudonymisation, encryption, ensuring confidentiality, integrity, availability, and resilience of processing systems, timely restoration of data, and regular testing and evaluation of security measures. The article also allows adherence to approved codes of conduct or certification mechanisms as evidence of compliance and requires that persons acting under the authority of the controller or processor only process data on instructions, unless required by law.
description.purpose: To ensure that personal data is processed securely and to mitigate risks to the rights and freedoms of individuals.
description.legislative_intent: To protect individuals' personal data by obligating organizations to adopt security measures proportionate to the risks involved in data processing.

what_it_covers: Implementation of technical and organisational security measures
Risk assessment related to personal data processing
Pseudonymisation and encryption of personal data
Ensuring confidentiality, integrity, availability, and resilience of processing systems
Restoration of data availability and access after incidents
Regular testing, assessment, and evaluation of security measures
Use of codes of conduct and certification mechanisms for compliance demonstration
Instructions for persons acting under authority of controller or processor

target_entities: Natural persons acting under authority of controllers or processors
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Entities established in the EU or processing data of individuals in the EU

what_it_does_not_cover: Processing not involving personal data
Processing outside the material and territorial scope of the GDPR
Processing by individuals for purely personal or household activities

Ensure ongoing confidentiality, integrity, availability, and resilience of processing systems and services
Restore availability and access to personal data in a timely manner after a physical or technical incident
Regularly test, assess, and evaluate the effectiveness of security measures
Ensure persons acting under authority of controller or processor process data only on instructions, unless required by law

how_to_exercise_rights: Individuals may exercise their rights under the GDPR through complaints to supervisory authorities or data controllers

conditional_exemptions: Adherence to codes of conduct or certification mechanisms is optional but can be used to demonstrate compliance
public_interest_exceptions: Processing by persons under authority may occur without instruction if required by law

Encryption of personal data
Ensuring confidentiality, integrity, availability, and resilience of processing systems
Ability to restore data availability and access after incidents
organizational_measures: Regular testing, assessment, and evaluation of security measures
Policies ensuring processing only on instructions
Procedures for risk assessment
security_measures: Appropriate security measures based on risk assessment
training_requirements: Training for staff on security measures and processing instructions
audit_requirements: Regular assessment and evaluation of security measures
certification_requirements: Optional adherence to approved codes of conduct or certification mechanisms

enforcement.regulatory_authority: Supervisory authorities designated by each EU Member State (e.g., Data Protection Authorities)

penalties.financial_penalties: Administrative fines up to â‚¬10,000,000 or up to 2% of the total worldwide annual turnover, whichever is higher (per GDPR Article 83(4))
penalties.administrative_penalties: Orders to bring processing into compliance, temporary or definitive limitation including a ban on processing
penalties.reputational_consequences: Public disclosure of non-compliance, reputational damage

key_definitions.controller: The natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which, alone or jointly with others, determines the purposes and means of the processing of personal data.
key_definitions.processor: A natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which processes personal data on behalf of the controller.
key_definitions.personal data: Any information relating to an identified or identifiable natural person ('data subject').
key_definitions.pseudonymisation: The processing of personal data in such a manner that the data can no longer be attributed to a specific data subject without the use of additional information.
key_definitions.encryption: The process of converting information or data into a code, especially to prevent unauthorized access.

cleaned_regulations.regulation_name: General Data Protection Regulation (EU) 2016/679, Article 33: Notification of a personal data breach to the supervisory authority

description.brief_summary: GDPR Article 33 requires data controllers to notify the competent supervisory authority of personal data breaches without undue delay and, where feasible, within 72 hours of becoming aware, unless the breach is unlikely to result in a risk to the rights and freedoms of natural persons. Processors must notify controllers without undue delay. The notification must include specific information, and breaches must be documented.
description.detailed_explanation: This regulation mandates that, in the event of a personal data breach, the data controller must notify the competent supervisory authority as soon as possible and, where feasible, no later than 72 hours after becoming aware of the breach. If notification is delayed beyond 72 hours, reasons for the delay must be provided. The notification must include a description of the breach, contact details for further information, likely consequences, and measures taken or proposed to address the breach. If all information cannot be provided at once, it may be submitted in phases without undue further delay. Controllers are also required to document all personal data breaches, including facts, effects, and remedial actions, to enable supervisory authority verification.
description.purpose: To ensure timely regulatory oversight and mitigation of risks to individuals resulting from personal data breaches.
description.legislative_intent: To protect the rights and freedoms of natural persons by ensuring that supervisory authorities are promptly informed of data breaches, enabling oversight, guidance, and enforcement.

what_it_covers: Notification of personal data breaches to supervisory authorities
Timelines for breach notification
Content requirements for breach notifications
Phased notification process
Documentation of personal data breaches

who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Entities established in the EU or processing data of individuals in the EU

what_it_does_not_cover: Personal data breaches unlikely to result in a risk to the rights and freedoms of natural persons
Notification to data subjects (covered under Article 34)

mandatory_obligations: Controllers must notify the competent supervisory authority of a personal data breach without undue delay and, where feasible, not later than 72 hours after becoming aware of it.
If notification is not made within 72 hours, reasons for the delay must be provided.
Processors must notify the controller without undue delay after becoming aware of a personal data breach.

Notification must include: description of the breach (including categories and approximate number of data subjects and records affected), contact details of the data protection officer or other contact point, likely consequences, and measures taken or proposed to address the breach.
Controllers must document any personal data breaches, including facts, effects, and remedial actions.
prohibited_actions: Controllers must not fail to notify the supervisory authority of a breach that is likely to result in a risk to the rights and freedoms of natural persons.
conditional_requirements: Notification is not required if the personal data breach is unlikely to result in a risk to the rights and freedoms of natural persons.
If it is not possible to provide all required information at the same time, information may be provided in phases without undue further delay.
documentation_requirements: Controllers must document the facts relating to the personal data breach, its effects, and the remedial action taken.
Documentation must enable the supervisory authority to verify compliance with this Article.
reporting_requirements: Notification to the supervisory authority within 72 hours of becoming aware of a personal data breach (where feasible).
Notification must include: nature of the breach, categories and approximate number of data subjects and records, contact details, likely consequences, and measures taken/proposed.
If notification is delayed, reasons for delay must be reported.
timeline_requirements: Notification to supervisory authority: without undue delay and, where feasible, not later than 72 hours after becoming aware of the breach.
Processor to controller notification: without undue delay after becoming aware.
Phased notification: information may be provided in phases without undue further delay if not all information is available at once.

general_restrictions: Notification is not required if the breach is unlikely to result in a risk to the rights and freedoms of natural persons.
data_restrictions: Notification must include only the information specified (nature of breach, categories and numbers, contact details, consequences, measures taken).
operational_restrictions: Controllers must document all breaches for supervisory authority verification.
geographic_restrictions: Notification must be made to the supervisory authority competent in accordance with Article 55 (i.e., the authority relevant to the controller's main establishment or affected data subjects).

individual_rights: Indirect right: Individuals benefit from regulatory oversight and potential mitigation of risks to their rights and freedoms.
organizational_rights: Right to provide notification in phases if all information is not immediately available.
how_to_exercise_rights: Organizations exercise the right to phased notification by submitting available information and updating as more becomes available.

general_exceptions: No notification required if the personal data breach is unlikely to result in a risk to the rights and freedoms of natural persons.
conditional_exemptions: Phased notification allowed if all information cannot be provided at the same time.

technical_measures: Implement systems to detect and assess personal data breaches promptly.
organizational_measures: Establish internal procedures for breach detection, assessment, notification, and documentation.
Assign a data protection officer or contact point for breach-related communications.
security_measures: Take measures to address and mitigate the effects of personal data breaches.
training_requirements: Train staff to recognize and report personal data breaches promptly.
audit_requirements: Maintain documentation to enable supervisory authority verification of compliance.

enforcement.regulatory_authority: Supervisory authorities designated under GDPR Article 55 (e.g., national Data Protection Authorities in EU Member States)

penalties.financial_penalties: Fines up to â‚¬10,000,000 or up to 2% of the total worldwide annual turnover of the preceding financial year, whichever is higher, for non-compliance with breach notification obligations (see GDPR Article 83(4)).
penalties.administrative_penalties: Orders to comply, reprimands, and other corrective powers as per GDPR.
penalties.reputational_consequences: Potential public disclosure of non-compliance and breaches.

enforcement_mechanisms: Imposition of administrative fines and corrective measures

related_articles: GDPR Article 5 (Principles relating to processing of personal data)
GDPR Article 34 (Communication of a personal data breach to the data subject)
GDPR Article 55 (Competence of the supervisory authority)
complementary_regulations: National data protection laws implementing GDPR

implementation_steps: Establish breach detection and reporting mechanisms.
Train staff on breach identification and escalation.
Develop internal procedures for timely notification to supervisory authorities.
Prepare templates for breach notification including all required information.
Maintain a breach register documenting all incidents, effects, and remedial actions.
Assign a data protection officer or contact point for breach communications.
common_violations: Failure to notify within 72 hours.
Incomplete or missing information in notifications.
Failure to document breaches.
Failure of processors to notify controllers promptly.
best_practices: Automate breach detection and escalation processes.
Regularly review and test incident response plans.
Maintain up-to-date contact details for supervisory authorities.
Document all decisions and actions taken in response to breaches.
compliance_checklist: Is there a documented breach response procedure?
Are staff trained on breach reporting?
Is there a process to notify the supervisory authority within 72 hours?
Are all required notification elements included?
Is breach documentation maintained and accessible for audits?

key_definitions.personal data breach: A breach of security leading to the accidental or unlawful destruction, loss, alteration, unauthorized disclosure of, or access to, personal data transmitted, stored or otherwise processed.
key_definitions.controller: The natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which, alone or jointly with others, determines the purposes and means of the processing of personal data.
key_definitions.processor: A natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which processes personal data on behalf of the controller.
key_definitions.supervisory authority: An independent public authority established by a Member State pursuant to Article 51 of the GDPR.

cleaned_regulations.source_section: ## Notification of a personal data breach to the supervisory authority

cleaned_regulations.regulation_name: General Data Protection Regulation (EU) 2016/679, Article 34 â€“ Communication of a personal data breach to the data subject

industry_sectors: All sectors processing personal data within the EU or of EU data subjects

description.brief_summary: GDPR Article 34 requires data controllers to communicate personal data breaches to affected data subjects without undue delay when the breach is likely to result in a high risk to their rights and freedoms, with specific content and exceptions.
description.detailed_explanation: This article mandates that when a personal data breach is likely to result in a high risk to the rights and freedoms of natural persons, the controller must inform the affected data subjects without undue delay. The communication must be clear and plain, describing the nature of the breach and including at least the information and measures specified in Article 33(3)(b), (c), and (d). There are exceptions: if the controller has implemented effective technical and organizational measures (such as encryption), taken subsequent measures to eliminate the high risk, or if notification would involve disproportionate effort (in which case a public communication is required). The supervisory authority may require notification if not already done, or may decide that an exception applies.
description.purpose: To ensure that individuals are informed of personal data breaches that may significantly impact their rights and freedoms, enabling them to take appropriate precautions.
description.legislative_intent: Lawmakers intended to enhance transparency, accountability, and individual empowerment in the event of data breaches, while balancing notification obligations with practical and security considerations.

what_it_covers: Communication of personal data breaches to data subjects
Content and language of breach notifications
Conditions under which notification is required or exempted
Role of supervisory authorities in breach notification

who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Entities established in the EU or processing data of EU data subjects

what_it_does_not_cover: Processors (unless acting as controllers)
Data breaches not likely to result in high risk to rights and freedoms
Notification to supervisory authorities (covered by Article 33)

mandatory_obligations: Communicate the personal data breach to the data subject without undue delay if likely to result in a high risk to rights and freedoms
Describe in clear and plain language the nature of the personal data breach
Include at least the information and measures referred to in Article 33(3)(b), (c), and (d)
conditional_requirements: Notification is not required if appropriate technical and organisational protection measures (e.g., encryption) were applied to the affected data
Notification is not required if subsequent measures ensure the high risk is no longer likely to materialise
If notification would involve disproportionate effort, a public communication or similar measure must be used to inform data subjects in an equally effective manner
reporting_requirements: Notification to data subjects under specified conditions
Public communication if individual notification is disproportionate
timeline_requirements: Notification must be made without undue delay

general_restrictions: Notification is only required if the breach is likely to result in a high risk to the rights and freedoms of natural persons
data_restrictions: If data is rendered unintelligible to unauthorized persons (e.g., encrypted), notification may not be required
technical_restrictions: Appropriate technical and organisational protection measures must be in place to qualify for exemption
geographic_restrictions: Applies to controllers subject to the GDPR

individual_rights: Right to be informed of a personal data breach likely to result in high risk to rights and freedoms
organizational_rights: Right to be exempt from notification under specified conditions
how_to_exercise_rights: Data subjects are informed directly or via public communication if individual notification is disproportionate

general_exceptions: Notification not required if appropriate technical and organisational protection measures were applied to the affected data
conditional_exemptions: Notification not required if subsequent measures ensure high risk is no longer likely to materialise
Notification not required if it would involve disproportionate effort, provided a public communication or similar measure is used

technical_measures: Implement appropriate technical protection measures (e.g., encryption)
organizational_measures: Implement organisational protection measures to mitigate breach risks
security_measures: Apply measures that render data unintelligible to unauthorized persons

enforcement.regulatory_authority: Supervisory Authority (as defined in GDPR Article 51)

penalties.financial_penalties: Administrative fines up to â‚¬10,000,000 or up to 2% of the total worldwide annual turnover, whichever is higher, as per GDPR Article 83(4)
penalties.administrative_penalties: Orders to notify data subjects, corrective orders
penalties.reputational_consequences: Public disclosure of breaches, reputational damage

enforcement_mechanisms: Supervisory authority may require notification to data subjects
Supervisory authority may decide that exceptions apply

related_articles: GDPR Article 33 (Notification of a personal data breach to the supervisory authority)
GDPR Article 5 (Principles relating to processing of personal data)

implementation_steps: Assess whether a breach is likely to result in high risk to data subjects
Prepare clear and plain language notifications
Include required information as per Article 33(3)(b), (c), and (d)
Implement and document technical and organisational measures (e.g., encryption)
Establish procedures for public communication if individual notification is disproportionate
Maintain records of breaches and notifications
common_violations: Failure to notify data subjects without undue delay
Incomplete or unclear breach notifications
Not applying exceptions correctly
Lack of documentation of technical measures
best_practices: Maintain up-to-date incident response plans
Regularly review and test technical and organisational measures
Train staff on breach notification procedures
Document all decisions regarding notification and exceptions
compliance_checklist: Is the breach likely to result in high risk?
Has notification been made without undue delay?
Does the notification include all required information?
Are technical and organisational measures in place and documented?
Is there a process for public communication if needed?
Are records of breaches and notifications maintained?

key_definitions.personal data breach: A breach of security leading to the accidental or unlawful destruction, loss, alteration, unauthorised disclosure of, or access to, personal data transmitted, stored or otherwise processed.
key_definitions.controller: The natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which, alone or jointly with others, determines the purposes and means of the processing of personal data.
key_definitions.data subject: An identified or identifiable natural person whose personal data is processed.
key_definitions.supervisory authority: An independent public authority established by a Member State pursuant to Article 51.

cleaned_regulations.source_section: ## Communication of a personal data breach to the data subject

cleaned_regulations.regulation_name: General Data Protection Regulation (EU) 2016/679, Article 35 â€“ Data protection impact assessment

description.brief_summary: GDPR Article 35 requires controllers to conduct a Data Protection Impact Assessment (DPIA) when processing is likely to result in a high risk to individualsâ€™ rights and freedoms, especially when using new technologies or conducting certain types of processing.
description.detailed_explanation: This article mandates that before initiating processing operations likely to result in high risk to the rights and freedoms of natural persons, controllers must carry out a DPIA. The DPIA must assess the impact of the envisaged processing operations on the protection of personal data. The regulation specifies scenarios where a DPIA is mandatory, such as systematic and extensive evaluation based on automated processing (including profiling), large-scale processing of special categories of data or data relating to criminal convictions, and systematic monitoring of publicly accessible areas. The controller must seek advice from the DPO (if designated), and the assessment must include a description of processing, assessment of necessity and proportionality, risk assessment, and measures to address risks. Supervisory authorities are required to publish lists of processing operations that require or do not require a DPIA and must communicate these to the European Data Protection Board. There are exceptions where a DPIA is not required if already conducted as part of a general impact assessment under certain legal bases. Controllers must review DPIAs when risks change.
description.purpose: To ensure that risks to data subjectsâ€™ rights and freedoms are identified and mitigated before high-risk processing activities are undertaken.
description.legislative_intent: To embed privacy by design and by default into data processing activities, ensuring proactive risk management and accountability for data controllers.

what_it_covers: Assessment of high-risk personal data processing operations
Processing using new technologies
Systematic and extensive evaluation of personal aspects based on automated processing (including profiling)
Large-scale processing of special categories of data (Article 9(1))
Large-scale processing of data relating to criminal convictions and offences (Article 10)
Systematic monitoring of publicly accessible areas on a large scale
Consultation with Data Protection Officer (where designated)
Consultation with data subjects or their representatives (where appropriate)
Review of DPIA when risk changes

who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Entities established in the EU or processing data of individuals in the EU

what_it_does_not_cover: Processing operations already covered by a general impact assessment under Union or Member State law, unless Member States require otherwise
Processing operations not likely to result in high risk to rights and freedoms

mandatory_obligations: Carry out a data protection impact assessment prior to processing likely to result in high risk to rights and freedoms of natural persons
Seek advice of the data protection officer, where designated, when carrying out a DPIA

Include at least the following in the DPIA: systematic description of processing and purposes, assessment of necessity and proportionality, assessment of risks to data subjects, measures to address risks
Review DPIA when there is a change of the risk represented by processing operations
Supervisory authority must establish and publish lists of processing operations requiring a DPIA and communicate these to the Board
prohibited_actions: Do not process high-risk personal data without first conducting a DPIA
conditional_requirements: A single DPIA may address a set of similar processing operations that present similar high risks

DPIA is particularly required for: systematic and extensive evaluation based on automated processing (including profiling) with legal or similarly significant effects; large-scale processing of special categories of data or data relating to criminal convictions; systematic monitoring of publicly accessible areas on a large scale
Supervisory authority may establish and publish lists of processing operations for which no DPIA is required
Prior to adoption of such lists, the consistency mechanism (Article 63) must be applied if processing involves multiple Member States or may affect free movement of personal data
documentation_requirements: Maintain records of DPIAs conducted
Include required elements in the DPIA documentation
reporting_requirements: Communicate lists of processing operations requiring or not requiring DPIA to the European Data Protection Board
timeline_requirements: DPIA must be carried out prior to the processing
Review DPIA at least when there is a change of the risk

general_restrictions: Processing likely to result in high risk must not commence before DPIA is completed
data_restrictions: Special categories of data and data relating to criminal convictions require particular attention
operational_restrictions: Systematic monitoring of publicly accessible areas on a large scale is subject to DPIA
technical_restrictions: Implement measures to address risks, including safeguards, security measures, and mechanisms to ensure protection of personal data
geographic_restrictions: Consistency mechanism applies if processing affects multiple Member States or free movement of data within the Union

individual_rights: Right to have risks to rights and freedoms assessed and mitigated before high-risk processing
Right to be consulted (where appropriate) on intended processing
organizational_rights: Right to rely on approved codes of conduct in DPIA assessment
how_to_exercise_rights: Data subjects or their representatives may be consulted by the controller on intended processing

general_exceptions: Paragraphs 1 to 7 do not apply if processing is pursuant to point (c) or (e) of Article 6(1), is regulated by Union or Member State law, and a DPIA has already been carried out as part of a general impact assessment, unless Member States require otherwise
conditional_exemptions: Supervisory authority may establish lists of processing operations for which no DPIA is required
public_interest_exceptions: Exception applies where processing is regulated by law for public interest purposes and DPIA has already been conducted

technical_measures: Implement safeguards, security measures, and mechanisms to ensure protection of personal data
organizational_measures: Seek advice from DPO (where designated)
Consult data subjects or their representatives where appropriate
Follow approved codes of conduct where applicable
security_measures: Measures to address risks identified in DPIA
audit_requirements: Review DPIA when risk changes

enforcement.regulatory_authority: Supervisory Authority (Data Protection Authority) in each Member State

penalties.financial_penalties: Administrative fines up to â‚¬10,000,000 or up to 2% of the total worldwide annual turnover, whichever is higher, for non-compliance with DPIA requirements (see GDPR Article 83(4))
penalties.administrative_penalties: Orders to cease processing, corrective orders, reprimands
penalties.reputational_consequences: Public disclosure of non-compliance, potential loss of trust

complementary_regulations: National data protection laws of Member States

implementation_steps: Identify processing operations likely to result in high risk
Determine if new technologies or special categories of data are involved
Consult the DPO (if designated)
Conduct and document a DPIA before processing
Include all required elements in the DPIA
Consult data subjects or representatives where appropriate
Implement measures to address identified risks
Review and update DPIA when risks change
Monitor supervisory authority lists for DPIA requirements
common_violations: Failure to conduct a DPIA before high-risk processing
Inadequate documentation of DPIA
Not consulting the DPO
Not including all required elements in the DPIA
Failure to review DPIA when risks change
best_practices: Integrate DPIA into project management processes
Engage DPO early in the process
Consult data subjects proactively
Use approved codes of conduct
Regularly review and update DPIAs
compliance_checklist: Is the processing likely to result in high risk?
Is a DPIA required under supervisory authority lists?
Has the DPO been consulted?
Does the DPIA include all required elements?
Have data subjects been consulted where appropriate?
Are measures in place to address risks?
Is the DPIA reviewed when risks change?

key_definitions.Data Protection Impact Assessment (DPIA): An assessment required under GDPR to identify and mitigate risks to the rights and freedoms of natural persons resulting from high-risk personal data processing operations.
key_definitions.Controller: The natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which, alone or jointly with others, determines the purposes and means of the processing of personal data.
key_definitions.Data Protection Officer (DPO): A person designated by the controller or processor to oversee data protection strategy and compliance.
key_definitions.Supervisory Authority: An independent public authority established by a Member State responsible for monitoring the application of the GDPR.
key_definitions.Special categories of data: Personal data revealing racial or ethnic origin, political opinions, religious or philosophical beliefs, or trade union membership, and the processing of genetic data, biometric data for the purpose of uniquely identifying a natural person, data concerning health or data concerning a natural person's sex life or sexual orientation.

cleaned_regulations.regulation_name: General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) Article 36 â€“ Prior consultation

description.brief_summary: GDPR Article 36 requires data controllers to consult the supervisory authority before processing personal data if a DPIA indicates high risk that cannot be mitigated. It sets out the process, documentation, supervisory authority response times, and special rules for legislative measures and public interest processing.
description.detailed_explanation: This article mandates that, where a data protection impact assessment (DPIA) under Article 35 shows that intended processing would result in a high risk to data subjects in the absence of mitigating measures, the controller must consult the supervisory authority before proceeding. The supervisory authority must respond in writing within eight weeks (extendable by six weeks for complex cases), may use its powers under Article 58, and can suspend the period pending further information. Controllers must provide detailed information, including roles, purposes, safeguards, DPO contact, the DPIA, and any other requested information. Member States must consult the supervisory authority when preparing legislative or regulatory measures relating to processing. National law may require prior consultation or authorization for public interest processing, including social protection and public health.
description.purpose: To ensure that high-risk personal data processing is subject to regulatory oversight and that risks to data subjects are properly assessed and mitigated before processing begins.
description.legislative_intent: To protect the rights and freedoms of data subjects by requiring regulatory scrutiny of high-risk processing activities and ensuring that controllers take appropriate measures to mitigate risks.

what_it_covers: Prior consultation with supervisory authority for high-risk processing
Processing activities identified as high risk by a DPIA under Article 35
Documentation and information to be provided to supervisory authority
Supervisory authority's review and advice process
Member State legislative and regulatory measures relating to processing
National law requirements for prior consultation/authorization for public interest processing

target_entities: Member State authorities preparing legislative/regulatory measures
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Entities established or operating in the EU/EEA or processing data of EU/EEA residents

what_it_does_not_cover: Processing not identified as high risk by a DPIA
Processing where risks have been adequately mitigated
Processing outside the scope of the GDPR

mandatory_obligations: Controllers MUST consult the supervisory authority prior to processing where a DPIA indicates high risk in the absence of mitigating measures.

Controllers MUST provide the supervisory authority with: (a) respective responsibilities of controllers/processors, (b) purposes and means of processing, (c) measures and safeguards for data subjects, (d) DPO contact details (if applicable), (e) the DPIA, (f) any other information requested.
Supervisory authority MUST provide written advice within up to eight weeks of receiving the consultation request.
Supervisory authority MUST inform the controller/processor of any extension within one month, with reasons.
Member States MUST consult the supervisory authority when preparing legislative or regulatory measures relating to processing.
prohibited_actions: Controllers MUST NOT proceed with high-risk processing without prior consultation if risks are not mitigated.
Supervisory authority MUST NOT delay response beyond the allowed period without informing the controller/processor.
conditional_requirements: If the supervisory authority considers the intended processing would infringe the Regulation, especially due to insufficient risk mitigation, it may provide advice and use its powers under Article 58.
The eight-week period for supervisory authority response MAY be extended by six weeks for complex processing.
Periods MAY be suspended until requested information is provided.
Member State law MAY require prior consultation or authorization for public interest processing.
documentation_requirements: DPIA under Article 35
Details of responsibilities of controllers/processors
Purposes and means of processing
Measures and safeguards for data subjects
DPO contact details (if applicable)
Any other information requested by the supervisory authority
reporting_requirements: Controllers MUST submit required information to the supervisory authority as part of the consultation.
Supervisory authority MUST provide written advice to the controller and, where applicable, the processor.
timeline_requirements: Supervisory authority response: up to eight weeks from receipt of request.
Possible extension: additional six weeks for complex cases.
Notification of extension: within one month of receipt of request, with reasons.
Periods may be suspended pending provision of requested information.

general_restrictions: Processing with high risk identified by DPIA cannot proceed without prior consultation if risks are not mitigated.
data_restrictions: Processing must not infringe the Regulation, particularly where risks are insufficiently identified or mitigated.
operational_restrictions: Controllers must not initiate high-risk processing before completing consultation if required.
geographic_restrictions: Applies to processing activities within the EU/EEA or affecting EU/EEA data subjects.

individual_rights: Indirect protection of data subjects' rights and freedoms through regulatory oversight of high-risk processing.
organizational_rights: Controllers have the right to receive written advice from the supervisory authority.
Controllers/processors have the right to be informed of any extension and the reasons for delay.
how_to_exercise_rights: Controllers initiate consultation by submitting required information to the supervisory authority.

general_exceptions: Processing not identified as high risk by a DPIA is not subject to prior consultation.
conditional_exemptions: If risks are adequately mitigated, prior consultation is not required.
public_interest_exceptions: Member State law may require prior consultation or authorization for processing in the public interest, including social protection and public health.

technical_measures: Implementation of measures and safeguards to mitigate risks to data subjects.
organizational_measures: Assignment of responsibilities among controllers, joint controllers, and processors.
Appointment of a Data Protection Officer where applicable.
security_measures: Appropriate safeguards to protect data subjects' rights and freedoms.
audit_requirements: Conducting a DPIA under Article 35 for high-risk processing.

enforcement.regulatory_authority: Supervisory authority (Data Protection Authority) of the relevant Member State

penalties.financial_penalties: Fines as per GDPR Article 83, up to â‚¬10 million or 2% of global annual turnover, whichever is higher, for non-compliance.
penalties.administrative_penalties: Orders to suspend or prohibit processing, corrective orders.
penalties.reputational_consequences: Public disclosure of enforcement actions.

enforcement_mechanisms: Supervisory authority review of consultation submissions.
Use of powers under Article 58 (including investigations, orders, and sanctions).

related_articles: GDPR Article 58 (Powers of the supervisory authority)
complementary_regulations: National data protection laws implementing or supplementing GDPR

implementation_steps: Conduct a DPIA for any high-risk processing.
If high risk remains after mitigation, prepare and submit required documentation to the supervisory authority.
Await written advice and comply with any recommendations or orders.
Document all steps and communications for audit purposes.
Consult the supervisory authority during legislative or regulatory drafting if required.
common_violations: Failing to consult the supervisory authority before high-risk processing.
Insufficient documentation provided during consultation.
Proceeding with processing before receiving supervisory authority advice.
Ignoring supervisory authority recommendations or orders.
best_practices: Integrate DPIA and consultation processes into project planning.
Maintain clear records of risk assessments and mitigation measures.
Engage with the supervisory authority early for complex or novel processing.
Ensure all required information is complete and accurate.
compliance_checklist: Has a DPIA been conducted for the processing?
Does the DPIA indicate high risk that cannot be mitigated?
Has the supervisory authority been consulted before processing?
Have all required documents and information been submitted?
Has written advice from the supervisory authority been received and followed?
Are timelines and extensions documented?

key_definitions.controller: The natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which, alone or jointly with others, determines the purposes and means of the processing of personal data.
key_definitions.supervisory authority: An independent public authority established by a Member State pursuant to Article 51 of the GDPR.
key_definitions.data protection impact assessment (DPIA): A process designed to describe the processing, assess its necessity and proportionality, and help manage the risks to the rights and freedoms of natural persons resulting from the processing of personal data.
key_definitions.processing: Any operation or set of operations which is performed on personal data or on sets of personal data, whether or not by automated means.

cleaned_regulations.regulation_name: General Data Protection Regulation (EU) 2016/679, Article 37 - Designation of the data protection officer

industry_sectors: All sectors processing personal data, including public authorities, private companies, non-profits, healthcare, finance, technology, education, government

description.brief_summary: Article 37 of the GDPR requires controllers and processors to designate a Data Protection Officer (DPO) in specific circumstances, outlines the conditions for appointment, and sets requirements for accessibility, qualifications, and publication of contact details.
description.detailed_explanation: This regulation mandates that a DPO must be appointed by controllers and processors when processing is carried out by a public authority or body (except courts acting in their judicial capacity), when core activities require regular and systematic monitoring of data subjects on a large scale, or when core activities involve large-scale processing of special categories of data or data relating to criminal convictions and offences. It allows for a single DPO for a group of undertakings or for several public authorities, provided accessibility is ensured. The DPO must be designated based on professional qualities and expert knowledge of data protection law and practices. The DPO may be an employee or engaged via a service contract. Contact details must be published and communicated to the supervisory authority. Voluntary appointment is allowed in other cases, and the DPO may act for associations or representative bodies.
description.purpose: To ensure that organizations processing personal data have a qualified individual responsible for overseeing data protection compliance and serving as a point of contact for data subjects and supervisory authorities.
description.legislative_intent: To strengthen data protection governance, accountability, and oversight within organizations, and to facilitate compliance with data protection obligations under the GDPR.

what_it_covers: Designation of a Data Protection Officer (DPO)
Conditions under which a DPO must be appointed
Qualifications and professional qualities required for DPOs
Possibility of appointing a single DPO for groups of undertakings or public authorities
Voluntary appointment of DPOs
Publication and communication of DPO contact details

who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Entities established or operating in the EU/EEA, or processing personal data of individuals in the EU/EEA

what_it_does_not_cover: Courts acting in their judicial capacity
Entities not meeting the specified criteria for mandatory DPO appointment

mandatory_obligations: Designate a Data Protection Officer if processing is carried out by a public authority or body (except courts acting in their judicial capacity)
Designate a DPO if core activities require regular and systematic monitoring of data subjects on a large scale
Designate a DPO if core activities involve large-scale processing of special categories of data (Article 9) or data relating to criminal convictions and offences (Article 10)
Ensure the DPO is easily accessible from each establishment if a single DPO is appointed for a group of undertakings
Publish the contact details of the DPO
Communicate the DPO's contact details to the supervisory authority
Designate the DPO on the basis of professional qualities and expert knowledge of data protection law and practices
conditional_requirements: A single DPO may be designated for several public authorities or bodies, taking account of their organisational structure and size
In cases other than those referred to in paragraph 1, a DPO may or, where required by Union or Member State law, shall be designated
The DPO may act for associations and other bodies representing controllers or processors
documentation_requirements: Maintain records of DPO designation and contact details
reporting_requirements: Communicate DPO contact details to the supervisory authority

general_restrictions: Courts acting in their judicial capacity are excluded from the requirement to appoint a DPO
data_restrictions: Requirement applies specifically to large-scale processing of special categories of data and data relating to criminal convictions and offences
operational_restrictions: DPO must be easily accessible from each establishment if appointed for a group

organizational_rights: Right to appoint a single DPO for a group of undertakings or several public authorities
Right to voluntarily appoint a DPO in cases not covered by mandatory requirements
how_to_exercise_rights: Organizations may designate a DPO according to the criteria set out in this Article

Ensure publication and communication of DPO contact details

penalties.administrative_penalties: Orders to comply, reprimands, and other corrective powers under GDPR
penalties.reputational_consequences: Public disclosure of non-compliance by supervisory authorities
