what_it_does_not_cover: Tasks not related to the protection of personal data
Supervisory authorities outside the EU/EEA
Non-personal data processing

mandatory_obligations: Monitor and enforce the application of the GDPR
Promote public awareness and understanding of data protection, with specific attention to children
Advise national parliaments, governments, and institutions on legislative and administrative measures
Promote awareness among controllers and processors of their GDPR obligations
Provide information to data subjects on exercising their rights
Handle and investigate complaints from data subjects or representative bodies
Inform complainants of investigation progress and outcomes within a reasonable period
Cooperate and provide mutual assistance to other supervisory authorities
Conduct investigations on GDPR application
Monitor relevant technological and commercial developments
Adopt standard contractual clauses (per Article 28(8) and Article 46(2)(d))
Establish and maintain DPIA lists (per Article 35(4))
Advise on high-risk processing operations (per Article 36(2))
Encourage and approve codes of conduct (per Article 40(1) and 40(5))
Encourage and approve certification mechanisms and criteria (per Article 42(1) and 42(5))
Carry out periodic review of certifications (per Article 42(7))
Draft and publish accreditation criteria for monitoring and certification bodies (per Articles 41 and 43)
Conduct accreditation of monitoring and certification bodies (per Articles 41 and 43)
Authorize contractual clauses (per Article 46(3))
Approve binding corporate rules (per Article 47)
Contribute to the activities of the European Data Protection Board
Keep internal records of infringements and measures taken (per Article 58(2))
Fulfil any other tasks related to personal data protection
Facilitate submission of complaints, including electronic forms
Provide free services to data subjects and, where applicable, data protection officers
prohibited_actions: Charging data subjects or data protection officers for the performance of supervisory authority tasks, except where requests are manifestly unfounded or excessive
Refusing to act on requests without demonstrating that they are manifestly unfounded or excessive
conditional_requirements: Charging a reasonable fee or refusing to act on requests only if requests are manifestly unfounded or excessive, particularly if repetitive
Burden of proof for manifestly unfounded or excessive requests lies with the supervisory authority
documentation_requirements: Keep internal records of infringements of the GDPR and measures taken (per Article 58(2))
Draft and publish criteria for accreditation of monitoring and certification bodies
reporting_requirements: Inform complainants of the progress and outcome of investigations within a reasonable period
timeline_requirements: Inform complainants of investigation progress and outcome within a reasonable period

general_restrictions: Supervisory authorities may only charge fees or refuse requests if they are manifestly unfounded or excessive
Supervisory authorities must demonstrate the manifestly unfounded or excessive character of requests
data_restrictions: Focus on personal data and processing activities
operational_restrictions: Complaint submission must not be limited to electronic means; other means must also be available
technical_restrictions: Complaint submission forms must be available electronically, but not exclusively
geographic_restrictions: Supervisory authority tasks are limited to their own territory

individual_rights: Right to lodge complaints with supervisory authorities
Right to receive information on the exercise of data protection rights
Right to have complaints investigated and be informed of progress and outcome
Right to free-of-charge services from supervisory authorities
organizational_rights: Bodies, organisations, or associations may lodge complaints on behalf of data subjects (per Article 80)
how_to_exercise_rights: Submission of complaints via forms (including electronic forms) or other means of communication
Requesting information from supervisory authorities regarding data protection rights

general_exceptions: Supervisory authorities may charge a reasonable fee or refuse to act on requests if they are manifestly unfounded or excessive
conditional_exemptions: Fee charging or refusal to act applies only if requests are manifestly unfounded or excessive, particularly if repetitive

technical_measures: Provision of electronic complaint submission forms
organizational_measures: Procedures for handling complaints
Procedures for informing complainants
Internal record-keeping of infringements and measures
training_requirements: Staff training on complaint handling and public awareness
audit_requirements: Periodic review of certifications issued
certification_requirements: Approval and periodic review of data protection certification mechanisms

enforcement.regulatory_authority: Supervisory authorities designated by each EU Member State

penalties.financial_penalties: Not specified in this section; see GDPR Article 83 for details on fines
penalties.administrative_penalties: Supervisory authorities may take measures in accordance with Article 58(2)
penalties.reputational_consequences: Potential public disclosure of infringements and enforcement actions

enforcement_mechanisms: Cooperation and mutual assistance with other supervisory authorities
Adoption of enforcement measures under Article 58(2)

implementation_steps: Establish procedures for monitoring and enforcement
Develop and distribute public awareness materials
Set up advisory processes for national bodies
Create and maintain complaint handling systems
Implement cooperation mechanisms with other supervisory authorities
Develop and maintain electronic and other complaint submission forms
Draft and publish accreditation criteria
Establish internal record-keeping systems
Train staff on GDPR tasks and complaint handling
common_violations: Failure to handle complaints in a timely manner
Charging data subjects for services without justification
Inadequate public awareness activities
Lack of cooperation with other supervisory authorities
Failure to keep required records
best_practices: Provide multiple channels for complaint submission
Regularly review and update public awareness campaigns
Maintain transparent communication with complainants
Document all enforcement actions and decisions
Engage in regular cooperation with other supervisory authorities
compliance_checklist: Are all mandatory tasks being performed?
Are complaint submission forms available electronically and by other means?
Are services provided free of charge to data subjects?
Are records of infringements and measures maintained?
Are public awareness activities conducted, especially for children?
Is there a process for handling manifestly unfounded or excessive requests?

key_definitions.supervisory authority: An independent public authority established by a Member State pursuant to Article 51 of the GDPR.
key_definitions.data subject: An identified or identifiable natural person whose personal data is processed.
key_definitions.controller: The natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which, alone or jointly with others, determines the purposes and means of the processing of personal data.
key_definitions.processor: A natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which processes personal data on behalf of the controller.
key_definitions.complaint: A formal expression of dissatisfaction or concern regarding the processing of personal data, lodged by a data subject or representative body.

cleaned_regulations.regulation_name: General Data Protection Regulation (EU) 2016/679, Article 58

industry_sectors: All sectors processing personal data within the EU

description.brief_summary: Article 58 of the GDPR enumerates the powers granted to supervisory authorities, including investigative, corrective, authorisation, and advisory powers, as well as the procedural safeguards and enforcement mechanisms for ensuring compliance with the Regulation.
description.detailed_explanation: This article provides a comprehensive list of powers that supervisory authorities possess to monitor and enforce compliance with the GDPR. These include the ability to investigate controllers and processors, issue warnings and reprimands, order compliance and rectification, impose fines, suspend data flows, and approve or withdraw certifications. It also mandates procedural safeguards, allows Member States to grant additional powers, and requires mechanisms for judicial remedy and due process.
description.purpose: To empower supervisory authorities with the necessary tools to ensure effective enforcement of data protection laws and safeguard the rights of data subjects.
description.legislative_intent: To establish a harmonized framework for supervisory authorities across the EU, ensuring they have sufficient powers to investigate, correct, authorise, and advise on data protection matters, and to provide effective remedies and enforcement.

what_it_covers: Investigative powers of supervisory authorities
Corrective powers of supervisory authorities
Authorisation and advisory powers of supervisory authorities
Procedural safeguards for the exercise of powers
Legal proceedings and enforcement mechanisms
Possibility for Member States to grant additional powers

who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Entities established or operating in the EU, or processing data of EU data subjects

what_it_does_not_cover: Specific technical standards for investigations
Detailed procedures for judicial remedies
Explicit size-based exemptions

mandatory_obligations: Controllers and processors must provide any information required by supervisory authorities for the performance of their tasks.
Controllers and processors must allow supervisory authorities to carry out investigations, including data protection audits.
Controllers and processors must provide access to all personal data and information necessary for supervisory authoritiesâ€™ tasks.
Controllers and processors must allow access to their premises and data processing equipment, in accordance with procedural law.
Controllers and processors must comply with orders to bring processing operations into compliance within specified manner and period.
Controllers must communicate personal data breaches to data subjects when ordered.
Controllers and processors must comply with orders for rectification, erasure, or restriction of processing.
Controllers and processors must comply with orders to suspend data flows to third countries or international organisations.
prohibited_actions: Controllers and processors must not refuse access to information or premises when lawfully requested by supervisory authorities.
Controllers and processors must not continue non-compliant processing after being ordered to cease or limit processing.
conditional_requirements: Supervisory authorities may order certification bodies not to issue certification if requirements are not met.
Supervisory authorities may withdraw certifications if requirements are no longer met.
Supervisory authorities may impose administrative fines in addition to, or instead of, other corrective measures, depending on the circumstances.
documentation_requirements: Controllers and processors must maintain records sufficient to demonstrate compliance with supervisory authority requests and orders.
reporting_requirements: Controllers must notify data subjects of personal data breaches when ordered by supervisory authorities.
Supervisory authorities must notify controllers or processors of alleged infringements.
timeline_requirements: Supervisory authorities may specify periods within which controllers or processors must comply with orders.

general_restrictions: Exercise of powers must be subject to appropriate safeguards, including effective judicial remedy and due process, as set out in Union and Member State law.
data_restrictions: Access to personal data and information by supervisory authorities must be necessary for the performance of their tasks.
operational_restrictions: Access to premises and data processing equipment must be in accordance with Union or Member State procedural law.
geographic_restrictions: Supervisory authority powers must not impair the effective operation of Chapter VII of the GDPR.

individual_rights: Right to effective judicial remedy and due process in relation to the exercise of supervisory authority powers.
organizational_rights: Right to be notified of alleged infringements.
Right to judicial remedy and due process against supervisory authority actions.
how_to_exercise_rights: By seeking judicial remedy as set out in Union and Member State law.

conditional_exemptions: Member States may provide by law that supervisory authorities have additional powers beyond those listed, provided these do not impair the effective operation of Chapter VII.
public_interest_exceptions: Supervisory authorities may bring infringements to the attention of judicial authorities and commence or engage in legal proceedings to enforce the Regulation.

organizational_measures: Establish procedures to respond to supervisory authority requests and orders.
Implement processes for data breach notification to data subjects.
audit_requirements: Be prepared for data protection audits by supervisory authorities.
certification_requirements: Comply with requirements for certification and be subject to withdrawal or denial of certification if requirements are not met.

enforcement.regulatory_authority: Supervisory authorities designated under the GDPR in each Member State.

penalties.financial_penalties: Administrative fines may be imposed pursuant to Article 83, in addition to or instead of other corrective measures. The amount and conditions are specified in Article 83.
penalties.administrative_penalties: Warnings, reprimands, orders to comply, orders to communicate breaches, orders to rectify or erase data, suspension of data flows, withdrawal or denial of certification.
penalties.reputational_consequences: Public disclosure of enforcement actions may occur, depending on Member State law and the nature of the infringement.

enforcement_mechanisms: Investigations and audits by supervisory authorities.
Issuance of warnings, reprimands, and orders.
Legal proceedings initiated by supervisory authorities.

implementation_steps: Establish internal procedures for responding to supervisory authority requests.
Maintain up-to-date records of processing activities.
Prepare for potential audits and investigations.
Ensure mechanisms are in place for prompt notification of data breaches to data subjects.
Review and update certification status as required.
common_violations: Failure to provide requested information to supervisory authorities.
Non-compliance with orders to rectify or erase data.
Failure to notify data subjects of breaches when ordered.
Obstructing supervisory authority access to premises or data.
best_practices: Maintain open communication with supervisory authorities.
Document all interactions and compliance efforts.
Regularly review compliance with GDPR requirements.
Train staff on responding to supervisory authority requests.
compliance_checklist: Are procedures in place for responding to supervisory authority requests?
Is there a process for handling data protection audits?
Are mechanisms established for breach notification to data subjects?
Is certification status monitored and updated as required?
Are records maintained to demonstrate compliance?

key_definitions.supervisory authority: An independent public authority established by a Member State pursuant to Article 51 of the GDPR, responsible for monitoring the application of the Regulation.
key_definitions.controller: The natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which, alone or jointly with others, determines the purposes and means of the processing of personal data.
key_definitions.processor: A natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which processes personal data on behalf of the controller.
key_definitions.certification body: A body accredited pursuant to Article 43 of the GDPR to issue certifications regarding data protection compliance.

cleaned_regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 of the European Parliament and of the Council (General Data Protection Regulation) - Article 59: Activity reports

description.brief_summary: Supervisory authorities are required to prepare and publish annual activity reports, including information on infringements and measures taken, and distribute these reports to designated national and EU bodies.
description.detailed_explanation: Article 59 of the GDPR requires each supervisory authority to draw up an annual report on its activities. The report may include a list of types of infringement notified and types of measures taken in accordance with Article 58(2) (which details the powers of supervisory authorities). The reports must be transmitted to the national parliament, the government, and other authorities as designated by Member State law. Additionally, the reports must be made available to the public, the European Commission, and the European Data Protection Board (EDPB). This ensures transparency and accountability of supervisory authorities in the enforcement of data protection laws.
description.purpose: To ensure transparency, accountability, and oversight of supervisory authorities' activities in enforcing data protection laws.
description.legislative_intent: Lawmakers intended to provide mechanisms for public and institutional oversight of supervisory authorities, ensuring that their activities are transparent and subject to review by both national and EU-level bodies.

what_it_covers: Preparation of annual activity reports by supervisory authorities
Inclusion of types of infringement notified
Inclusion of types of measures taken (per Article 58(2))
Transmission of reports to national parliament, government, and other designated authorities
Publication of reports to the public, the European Commission, and the Board

who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Located within EU Member States

what_it_does_not_cover: Reporting obligations for private companies or individuals
Specific content requirements beyond those mentioned
Reporting frequency other than annual

mandatory_obligations: Each supervisory authority SHALL draw up an annual report on its activities
Reports SHALL be transmitted to the national parliament, the government, and other authorities as designated by Member State law
Reports SHALL be made available to the public, to the Commission, and to the Board
conditional_requirements: Reports MAY include a list of types of infringement notified and types of measures taken in accordance with Article 58(2)
documentation_requirements: Annual activity report
List of types of infringement notified (optional)
List of types of measures taken (optional)
reporting_requirements: Transmit annual report to national parliament
Transmit annual report to government
Transmit annual report to other authorities as designated by Member State law
Make annual report available to the public
Make annual report available to the European Commission
Make annual report available to the European Data Protection Board
timeline_requirements: Annual reporting (once per year)

general_restrictions: Reports must be transmitted only to authorities as designated by Member State law
operational_restrictions: Supervisory authorities are limited to reporting as specified; no operational restrictions on other activities are mentioned
geographic_restrictions: Applies only within EU Member States

organizational_rights: Right of the public, the Commission, and the Board to access annual reports
how_to_exercise_rights: Reports are made available to the public; access procedures depend on publication method

organizational_measures: Establish procedures for preparing annual reports
Establish procedures for transmitting and publishing reports

enforcement.regulatory_authority: National supervisory authorities; oversight by national parliament, government, and the European Data Protection Board

penalties.reputational_consequences: Failure to publish or transmit reports may result in reputational damage and loss of public trust

enforcement_mechanisms: Oversight by national parliament and government
Oversight by the European Data Protection Board

implementation_steps: Establish internal processes for annual activity reporting
Collect and document types of infringements and measures taken
Prepare and approve the annual report
Transmit the report to required national authorities
Publish the report for public access and notify the Commission and Board
common_violations: Failure to prepare an annual report
Failure to include required information
Failure to transmit or publish the report as required
best_practices: Maintain detailed records throughout the year to facilitate reporting
Ensure timely preparation and dissemination of the report
Engage with designated authorities to confirm transmission requirements
compliance_checklist: Annual report prepared
Report includes types of infringements and measures (if applicable)
Report transmitted to national parliament
Report transmitted to government
Report transmitted to other designated authorities
Report published for public, Commission, and Board

key_definitions.supervisory authority: An independent public authority established by a Member State pursuant to Article 51 of the GDPR.
key_definitions.Board: The European Data Protection Board (EDPB), established by Article 68 of the GDPR.

cleaned_regulations.regulation_name: General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) Article 60 â€“ Cooperation between the lead supervisory authority and the other supervisory authorities concerned

industry_sectors: All sectors processing personal data within the EU/EEA

description.brief_summary: Article 60 of the GDPR establishes the framework for cooperation and consistency among supervisory authorities in cases of cross-border data processing, detailing the roles, procedures, and obligations of the lead supervisory authority and other authorities concerned.
description.detailed_explanation: This article mandates that the lead supervisory authority (LSA) must cooperate with other supervisory authorities concerned (CSAs) to reach consensus on cross-border data protection matters. It sets out the process for information exchange, mutual assistance, joint operations, and the handling of draft decisions, including the process for objections and the use of the consistency mechanism. It also specifies notification requirements for decisions, complaint handling procedures, urgent action protocols, and the use of standardized electronic formats for communication.
description.purpose: To ensure effective, consistent, and coordinated enforcement of data protection rules across the EU/EEA in cases involving cross-border processing of personal data.
description.legislative_intent: To prevent fragmented enforcement, ensure data subjects' rights are uniformly protected, and provide clear procedures for resolving disputes between supervisory authorities.

what_it_covers: Cooperation between lead and concerned supervisory authorities
Exchange of relevant information
Requests for mutual assistance (Article 61)
Joint operations (Article 62)
Draft decision submission and consultation
Objection and consistency mechanism (Article 63)
Notification of decisions to controllers/processors and complainants
Complaint dismissal/rejection procedures
Obligations of controllers/processors after decisions
Urgency procedure (Article 66)
Standardized electronic communication

who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Entities established or operating in more than one EU/EEA Member State

what_it_does_not_cover: Supervisory authority cooperation outside the context of cross-border processing
Procedures for purely domestic data protection cases

mandatory_obligations: Lead supervisory authority must cooperate with other supervisory authorities concerned to reach consensus.
Lead and concerned supervisory authorities must exchange all relevant information.
Lead supervisory authority may request mutual assistance (Article 61) and conduct joint operations (Article 62).
Lead supervisory authority must communicate relevant information without delay to other authorities.
Lead supervisory authority must submit draft decisions to other authorities for their opinion and take due account of their views.
If objections are raised, the lead supervisory authority must submit the matter to the consistency mechanism (Article 63) if it does not follow the objection.
If the lead supervisory authority follows an objection, it must submit a revised draft decision for further opinion.
If no objections are raised within specified periods, authorities are deemed in agreement and are bound by the draft decision.
Lead supervisory authority must adopt and notify the decision to the main/single establishment of the controller/processor and inform other authorities and the Board.
Supervisory authority with which a complaint was lodged must inform the complainant of the decision.
If a complaint is dismissed or rejected, the authority with which it was lodged must adopt and notify the decision to the complainant and inform the controller.
Separate decisions must be adopted for different parts of a complaint if only some parts are dismissed/rejected.
Controller or processor must take necessary measures to comply with the decision and notify the lead supervisory authority, which must inform other authorities.
In urgent cases, the urgency procedure (Article 66) applies.
Information must be supplied electronically using a standardized format.
prohibited_actions: Lead supervisory authority must not ignore relevant and reasoned objections without following the consistency mechanism.
Supervisory authorities must not act outside the procedures set out for cooperation and decision-making.
conditional_requirements: If a relevant and reasoned objection is raised within four weeks, the lead supervisory authority must address it or refer to the consistency mechanism.
If the lead supervisory authority follows an objection, a revised draft decision must be submitted within two weeks for further opinion.
Separate decisions are required if only parts of a complaint are dismissed/rejected.
documentation_requirements: Draft decisions must be documented and submitted to concerned authorities.
Summary of relevant facts and grounds must be included in notifications.
Controllers/processors must document measures taken to comply with decisions.
reporting_requirements: Lead supervisory authority must notify decisions to main/single establishment and inform other authorities and the Board.
Supervisory authority with which a complaint was lodged must inform the complainant.
Controllers/processors must notify the lead supervisory authority of compliance measures, which must inform other authorities.
timeline_requirements: Relevant and reasoned objections must be raised within four weeks of consultation.
Revised draft decisions must be submitted for opinion within two weeks.
Communication and notifications must be made without delay.

general_restrictions: Supervisory authorities are bound by the agreed draft decision if no objections are raised within the specified period.
data_restrictions: Controllers/processors must ensure compliance with decisions regarding processing activities in all their EU establishments.
operational_restrictions: Controllers/processors must implement necessary measures following decisions.
technical_restrictions: Information exchange must use electronic means and standardized formats.
geographic_restrictions: Applies to processing activities in the context of all establishments in the Union.

individual_rights: Right of complainants to be informed of the decision regarding their complaint.
organizational_rights: Right of supervisory authorities to raise relevant and reasoned objections.
Right of lead supervisory authority to request mutual assistance and conduct joint operations.
how_to_exercise_rights: Complainants are informed by the authority with which they lodged the complaint.
Supervisory authorities exercise rights through formal objection and cooperation procedures.

general_exceptions: By derogation from paragraph 7, where a complaint is dismissed or rejected, the supervisory authority with which the complaint was lodged adopts and notifies the decision.
conditional_exemptions: Separate decisions for different parts of a complaint if only some parts are dismissed/rejected.
public_interest_exceptions: Urgency procedure applies in exceptional circumstances to protect the interests of data subjects (Article 66).

technical_measures: Use of electronic means and standardized formats for information exchange.
organizational_measures: Procedures for cooperation, mutual assistance, and joint operations.
Processes for draft decision submission, objection handling, and notification.

enforcement.regulatory_authority: Supervisory authorities of EU Member States; European Data Protection Board (for consistency mechanism)

penalties.administrative_penalties: Supervisory authorities may impose administrative sanctions for non-compliance with decisions.
penalties.reputational_consequences: Public disclosure of decisions may occur.

enforcement_mechanisms: Supervisory authorities monitor compliance with decisions.
Controllers/processors must notify authorities of compliance measures.
Consistency mechanism and urgency procedure for dispute resolution.

implementation_steps: Establish procedures for cooperation and information exchange between supervisory authorities.
Implement processes for submitting and reviewing draft decisions.
Develop protocols for handling objections and invoking the consistency mechanism.
Ensure timely notification of decisions to relevant parties.
Adopt standardized electronic formats for communication.
common_violations: Failure to cooperate or exchange information between authorities.
Delays in submitting draft decisions or notifications.
Ignoring relevant and reasoned objections.
Non-compliance by controllers/processors with decisions.
best_practices: Maintain clear records of all communications and decisions.
Use secure, standardized electronic communication channels.
Train staff on cross-border cooperation procedures.
Regularly review and update cooperation protocols.
compliance_checklist: Are procedures in place for cooperation and information exchange?
Is there a process for submitting and reviewing draft decisions?
Are timelines for objections and notifications monitored?
Are standardized electronic formats used for communication?
Are decisions and compliance measures properly documented and notified?

key_definitions.lead supervisory authority: The supervisory authority of the main establishment or single establishment of the controller or processor responsible for cross-border processing.
key_definitions.supervisory authorities concerned: Supervisory authorities which are concerned by the processing because the controller or processor is established on their territory, data subjects residing in their territory are substantially affected, or a complaint has been lodged with them.
key_definitions.consistency mechanism: A process under the GDPR to ensure consistent application of the regulation by supervisory authorities, involving the European Data Protection Board.
key_definitions.mutual assistance: Obligation of supervisory authorities to provide each other with information and support in enforcing the GDPR.
key_definitions.joint operations: Coordinated actions by multiple supervisory authorities, such as investigations or monitoring.

cleaned_regulations.source_section: ## Cooperation between the lead supervisory authority and the other supervisory authorities concerned

cleaned_regulations.regulation_name: General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) Article 61 â€“ Mutual assistance

description.brief_summary: Article 61 of the GDPR mandates mutual assistance and cooperation between supervisory authorities to ensure consistent application and enforcement of the Regulation across the EU. It sets out procedures for information requests, timelines, grounds for refusal, and the use of electronic means.
description.detailed_explanation: This article requires supervisory authorities to assist each other by sharing relevant information and cooperating on enforcement actions, such as investigations, authorisations, and consultations. Requests must be responded to within one month, and refusals are only permitted on grounds of lack of competence or legal conflict. Information exchanged must be used solely for the stated purpose. Electronic communication in a standardised format is required, and no fees may be charged for assistance. In cases of non-cooperation, provisional measures and urgent Board decisions are permitted. The European Commission is empowered to specify technical and procedural details for mutual assistance.
description.purpose: To ensure effective, consistent, and coordinated enforcement of the GDPR across all Member States by facilitating cooperation and information exchange between supervisory authorities.
description.legislative_intent: Lawmakers intended to prevent regulatory fragmentation and ensure that data protection rules are applied uniformly throughout the EU, especially in cross-border cases, by obligating authorities to assist each other and establishing clear procedures for cooperation.

what_it_covers: Provision of relevant information between supervisory authorities
Mutual assistance in implementing and applying the Regulation
Information requests
Supervisory measures (authorisations, consultations, inspections, investigations)
Timely responses to requests
Use of electronic means for information exchange
Prohibition of fees for mutual assistance
Indemnification for exceptional costs
Procedures for provisional measures in case of non-cooperation
Commission's power to specify formats and procedures

who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Located within EU Member States or EEA countries

what_it_does_not_cover: Direct obligations for private organizations or individuals
Supervisory authorities outside the EU/EEA unless otherwise specified

mandatory_obligations: Supervisory authorities SHALL provide each other with relevant information and mutual assistance.
Supervisory authorities SHALL put in place measures for effective cooperation.
Mutual assistance SHALL cover information requests and supervisory measures (including prior authorisations, consultations, inspections, investigations).
Each supervisory authority SHALL take all appropriate measures required to reply to a request without undue delay and no later than one month after receiving the request.
Requests for assistance SHALL contain all necessary information, including the purpose and reasons.
Information exchanged SHALL be used only for the purpose for which it was requested.
Requested supervisory authorities SHALL inform the requesting authority of the results or progress of measures taken.
Requested supervisory authorities SHALL provide reasons for any refusal to comply.
Requested supervisory authorities SHALL, as a rule, supply information by electronic means using a standardised format.
Requested supervisory authorities SHALL NOT charge a fee for any action taken pursuant to a request for mutual assistance.
prohibited_actions: Requested supervisory authorities SHALL NOT refuse to comply with a request except on specified grounds.
Requested supervisory authorities SHALL NOT use exchanged information for purposes other than those for which it was requested.
Requested supervisory authorities SHALL NOT charge a fee for mutual assistance.
conditional_requirements: Refusal to comply with a request is permitted ONLY IF: (a) the authority is not competent for the subject-matter or measures requested; or (b) compliance would infringe the Regulation or Union/Member State law.
Supervisory authorities MAY agree on rules to indemnify each other for specific expenditure arising from mutual assistance in exceptional circumstances.
If information is not provided within one month, the requesting authority MAY adopt a provisional measure in its Member State, and urgent action under Article 66(1) is presumed.
documentation_requirements: Requests for assistance must include all necessary information, including the purpose and reasons.
Requested authorities must document and communicate the results or progress of measures taken.
Reasons for refusal must be provided in writing.
reporting_requirements: Requested authorities must inform the requesting authority of results or progress.
Reasons for refusal must be reported to the requesting authority.
timeline_requirements: Reply to requests must be provided without undue delay and no later than one month after receiving the request.
If information is not provided within one month, provisional measures may be taken.

general_restrictions: Refusal to comply with a request is limited to lack of competence or legal conflict.
Information exchanged is restricted to the purpose for which it was requested.
data_restrictions: Information exchanged may only be used for the stated purpose.
operational_restrictions: No fees may be charged for mutual assistance actions.
Information should be supplied by electronic means using a standardised format.
technical_restrictions: Information should be exchanged by electronic means in a standardised format (subject to Commission implementing acts).
geographic_restrictions: Applies to supervisory authorities within the EU/EEA.

organizational_rights: Supervisory authorities have the right to request mutual assistance from other supervisory authorities.
Supervisory authorities have the right to receive information and cooperation from other authorities.
Supervisory authorities may agree on indemnification for exceptional costs.
how_to_exercise_rights: Submit a request for assistance containing all necessary information, including purpose and reasons, to another supervisory authority.

general_exceptions: Requested supervisory authority may refuse to comply with a request if it is not competent for the subject-matter or measures requested.
Requested supervisory authority may refuse if compliance would infringe the Regulation or Union/Member State law.
conditional_exemptions: Indemnification for specific expenditure is allowed in exceptional circumstances if agreed upon.

technical_measures: Use of electronic means for information exchange.
Adoption of standardised formats for communication (as specified by the Commission).
organizational_measures: Establish measures for effective cooperation.
Procedures for handling and responding to requests for assistance.

enforcement.regulatory_authority: Supervisory authorities in each EU/EEA Member State; European Data Protection Board (for urgent binding decisions); European Commission (for implementing acts).
enforcement_mechanisms: Supervisory authorities may adopt provisional measures if mutual assistance is not provided within one month.
Urgent binding decisions may be required from the Board under Article 66(2).
Commission may specify procedures and formats via implementing acts.

related_articles: Article 66(2) (Urgent binding decision from the Board)
complementary_regulations: GDPR Article 60 (Cooperation between the lead supervisory authority and the other supervisory authorities concerned)
GDPR Article 62 (Joint operations of supervisory authorities)

implementation_steps: Establish internal procedures for handling mutual assistance requests.
Ensure staff are trained to respond within one month.
Adopt electronic systems capable of exchanging information in standardised formats.
Document all requests, responses, and reasons for any refusals.
Agree on indemnification rules for exceptional costs if necessary.
common_violations: Failure to respond to requests within one month.
Refusing requests without valid grounds.
Charging fees for mutual assistance.
Using exchanged information for unauthorized purposes.
Not providing reasons for refusal.
best_practices: Maintain clear records of all mutual assistance activities.
Use secure and interoperable electronic communication channels.
Regularly review and update cooperation procedures.
Coordinate with other supervisory authorities proactively.
compliance_checklist: Are all requests for assistance responded to within one month?
Are refusals only made on grounds of lack of competence or legal conflict?
Is all information exchanged used solely for the stated purpose?
Are electronic means and standardised formats used for communication?
Are no fees charged for mutual assistance?
Are reasons for refusals documented and communicated?

key_definitions.supervisory authority: An independent public authority established by a Member State pursuant to Article 51 of the GDPR.
key_definitions.mutual assistance: The process by which supervisory authorities provide each other with relevant information and support to implement and apply the Regulation.
key_definitions.provisional measure: A temporary action taken by a supervisory authority in its Member State when mutual assistance is not provided in a timely manner.
key_definitions.implementing acts: Legal acts adopted by the European Commission to specify technical and procedural details for the application of the Regulation.

cleaned_regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation), Article 62 â€“ Joint operations of supervisory authorities

industry_sectors: All sectors processing personal data within the EU

description.brief_summary: Article 62 of the GDPR sets out the legal basis and procedures for joint operations, including investigations and enforcement, by supervisory authorities from different EU Member States in cases of cross-border data processing.
description.detailed_explanation: This article mandates that supervisory authorities cooperate in joint operations, such as investigations and enforcement measures, when appropriate, especially in cases involving controllers or processors with establishments in multiple Member States or where data subjects in more than one Member State are substantially affected. It details the rights of supervisory authorities to participate, the obligation of the competent authority to invite and respond to participation requests, the conferral and exercise of investigative powers by seconded staff, liability and reimbursement for damages caused during joint operations, exceptions to reimbursement, and the procedure for provisional measures and urgent Board decisions when a supervisory authority fails to comply with participation obligations.
description.purpose: To ensure effective, coordinated, and consistent enforcement of data protection rules across the EU, particularly in cross-border cases.
description.legislative_intent: Lawmakers intended to facilitate cooperation and mutual assistance among supervisory authorities, prevent regulatory gaps in cross-border cases, and provide clear rules for liability, participation, and urgent action.

what_it_covers: Joint operations by supervisory authorities
Joint investigations
Joint enforcement measures
Participation of staff from other Member States
Conferral and exercise of investigative powers
Liability for damages during joint operations
Reimbursement between Member States
Provisional measures and urgent Board decisions

who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Entities with establishments or data subjects in more than one EU Member State

what_it_does_not_cover: Operations not involving cross-border processing
Supervisory authorities outside the EU
Non-personal data processing

mandatory_obligations: Supervisory authorities shall conduct joint operations where appropriate.
Competent supervisory authority must invite other relevant supervisory authorities to participate in joint operations.
Competent supervisory authority must respond without delay to participation requests from other supervisory authorities.
Investigative powers may only be exercised under the guidance and in the presence of host supervisory authority staff.
Host Member State assumes responsibility and liability for actions of seconded staff during joint operations.
Member State where damage occurs must compensate for damage as if caused by its own staff.
Seconding Member State must reimburse host Member State for compensation paid.
Each Member State shall refrain from requesting reimbursement from another Member State except as provided in paragraph 5.
prohibited_actions: Member States must not request reimbursement from another Member State for damage except as provided in paragraph 5.
conditional_requirements: Joint operations are required 'where appropriate'.

Participation rights apply where controller/processor has establishments in several Member States or where a significant number of data subjects in more than one Member State are likely to be substantially affected.
Conferral of investigative powers is subject to Member State law and authorisation by the seconding supervisory authority.
Exercise of investigative powers by seconded staff is subject to the law of the host supervisory authority's Member State.
If a supervisory authority does not comply with participation obligations within one month, other authorities may adopt provisional measures.
timeline_requirements: Competent supervisory authority must respond to participation requests without delay.
If a supervisory authority does not comply within one month, other authorities may act provisionally.

general_restrictions: Investigative powers by seconded staff may only be exercised under guidance and in the presence of host authority staff.
Seconded staff are subject to the law of the host Member State.
operational_restrictions: Joint operations must involve staff from other Member States only as permitted by law.
Provisional measures may only be adopted if participation obligations are not met within one month.
geographic_restrictions: Applies only within the territory of EU Member States.

organizational_rights: Supervisory authorities of each relevant Member State have the right to participate in joint operations.
Supervisory authorities may request to participate in joint operations.
how_to_exercise_rights: Supervisory authorities exercise participation rights by request; competent authority must invite and respond.

general_exceptions: Member States are not required to reimburse each other for damages except as provided in paragraph 5.
conditional_exemptions: Conferral of investigative powers is subject to Member State law and authorisation.

organizational_measures: Establish procedures for joint operations and participation.
Implement protocols for conferral and exercise of investigative powers.
Maintain liability and reimbursement processes for damages.

enforcement.regulatory_authority: Supervisory authorities of EU Member States; European Data Protection Board (for urgent binding decisions)

penalties.financial_penalties: Liability for damages caused by staff during joint operations; reimbursement obligations between Member States.
penalties.administrative_penalties: Possible administrative actions for non-compliance with participation obligations.

enforcement_mechanisms: Urgent binding decisions by the European Data Protection Board

related_articles: Article 56 (Competence of the lead supervisory authority)

implementation_steps: Identify cross-border processing cases requiring joint operations.
Establish communication protocols between supervisory authorities.
Develop procedures for inviting and responding to participation requests.
Define processes for conferral and exercise of investigative powers.
Set up liability and reimbursement mechanisms for damages.
Monitor compliance with participation and response timelines.
Prepare for provisional measures and urgent Board decisions if necessary.
common_violations: Failure to invite or respond to participation requests from other supervisory authorities.
Improper conferral or exercise of investigative powers by seconded staff.
Failure to assume liability or reimburse damages as required.
Delays in responding to participation requests.
best_practices: Maintain clear documentation of joint operation procedures.
Regularly train staff on cross-border cooperation protocols.
Establish clear lines of authority and responsibility for joint operations.
Promptly address requests and obligations to avoid provisional measures.
compliance_checklist: Are joint operations conducted where appropriate?
Are all relevant supervisory authorities invited and responded to promptly?
Are investigative powers conferred and exercised in compliance with Member State law?
Is liability for damages properly assumed and reimbursed?
Are timelines for participation and response met?
Are provisional measures and urgent Board decisions used only as permitted?

key_definitions.supervisory authority: An independent public authority established by a Member State pursuant to Article 51 of the GDPR.
key_definitions.joint operation: Coordinated action, including investigations and enforcement, conducted by supervisory authorities from more than one Member State.
key_definitions.seconding supervisory authority: The supervisory authority sending its staff to participate in a joint operation in another Member State.
key_definitions.host supervisory authority: The supervisory authority in the Member State where the joint operation is taking place.

description.brief_summary: Supervisory authorities in the EU must cooperate with each other and, where relevant, with the Commission, using a consistency mechanism to ensure the Regulation is applied uniformly.
description.detailed_explanation: This section mandates that supervisory authorities across the European Union engage in cooperation, both among themselves and, when appropriate, with the European Commission. The cooperation must occur through a formalized process referred to as the 'consistency mechanism.' The purpose of this mechanism is to promote and ensure the consistent application and enforcement of the Regulation throughout all EU member states.
description.purpose: To ensure that the Regulation is applied in a consistent manner across all EU member states, preventing divergent interpretations or enforcement.
description.legislative_intent: Lawmakers intended to create a harmonized approach to regulatory enforcement and interpretation, reducing fragmentation and ensuring legal certainty for entities subject to the Regulation.

what_it_covers: Cooperation between supervisory authorities
Cooperation with the European Commission where relevant
Use of a consistency mechanism for regulatory application

who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Within the European Union

what_it_does_not_cover: Direct obligations for private organizations or individuals
Specific procedures of the consistency mechanism (not detailed in this section)

mandatory_obligations: Supervisory authorities SHALL cooperate with each other
Supervisory authorities SHALL cooperate with the Commission where relevant
Cooperation SHALL occur through the consistency mechanism as set out in this Section
conditional_requirements: Cooperation with the Commission is required only where relevant

general_restrictions: Cooperation with the Commission is limited to situations where it is relevant
operational_restrictions: Supervisory authorities must use the consistency mechanism for cooperation
geographic_restrictions: Applies only within the European Union

organizational_rights: Supervisory authorities have the right to cooperate with each other and with the Commission through the consistency mechanism

general_exceptions: Cooperation with the Commission is not required if not relevant

organizational_measures: Establish procedures for cooperation through the consistency mechanism

enforcement.regulatory_authority: Supervisory authorities and the European Commission (where relevant)
enforcement_mechanisms: Oversight by the European Commission and peer supervisory authorities

implementation_steps: Identify relevant supervisory authorities
Establish communication channels for cooperation
Develop internal procedures for engaging in the consistency mechanism
common_violations: Failure to cooperate with other supervisory authorities
Failure to involve the Commission where relevant
Not using the consistency mechanism as required
best_practices: Maintain clear records of cooperation activities
Regularly review procedures for consistency mechanism engagement
compliance_checklist: Are procedures in place for cooperation with other supervisory authorities?
Is there a process to determine when Commission involvement is relevant?
Is the consistency mechanism being used as required?

key_definitions.consistency mechanism: A formal process established to ensure the uniform application of a regulation across all relevant authorities within the Union.

cleaned_regulations.regulation_name: General Data Protection Regulation (EU) 2016/679, Article 64 â€“ Opinion of the Board

industry_sectors: All sectors processing personal data within the EU

description.brief_summary: Article 64 of the GDPR sets out the circumstances and procedures under which the European Data Protection Board (EDPB) must issue an opinion on certain draft decisions by supervisory authorities, ensuring harmonized application of data protection rules across the EU.
description.detailed_explanation: This article requires that when a competent supervisory authority intends to adopt specific measuresâ€”such as lists of processing operations requiring a data protection impact assessment, codes of conduct, accreditation criteria for certification bodies, standard data protection clauses, contractual clauses for data transfers, or binding corporate rulesâ€”it must communicate the draft decision to the EDPB for an opinion. The article also allows any supervisory authority, the Chair of the Board, or the European Commission to request an opinion on matters of general application or cross-border effect, especially in cases of non-compliance with mutual assistance or joint operations obligations. The Board must issue its opinion within a set timeframe, and supervisory authorities must take utmost account of the opinion, communicating their final decision and rationale. If the authority does not follow the Board's opinion, escalation to the dispute resolution mechanism under Article 65 is required.
description.purpose: To ensure consistent and harmonized application of data protection rules across the EU, particularly in cases with cross-border implications or significant impact.
description.legislative_intent: Lawmakers intended to prevent fragmentation in the application of data protection law by requiring supervisory authorities to seek and consider the EDPB's opinion on key decisions, thereby promoting uniformity and legal certainty.

what_it_covers: Adoption of lists of processing operations requiring data protection impact assessments (Article 35(4))
Assessment of codes of conduct and their amendments/extensions (Article 40(7))
Approval of accreditation criteria for monitoring bodies (Article 41(3))
Approval of accreditation criteria for certification bodies (Article 43(3))
Determination of standard data protection clauses (Article 46(2)(d), Article 28(8))
Authorization of contractual clauses for data transfers (Article 46(3)(a))
Approval of binding corporate rules (Article 47)
Matters of general application or cross-border effect
Cases of non-compliance with mutual assistance (Article 61) or joint operations (Article 62)

target_entities: Organizations seeking approval for codes of conduct, certification, or binding corporate rules
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Entities operating within the EU or whose processing activities affect data subjects in the EU

what_it_does_not_cover: Matters not listed in paragraphs 1 and 2
Draft decisions not communicated to the Board
Matters already subject to a previous Board opinion

mandatory_obligations: Competent supervisory authority MUST communicate draft decisions to the Board in specified cases (see paragraph 1)
Supervisory authorities, the Chair of the Board, or the Commission MAY request Board examination of matters of general application or cross-border effect
Board MUST issue an opinion within eight weeks (extendable by six weeks for complexity)
Supervisory authorities and the Commission MUST communicate relevant information to the Board without undue delay using a standardized format
Chair of the Board MUST inform members and the Commission of relevant information and opinions without undue delay
Supervisory authority MUST NOT adopt its draft decision during the Board's opinion period
Supervisory authority MUST take utmost account of the Board's opinion and communicate its response within two weeks
prohibited_actions: Supervisory authority MUST NOT adopt the draft decision referred to in paragraph 1 within the period referred to in paragraph 3
conditional_requirements: If the supervisory authority does not intend to follow the Board's opinion, it MUST provide relevant grounds and Article 65(1) applies (dispute resolution mechanism)
Board opinion period MAY be extended by six weeks for complex matters
documentation_requirements: Draft decision
Summary of facts
Grounds for the measure
Views of other supervisory authorities concerned
Communication of amended draft decision if applicable
reporting_requirements: Communication of draft decisions and relevant information to the Board
Notification to the Chair of the Board regarding whether the draft decision will be maintained or amended
timeline_requirements: Board opinion to be adopted within eight weeks (extendable by six weeks)
Supervisory authority to respond within two weeks after receiving the opinion
Reasonable period for members to object to draft decision as indicated by the Chair

general_restrictions: Supervisory authority cannot proceed with draft decision until Board opinion process is complete
data_restrictions: Applies to processing operations subject to data protection impact assessments, codes of conduct, certification, and cross-border data transfers
operational_restrictions: Supervisory authorities must follow standardized communication and procedural steps
technical_restrictions: Use of standardized electronic formats for communication
geographic_restrictions: Applies within the EU and to cross-border matters affecting more than one Member State

organizational_rights: Right of supervisory authorities, the Chair of the Board, or the Commission to request Board examination of matters of general application or cross-border effect
how_to_exercise_rights: Submission of request to the Board for opinion

general_exceptions: Board does not issue an opinion if it has already issued an opinion on the same matter

technical_measures: Use of electronic means and standardized formats for communication
organizational_measures: Procedures for submitting draft decisions and responding to Board opinions
Internal processes to ensure timely communication and compliance with Board opinions
certification_requirements: Approval of accreditation criteria for certification bodies (Article 43(3))

enforcement.regulatory_authority: European Data Protection Board (EDPB), National Supervisory Authorities, European Commission

penalties.administrative_penalties: Potential administrative actions for non-compliance with Board opinions or procedural requirements
penalties.reputational_consequences: Publication of Board opinions and decisions

enforcement_mechanisms: Escalation to dispute resolution mechanism under Article 65(1) if Board opinion is not followed
Public disclosure of opinions and decisions

complementary_regulations: Other GDPR articles on supervisory authority cooperation and consistency

implementation_steps: Identify when a draft decision falls under Article 64(1) or (2)
Prepare and submit draft decision and supporting documentation to the Board
Use standardized electronic formats for all communications
Monitor Board opinion timelines and refrain from adopting draft decisions during this period
Respond to Board opinion within two weeks, indicating whether the draft decision will be maintained or amended
If not following the Board's opinion, provide grounds and prepare for possible dispute resolution under Article 65
common_violations: Failure to submit draft decisions to the Board when required
Adopting draft decisions before the Board opinion process is complete
Not taking utmost account of the Board's opinion
Failure to communicate responses or amended decisions within required timelines
best_practices: Establish internal procedures for timely submission and response
Maintain clear records of all communications with the Board
Ensure staff are trained on procedural requirements
Monitor for updates or changes in Board procedures
compliance_checklist: Is the draft decision covered by Article 64(1) or (2)?
Has the draft decision and all required information been submitted to the Board?
Are communications using the standardized format and electronic means?
Has the Board's opinion been received and considered?
Has the response to the Board been communicated within two weeks?
If not following the Board's opinion, have grounds been provided and Article 65 procedures initiated?

key_definitions.Board: European Data Protection Board (EDPB), the EU body responsible for ensuring consistent application of the GDPR.
key_definitions.Supervisory Authority: Independent public authority established by a Member State under Article 51 of the GDPR.
key_definitions.Draft Decision: A preliminary decision by a supervisory authority subject to review or opinion by the Board.
key_definitions.Opinion: Formal advice or assessment issued by the Board regarding a draft decision.
key_definitions.Binding Corporate Rules: Internal rules adopted by multinational companies to allow intra-group transfers of personal data outside the EU in compliance with GDPR.

cleaned_regulations.regulation_name: General Data Protection Regulation (EU) 2016/679, Article 65 â€“ Dispute resolution by the Board

industry_sectors: All sectors processing personal data within the EU/EEA

description.brief_summary: Article 65 of the GDPR establishes the process by which the European Data Protection Board (EDPB) resolves disputes between supervisory authorities to ensure the consistent application of the Regulation.
description.detailed_explanation: This article sets out the circumstances in which the EDPB must adopt a binding decision, including when there are relevant and reasoned objections to a draft decision, conflicts over the competent supervisory authority, or failure to request or follow the Board's opinion. It prescribes the decision-making process, including voting thresholds, timelines, notification, and publication requirements. The article also restricts supervisory authorities from making decisions on the subject matter during the Board's deliberation and mandates that final decisions by supervisory authorities must be based on the Board's binding decision.
description.purpose: To ensure the correct and consistent application of the GDPR across the EU by providing a binding dispute resolution mechanism for disagreements between supervisory authorities.
description.legislative_intent: Lawmakers intended to prevent inconsistent enforcement of data protection rules across Member States by empowering the EDPB to resolve disputes and issue binding decisions.

what_it_covers: Dispute resolution between supervisory authorities
Adoption of binding decisions by the EDPB
Cases involving relevant and reasoned objections to draft decisions
Conflicts regarding the competent supervisory authority
Failure to request or follow the Board's opinion under Article 64
Timelines and procedures for Board decisions
Notification and publication of Board decisions
Obligations of supervisory authorities to implement Board decisions

who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Entities established or operating in the EU/EEA

what_it_does_not_cover: Disputes not involving supervisory authorities
Matters outside the scope of the GDPR
Private disputes between data subjects and controllers/processors

mandatory_obligations: The Board SHALL adopt a binding decision in the cases specified in paragraph 1.
The decision SHALL be adopted within one month from referral, extendable by one month for complexity.
The decision SHALL be reasoned and addressed to the lead supervisory authority and all concerned supervisory authorities and SHALL be binding on them.
Supervisory authorities concerned SHALL NOT adopt a decision on the subject matter during the Board's deliberation periods.
The Chair of the Board SHALL notify the decision without undue delay to the supervisory authorities concerned and inform the Commission.
The decision SHALL be published on the Board's website after the final decision is notified.
The lead supervisory authority or the authority with which the complaint was lodged SHALL adopt its final decision based on the Board's decision within one month of notification.
The final decision SHALL refer to and attach the Board's decision and specify its publication.
prohibited_actions: Supervisory authorities concerned MUST NOT adopt a decision on the subject matter during the Board's decision-making periods.
conditional_requirements: If the Board cannot adopt a decision within the initial periods, it SHALL adopt a decision within two weeks by simple majority; if tied, the Chair's vote prevails.
Any supervisory authority concerned or the Commission MAY communicate the matter to the Board if a competent authority does not request or follow the Board's opinion under Article 64.
documentation_requirements: The final decision SHALL attach the Board's binding decision.
Supervisory authorities SHALL inform the Board of the date when the final decision is notified to the controller/processor and data subject.
reporting_requirements: Notification of the Board's decision to supervisory authorities and the Commission.
Publication of the Board's decision on its website.
timeline_requirements: Board decision within one month of referral (extendable by one month for complexity).
If not adopted in time, decision within two weeks after the second month by simple majority.
Final decision by lead or relevant supervisory authority within one month after Board notification.
Notification of final decision to controller/processor and data subject without undue delay.

general_restrictions: Supervisory authorities concerned are restricted from making decisions on the subject matter during the Board's deliberation periods.
operational_restrictions: Supervisory authorities must suspend decision-making on the disputed subject matter during the Board's process.

individual_rights: Right of data subjects to have complaints resolved in accordance with a consistent EU-wide process.
organizational_rights: Right of supervisory authorities and the Commission to refer disputes to the Board.
Right of supervisory authorities to receive a binding decision from the Board.
how_to_exercise_rights: Supervisory authorities or the Commission communicate the matter to the Board as per Article 65(1)(c).

general_exceptions: No explicit general exceptions stated in this section.
conditional_exemptions: Extension of the Board's decision period by one month in complex cases.

organizational_measures: Establish procedures for timely referral and notification of disputes to the Board.
Implement processes to suspend decision-making during Board deliberations.
Ensure publication of Board decisions as required.

enforcement.regulatory_authority: European Data Protection Board (EDPB); National Supervisory Authorities

penalties.administrative_penalties: Binding nature of Board decisions; failure to comply may result in enforcement action under GDPR.
penalties.reputational_consequences: Publication of Board decisions on the EDPB website.

enforcement_mechanisms: Binding decisions enforceable on supervisory authorities.
Publication of decisions for transparency and accountability.

related_articles: Article 60 (Cooperation between the lead supervisory authority and the other supervisory authorities concerned)
complementary_regulations: National data protection laws implementing GDPR

implementation_steps: Establish internal procedures for handling disputes and referrals to the Board.
Train staff on the timelines and requirements for Board involvement.
Ensure mechanisms for suspending decision-making during Board deliberations.
Prepare templates for notification and publication of Board decisions.
common_violations: Failure to refer disputes to the Board in a timely manner.
Issuing decisions on disputed matters before the Board's binding decision.
Not publishing or notifying Board decisions as required.
best_practices: Maintain clear communication channels with the Board and other supervisory authorities.
Document all steps and communications related to dispute resolution.
Monitor Board publications for relevant decisions.
compliance_checklist: Are disputes referred to the Board as required?
Are all timelines for Board and final decisions met?
Is decision-making suspended during Board deliberations?
Are notifications and publications completed without undue delay?
Are Board decisions attached to final decisions and referenced appropriately?

key_definitions.Board: European Data Protection Board (EDPB), the EU body responsible for ensuring consistent application of the GDPR.
key_definitions.Supervisory authority: An independent public authority established by a Member State under Article 51 of the GDPR.
key_definitions.Lead supervisory authority: The authority with primary responsibility for cross-border processing cases under Article 56.
key_definitions.Relevant and reasoned objection: An objection to a draft decision that clearly demonstrates the significance of the risks posed by the draft decision as regards the fundamental rights and freedoms of data subjects and, where applicable, the free flow of personal data within the Union.

cleaned_regulations.regulation_name: General Data Protection Regulation (EU) 2016/679, Article 66 â€“ Urgency procedure

industry_sectors: All sectors processing personal data within the EU

description.brief_summary: Article 66 of the GDPR allows supervisory authorities to take urgent provisional measures to protect data subjects' rights and freedoms, bypassing the usual consistency mechanisms, and sets out the process for requesting urgent opinions or binding decisions from the EDPB.
description.detailed_explanation: In exceptional circumstances where urgent action is needed to protect the rights and freedoms of data subjects, a supervisory authority may, by way of derogation from the standard consistency mechanism (Articles 63, 64, 65) or the cooperation procedure (Article 60), immediately adopt provisional measures with legal effect in its own territory for up to three months. The authority must promptly communicate these measures and the reasons for them to other concerned supervisory authorities, the EDPB, and the European Commission. If final measures are urgently needed, the authority may request an urgent opinion or binding decision from the EDPB, providing reasons. Any supervisory authority may also request such urgent action if a competent authority has not acted appropriately. The EDPB must adopt urgent opinions or binding decisions within two weeks by simple majority, derogating from the usual timelines in Articles 64(3) and 65(2).
description.purpose: To ensure that supervisory authorities can act swiftly to protect data subjects' rights and freedoms in urgent situations, even if this requires bypassing standard procedures.
description.legislative_intent: Lawmakers intended to provide a mechanism for immediate intervention by supervisory authorities in exceptional cases where the standard consistency or cooperation procedures would be too slow to prevent harm to data subjects.

what_it_covers: Adoption of provisional measures by supervisory authorities in urgent cases
Derogation from the consistency mechanism (Articles 63, 64, 65)
Derogation from the cooperation procedure (Article 60)
Communication of urgent measures to other authorities, the EDPB, and the Commission
Requesting urgent opinions or binding decisions from the EDPB
Timelines for urgent EDPB decisions

who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Supervisory authorities within EU Member States

what_it_does_not_cover: Routine data processing activities by organizations or individuals
Non-urgent situations
Actions outside the territory of the supervisory authority adopting the provisional measure

mandatory_obligations: Supervisory authority must consider there is an urgent need to act to protect data subjects' rights and freedoms
Provisional measures must be adopted by way of derogation from Articles 63, 64, 65 or Article 60
Provisional measures must have a specified period of validity not exceeding three months
Supervisory authority must communicate those measures and the reasons for adopting them without delay to other supervisory authorities concerned, to the Board, and to the Commission
If final measures are urgently needed, the authority may request an urgent opinion or binding decision from the Board, giving reasons
Any supervisory authority may request an urgent opinion or binding decision from the Board if a competent authority has not acted appropriately in an urgent situation, giving reasons
Urgent opinions or binding decisions by the Board must be adopted within two weeks by simple majority
prohibited_actions: Adopting provisional measures for longer than three months
Failing to communicate urgent measures and reasons without delay
conditional_requirements: Derogation from the consistency mechanism or cooperation procedure is only permitted in exceptional circumstances where urgent action is needed
Request for urgent opinion or binding decision must include reasons for the request and for the urgent need to act
documentation_requirements: Record of provisional measures adopted
Reasons for adopting urgent measures
Requests for urgent opinions or binding decisions, including justifications
reporting_requirements: Immediate communication of urgent measures and reasons to other supervisory authorities concerned, the Board, and the Commission
timeline_requirements: Provisional measures: validity not exceeding three months
Urgent opinions or binding decisions: to be adopted within two weeks

general_restrictions: Provisional measures may only be adopted in exceptional circumstances and must be limited to a maximum of three months
operational_restrictions: Provisional measures may only have legal effect within the territory of the adopting supervisory authority
geographic_restrictions: Provisional measures are limited to the territory of the supervisory authority adopting them

individual_rights: Indirect protection of data subjects' rights and freedoms through urgent supervisory authority action
organizational_rights: Supervisory authorities have the right to derogate from standard procedures in urgent cases
Right to request urgent opinions or binding decisions from the Board
how_to_exercise_rights: Supervisory authorities exercise these rights by adopting provisional measures and/or submitting requests to the Board with justifications

general_exceptions: Standard consistency mechanism and cooperation procedures do not apply in exceptional urgent cases as described
conditional_exemptions: Derogation is only allowed in exceptional circumstances where urgent action is necessary
public_interest_exceptions: Urgency procedure may be invoked to protect the rights and freedoms of data subjects, which may include public interest considerations

organizational_measures: Procedures for identifying and responding to urgent situations
Processes for communicating urgent measures to relevant authorities
training_requirements: Training for supervisory authority staff on urgency procedures and communication obligations
audit_requirements: Internal review of urgency procedure activations and compliance with communication and documentation requirements

enforcement.regulatory_authority: Supervisory authorities in each EU Member State; European Data Protection Board (EDPB)

penalties.administrative_penalties: Possible administrative sanctions for supervisory authorities failing to comply with procedural requirements
penalties.reputational_consequences: Potential reputational impact for authorities not acting or communicating appropriately in urgent cases

enforcement_mechanisms: Oversight by the EDPB and the European Commission
Peer review by other supervisory authorities

implementation_steps: Establish internal criteria for identifying exceptional urgent circumstances
Develop procedures for adopting and documenting provisional measures
Set up rapid communication channels with other supervisory authorities, the EDPB, and the Commission
Train staff on urgency procedures and documentation requirements
Monitor and review the use of urgency procedures for compliance
common_violations: Failure to communicate urgent measures and reasons without delay
Adopting provisional measures for longer than three months
Requesting urgent Board action without sufficient justification
best_practices: Maintain clear records of all urgent actions and communications
Ensure transparency and accountability in the use of urgency procedures
Regularly review and update internal urgency procedures
compliance_checklist: Are exceptional circumstances clearly documented?
Were provisional measures limited to three months?
Were all required communications made without delay?
Were requests for urgent Board action properly justified?
Was the urgency procedure used only when standard mechanisms were insufficient?

key_definitions.supervisory authority: An independent public authority established by a Member State pursuant to Article 51 of the GDPR.
key_definitions.consistency mechanism: A process under the GDPR to ensure consistent application of the regulation across the EU, involving cooperation and consultation among supervisory authorities and the EDPB.
key_definitions.provisional measures: Temporary legal actions adopted by a supervisory authority intended to address urgent risks to data subjects' rights and freedoms.
key_definitions.EDPB: European Data Protection Board, the EU body responsible for ensuring consistent application of the GDPR.

industry_sectors: All sectors subject to EU data protection law

description.brief_summary: Empowers the Commission to adopt implementing acts specifying electronic information exchange arrangements between supervisory authorities and the Board, using a standardized format as per Article 64, and requires use of the examination procedure in Article 93(2).
description.detailed_explanation: This section provides the legal basis for the European Commission to establish detailed rules (implementing acts) regarding how information is to be exchanged electronically between supervisory authorities and between those authorities and the Board. The section specifically references the need to define a standardized format for such exchanges, as mentioned in Article 64. The adoption of these implementing acts must follow the examination procedure set out in Article 93(2), which involves oversight and input from a committee procedure.
