description.brief_summary: GDPR Article 80 allows data subjects to mandate not-for-profit organizations to represent them in exercising their rights, lodging complaints, and seeking compensation. It also permits Member States to allow such organizations to act independently in certain cases.
description.detailed_explanation: This article provides that data subjects have the right to appoint a not-for-profit body, organization, or association, which is properly constituted under Member State law, has public interest objectives, and is active in data protection, to act on their behalf in lodging complaints, exercising rights under Articles 77 (right to lodge a complaint), 78 (right to an effective judicial remedy against a supervisory authority), and 79 (right to an effective judicial remedy against a controller or processor), and to seek compensation under Article 82. Additionally, Member States may allow such organizations to lodge complaints and exercise rights under Articles 78 and 79 independently of a data subject's mandate if they believe a data subject's rights have been infringed.
description.purpose: To facilitate the effective exercise of data protection rights by allowing collective representation and to ensure access to remedies for data subjects, especially those who may not be able to act individually.
description.legislative_intent: Lawmakers intended to strengthen the enforcement of data protection rights by enabling collective action and representation, thereby improving access to justice and remedies for data subjects.

what_it_covers: Mandating not-for-profit organizations to represent data subjects
Lodging complaints with supervisory authorities
Exercising rights under Articles 77, 78, and 79
Seeking compensation under Article 82
Independent action by organizations where permitted by Member State law

who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Entities and individuals within EU Member States

what_it_does_not_cover: For-profit organizations acting as representatives
Organizations not properly constituted under Member State law
Organizations without public interest statutory objectives
Organizations not active in data protection

mandatory_obligations: Organizations must be not-for-profit, properly constituted under Member State law, have public interest statutory objectives, and be active in data protection to be mandated by data subjects.
Member States must allow data subjects to mandate such organizations to act on their behalf as described.
prohibited_actions: For-profit or improperly constituted organizations may not act as representatives under this Article.
conditional_requirements: The right to seek compensation under Article 82 on behalf of a data subject is only where provided for by Member State law.
Member States may (but are not required to) allow organizations to act independently of a data subject's mandate.
documentation_requirements: Organizations must be able to demonstrate proper constitution under Member State law and public interest statutory objectives.
reporting_requirements: Complaints must be lodged with the competent supervisory authority as per Article 77.

general_restrictions: Only not-for-profit bodies, organizations, or associations meeting specific criteria may act as representatives.
operational_restrictions: Organizations must be active in the field of the protection of data subjects' rights and freedoms with regard to personal data.
geographic_restrictions: Organizations must be constituted in accordance with the law of a Member State.

individual_rights: Right to mandate a qualified not-for-profit organization to lodge complaints, exercise rights under Articles 77, 78, and 79, and seek compensation under Article 82 on their behalf.
organizational_rights: Right for qualified organizations to act on behalf of data subjects as mandated.
Right for qualified organizations to lodge complaints and exercise rights under Articles 78 and 79 independently of a data subject's mandate, where permitted by Member State law.
how_to_exercise_rights: Data subject provides a mandate to a qualified organization.
Organization lodges complaint or exercises rights with the competent supervisory authority.
Organization may act independently if Member State law allows.

general_exceptions: Organizations that do not meet the criteria (not-for-profit, properly constituted, public interest objectives, active in data protection) are excluded.
conditional_exemptions: Right to seek compensation on behalf of a data subject is only available where provided for by Member State law.
Independent action by organizations is subject to Member State discretion.

organizational_measures: Organizations must maintain documentation proving their not-for-profit status, proper constitution, public interest objectives, and activity in data protection.

enforcement.regulatory_authority: Supervisory authorities designated under GDPR Article 51 in each Member State

penalties.financial_penalties: Fines for non-compliance with GDPR as per Article 83; up to â‚¬20 million or 4% of annual global turnover, whichever is higher, depending on the infringement.
penalties.administrative_penalties: Orders to comply, reprimands, or bans on processing.
penalties.reputational_consequences: Public disclosure of enforcement actions by supervisory authorities.

enforcement_mechanisms: Investigation of complaints by supervisory authorities

implementation_steps: Verify organizational eligibility (not-for-profit, proper constitution, public interest objectives, active in data protection).
Establish procedures for accepting mandates from data subjects.
Develop processes for lodging complaints and exercising rights on behalf of data subjects.
Monitor Member State law for provisions allowing independent action.
common_violations: Organizations acting without proper mandate or not meeting eligibility criteria.
Failure to provide documentation of eligibility.
Lodging complaints without proper authority.
best_practices: Maintain clear records of mandates and organizational status.
Regularly review Member State legal requirements.
Train staff on rights and procedures for representation.
compliance_checklist: Is the organization not-for-profit?
Is it properly constituted under Member State law?
Does it have public interest statutory objectives?
Is it active in data protection?
Is there a valid mandate from the data subject (unless acting independently under Member State law)?

key_definitions.data subject: An identified or identifiable natural person whose personal data is processed.
key_definitions.not-for-profit body, organisation or ass: An entity that does not operate for profit, is properly constituted under Member State law, has public interest statutory objectives, and is active in data protection.
key_definitions.mandate: Authorization given by a data subject to an organization to act on their behalf.
key_definitions.supervisory authority: An independent public authority established by a Member State pursuant to Article 51.

industry_sectors: All sectors involving data controllers or processors

description.brief_summary: This section regulates how courts in different EU Member States must coordinate when there are parallel proceedings concerning the same subject matter and the same data controller or processor.
description.detailed_explanation: The section requires that if a competent court in one Member State becomes aware of proceedings on the same subject matter involving the same controller or processor in another Member State, it must contact the other court to confirm the existence of such proceedings. If such parallel proceedings exist, any court other than the one first seized may suspend its proceedings. Additionally, if the proceedings are at first instance, courts other than the first seized may, upon application by a party, decline jurisdiction if the first court has jurisdiction and its law allows consolidation.
description.purpose: To prevent conflicting judgments, ensure judicial efficiency, and promote coordination between courts in cross-border data protection cases.
description.legislative_intent: Lawmakers intended to avoid duplicative or conflicting legal actions regarding the same data processing activities across Member States, ensuring coherent and efficient judicial outcomes.

what_it_covers: Judicial proceedings concerning the same subject matter
Cases involving the same data controller or processor
Cross-border legal actions within EU Member States

target_entities: Parties to proceedings involving data controllers or processors
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Within EU Member States

what_it_does_not_cover: Proceedings not involving the same subject matter
Cases not involving the same controller or processor
Non-judicial proceedings
Proceedings outside EU Member States

mandatory_obligations: A competent court must contact the court in another Member State to confirm the existence of parallel proceedings concerning the same subject matter and the same controller or processor.
conditional_requirements: Any competent court other than the court first seized may suspend its proceedings if parallel proceedings exist in another Member State.

Any court other than the court first seized may, on application of a party, decline jurisdiction if the court first seized has jurisdiction and its law permits consolidation, provided the proceedings are at first instance.

general_restrictions: Courts other than the court first seized are restricted from proceeding with cases if parallel proceedings exist and may be required to suspend or decline jurisdiction.
operational_restrictions: Courts must coordinate and may be required to suspend or decline jurisdiction in certain cross-border cases.
geographic_restrictions: Applies only to courts within EU Member States.

organizational_rights: Parties to proceedings may apply for a court to decline jurisdiction if the conditions are met.
how_to_exercise_rights: A party may submit an application to the court for it to decline jurisdiction if the proceedings are at first instance and the court first seized has jurisdiction and its law allows consolidation.

general_exceptions: Does not apply if proceedings do not concern the same subject matter or the same controller or processor.
conditional_exemptions: A court may decline jurisdiction only if the proceedings are at first instance, the court first seized has jurisdiction, and its law permits consolidation.

organizational_measures: Courts must establish procedures to identify and communicate with courts in other Member States regarding parallel proceedings.

enforcement.regulatory_authority: National courts of EU Member States
enforcement_mechanisms: Procedural enforcement by courts; decisions may be subject to appeal or review under national law.

implementation_steps: Establish internal court procedures for identifying parallel proceedings.
Ensure communication channels with courts in other Member States.
Train judicial staff on the requirements for suspension and declining jurisdiction.
Develop templates for contacting other courts and for parties to apply for jurisdiction to be declined.
common_violations: Failure to contact the court in another Member State to confirm parallel proceedings.
Proceeding with a case despite the existence of parallel proceedings in another Member State.
Refusing to suspend or decline jurisdiction when required.
best_practices: Promptly check for parallel proceedings in other Member States.
Maintain clear records of communications with other courts.
Inform parties of their right to apply for the court to decline jurisdiction.
compliance_checklist: Has the court checked for parallel proceedings in other Member States?
Has the court contacted the other court to confirm the existence of such proceedings?
Has the court considered suspension or declining jurisdiction where appropriate?
Are parties informed of their rights under this section?

key_definitions.competent court: A court that has the legal authority to hear a case.
key_definitions.Member State: A country that is a member of the European Union.
key_definitions.controller: The natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which, alone or jointly with others, determines the purposes and means of the processing of personal data.
key_definitions.processor: A natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which processes personal data on behalf of the controller.
key_definitions.court first seized: The court where proceedings were first initiated.

cleaned_regulations.regulation_name: General Data Protection Regulation (EU) 2016/679, Article 82 â€“ Right to compensation and liability

description.brief_summary: GDPR Article 82 provides individuals with the right to receive compensation from controllers or processors for damages suffered as a result of infringements of the Regulation, and sets out the liability framework for controllers and processors.
description.detailed_explanation: Article 82 of the GDPR establishes that any person who suffers material or non-material damage due to a violation of the Regulation has the right to compensation from the controller or processor responsible. Controllers are generally liable for damages caused by unlawful processing, while processors are liable only if they breach processor-specific obligations or act outside or against the controller's instructions. Exemption from liability is possible if the party proves it is not responsible for the event causing the damage. Where multiple parties are involved, each can be held liable for the entire damage to ensure effective compensation, but they may seek recourse from each other according to their share of responsibility. Claims must be brought before competent courts as specified in Article 79(2).
description.purpose: To ensure effective remedies and compensation for individuals whose data protection rights are infringed, and to clarify the liability of controllers and processors.
description.legislative_intent: To provide a clear and enforceable right to compensation for data subjects, promote accountability among controllers and processors, and facilitate access to justice in cases of data protection violations.

what_it_covers: Right to compensation for material or non-material damage
Liability of controllers for damage caused by processing
Liability of processors for damage caused by processing under specific conditions
Exemption from liability if not responsible
Joint and several liability among controllers and processors
Right of recourse among controllers and processors
Jurisdiction for court proceedings regarding compensation

entity_types: Any entity acting as controller or processor
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Entities established in the EU or processing data of individuals in the EU

what_it_does_not_cover: Compensation for damages not resulting from an infringement of the Regulation
Liability for parties proven not responsible for the event causing damage
Matters outside the scope of personal data processing as defined by the GDPR

mandatory_obligations: Controllers must compensate data subjects for damage caused by infringements of the Regulation.
Processors must compensate data subjects for damage if they breach processor-specific obligations or act outside/contrary to controller instructions.
Controllers and processors involved in the same processing are jointly and severally liable for the entire damage to ensure effective compensation.
Controllers or processors who paid full compensation may claim back from others involved according to their share of responsibility.
Court proceedings for compensation must be brought before competent courts as per Article 79(2).
prohibited_actions: Processors must not act outside or contrary to lawful instructions of the controller.
conditional_requirements: Processors are liable only if they breach obligations specifically directed to processors or act outside/contrary to controller instructions.
Controllers or processors are exempt from liability if they prove they are not responsible for the event causing the damage.
Right of recourse applies only after full compensation has been paid.

general_restrictions: Liability is limited to cases where the controller or processor is responsible for the event causing the damage.
operational_restrictions: Processors must operate within the lawful instructions of the controller.
geographic_restrictions: Court proceedings must be brought before courts competent under the law of the Member State referred to in Article 79(2).

individual_rights: Right to receive compensation for material or non-material damage resulting from an infringement of the Regulation.
organizational_rights: Right of recourse for controllers or processors who have paid full compensation to claim back from other responsible parties.
how_to_exercise_rights: Court proceedings for compensation must be brought before the competent courts as specified in Article 79(2) of the GDPR.

general_exceptions: Exemption from liability if the controller or processor proves it is not responsible for the event giving rise to the damage.
conditional_exemptions: Processor liability applies only if obligations specifically directed to processors are breached or if acting outside/contrary to controller instructions.

organizational_measures: Controllers and processors must have procedures to assess and demonstrate responsibility for events causing damage.

enforcement.regulatory_authority: National courts of EU Member States (as per Article 79(2)); Data Protection Authorities may also be involved in related enforcement.

penalties.financial_penalties: Obligation to pay full compensation for material or non-material damage suffered by data subjects.
penalties.reputational_consequences: Potential reputational damage due to court proceedings and public disclosure.

enforcement_mechanisms: Court proceedings initiated by data subjects for compensation.
Recourse actions among controllers and processors.

related_articles: GDPR Article 5 (Principles relating to processing of personal data)
GDPR Article 79 (Right to an effective judicial remedy against a controller or processor)

implementation_steps: Establish clear contractual arrangements between controllers and processors regarding liability.
Maintain records of processing activities and instructions.
Implement procedures for handling compensation claims.
Assess and document responsibility for any data protection incidents.
Ensure awareness of competent courts for legal proceedings.
common_violations: Failure to compensate data subjects for damages.
Processors acting outside or contrary to controller instructions.
Lack of clarity regarding responsibility among multiple controllers/processors.
Inability to prove exemption from liability.
best_practices: Clearly define roles and responsibilities in contracts.
Promptly investigate and document incidents.
Train staff on obligations and liability under GDPR.
Cooperate with other controllers/processors in joint processing activities.
compliance_checklist: Are compensation procedures in place?
Are roles and responsibilities clearly documented?
Is there a process to assess and prove (or disprove) responsibility for incidents?
Are contractual arrangements with processors compliant?
Is the process for recourse among parties established?

key_definitions.controller: The natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which, alone or jointly with others, determines the purposes and means of the processing of personal data.
key_definitions.processor: A natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which processes personal data on behalf of the controller.
key_definitions.material damage: Tangible harm suffered by a data subject as a result of a data protection infringement.
key_definitions.non-material damage: Intangible harm (such as distress or reputational harm) suffered by a data subject as a result of a data protection infringement.
key_definitions.joint and several liability: Legal doctrine whereby each liable party is individually responsible for the entire damage, allowing the data subject to claim full compensation from any one of them.

cleaned_regulations.regulation_name: General Data Protection Regulation (EU) 2016/679, Article 83 â€“ General conditions for imposing administrative fines

description.brief_summary: Article 83 of the GDPR sets out the general conditions and criteria for imposing administrative fines for infringements of the Regulation, including the principles, factors for assessment, maximum fine amounts, and procedural requirements.
description.detailed_explanation: This article mandates that supervisory authorities impose administrative fines that are effective, proportionate, and dissuasive for GDPR infringements. It specifies that fines may be imposed in addition to or instead of other corrective measures, and lists detailed criteria for determining whether to impose a fine and its amount. The article sets two tiers of maximum fines (10 million EUR/2% turnover and 20 million EUR/4% turnover) depending on the nature of the infringement. It also addresses the treatment of multiple infringements, the application to public authorities, procedural safeguards, and alternative enforcement mechanisms in Member States where administrative fines are not directly available.
description.purpose: To ensure consistent, effective, and fair enforcement of the GDPR through administrative fines that deter non-compliance and protect data subjectsâ€™ rights.
description.legislative_intent: Lawmakers intended to provide a harmonized, robust enforcement mechanism for data protection across the EU, ensuring that fines are not arbitrary but based on clear criteria and proportional to the infringement.

what_it_covers: Imposition of administrative fines for GDPR infringements
Criteria for determining fines
Maximum fine amounts for specific GDPR provisions
Procedural safeguards for enforcement
Notification obligations for Member States with alternative legal systems

target_entities: Public authorities and bodies (subject to Member State law)
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Entities established or operating in the EU, or processing personal data of individuals in the EU

what_it_does_not_cover: Criminal penalties (outside administrative fines)
Matters not related to GDPR infringements
Entities or activities outside the scope of GDPR

mandatory_obligations: Supervisory authorities MUST ensure fines are effective, proportionate, and dissuasive (Quote: 'shall in each individual case be effective, proportionate and dissuasive').
Fines MUST be imposed in accordance with the criteria listed in paragraph 2.
Due regard MUST be given to the factors listed in paragraph 2(a)-(k) when deciding on fines.
Fines for multiple infringements MUST NOT exceed the amount for the gravest infringement.
Fines for specified infringements (paragraphs 4, 5, 6) MUST NOT exceed the stated maximums.
Member States with alternative legal systems MUST notify the Commission of their laws by 25 May 2018 and any amendments.
prohibited_actions: Supervisory authorities MUST NOT impose fines exceeding the maximums specified for the gravest infringement in cases of multiple infringements.
Entities MUST NOT fail to comply with orders or measures imposed under Article 58(2).
conditional_requirements: Fines MAY be imposed in addition to or instead of other measures under Article 58(2)(a)-(h), (j).
Member States MAY lay down rules on fines for public authorities and bodies.
If a Member State does not provide for administrative fines, fines MAY be imposed by national courts upon initiation by the supervisory authority.
documentation_requirements: Member States with alternative legal systems MUST notify the Commission of their relevant laws and amendments.
reporting_requirements: Notification to the Commission by Member States regarding alternative enforcement mechanisms.
timeline_requirements: Notification to the Commission by 25 May 2018 for Member States with alternative legal systems.

general_restrictions: Fines MUST be effective, proportionate, and dissuasive.
Total fine for multiple infringements MUST NOT exceed the maximum for the gravest infringement.
data_restrictions: Assessment of fines MUST consider the categories of personal data affected.
operational_restrictions: Entities MUST comply with measures imposed under Article 58(2).
technical_restrictions: Degree of responsibility assessed includes technical and organisational measures implemented under Articles 25 and 32.
geographic_restrictions: Member States MAY set rules for public authorities and bodies established in their territory.

individual_rights: Right to effective judicial remedy and due process in enforcement proceedings.
organizational_rights: Right to procedural safeguards in accordance with Union and Member State law.
how_to_exercise_rights: Through judicial review and due process mechanisms as provided by law.

general_exceptions: Member States MAY determine whether and to what extent fines apply to public authorities and bodies.
conditional_exemptions: Where a Member State's legal system does not provide for administrative fines, fines MAY be imposed by national courts instead.
public_interest_exceptions: Public authorities and bodies MAY be exempted from fines as determined by Member State law.

technical_measures: Implementation of technical measures as required by Articles 25 and 32.
organizational_measures: Implementation of organisational measures as required by Articles 25 and 32.
Adherence to approved codes of conduct (Article 40) or certification mechanisms (Article 42).
security_measures: Implementation of security measures as required by Article 32.
certification_requirements: Adherence to approved certification mechanisms (Article 42) may be considered in fine assessment.

enforcement.regulatory_authority: Supervisory authorities designated under the GDPR in each Member State.

penalties.financial_penalties: Administrative fines up to 10,000,000 EUR or 2% of total worldwide annual turnover for certain infringements; up to 20,000,000 EUR or 4% of total worldwide annual turnover for others, whichever is higher.
penalties.administrative_penalties: Imposition of corrective measures under Article 58(2), including orders, limitations, or suspensions.
penalties.reputational_consequences: Potential public disclosure of enforcement actions and fines.

enforcement_mechanisms: Investigation and enforcement by supervisory authorities.
Initiation of fines by supervisory authorities and imposition by national courts in certain Member States.
Consideration of mitigating/aggravating factors in enforcement.

related_articles: Article 5 (Principles relating to processing of personal data)
Article 9 (Processing of special categories of personal data)

implementation_steps: Assess and document compliance with all GDPR obligations.
Implement technical and organisational measures as required.
Maintain records of processing activities.
Cooperate with supervisory authorities during investigations.
Notify supervisory authorities of relevant laws if operating in a Member State with alternative enforcement mechanisms.
Adhere to codes of conduct and certification mechanisms where applicable.
common_violations: Failure to implement adequate security measures.
Non-compliance with data subject rights.
Unlawful data transfers.
Failure to cooperate with supervisory authorities.
Non-compliance with orders under Article 58(2).
best_practices: Regularly review and update data protection policies.
Conduct data protection impact assessments.
Train staff on GDPR compliance.
Engage with certification and codes of conduct.
Promptly address and mitigate any data breaches.
compliance_checklist: Are all GDPR obligations being met?
Are technical and organisational measures in place?
Is there a process for cooperating with supervisory authorities?
Are records and documentation up to date?
Are codes of conduct/certifications adhered to where relevant?
Are public authorities/bodies aware of Member State-specific rules?

key_definitions.supervisory authority: An independent public authority established by a Member State pursuant to Article 51 of the GDPR.
key_definitions.controller: The natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which, alone or jointly with others, determines the purposes and means of the processing of personal data.
key_definitions.processor: A natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which processes personal data on behalf of the controller.
key_definitions.undertaking: An entity engaged in an economic activity, regardless of its legal form.
key_definitions.administrative fine: A monetary penalty imposed by a supervisory authority for infringement of the GDPR.

cleaned_regulations.source_section: ## General conditions for imposing administrative fines

cleaned_regulations.regulation_name: General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) Article 84 â€“ Penalties

industry_sectors: All sectors processing personal data within the EU

description.brief_summary: Article 84 of the GDPR requires Member States to establish penalties for infringements of the Regulation that are not subject to administrative fines under Article 83, ensuring these penalties are effective, proportionate, and dissuasive. It also obligates Member States to notify the European Commission of such legal provisions and any amendments.
description.detailed_explanation: This article addresses the need for Member States to fill any enforcement gaps left by Article 83, which covers administrative fines. For infringements not covered by Article 83, Member States must create their own penalty regimes. The penalties must be effective, proportionate, and dissuasive to ensure compliance with the Regulation. Furthermore, Member States are required to inform the European Commission of the laws they adopt in this regard by a specific deadline (25 May 2018) and to notify the Commission without delay of any subsequent changes to these laws.
description.purpose: To ensure that all infringements of the GDPR are subject to appropriate penalties, even when not covered by administrative fines, thereby strengthening enforcement and harmonization across the EU.
description.legislative_intent: Lawmakers intended to close enforcement gaps and ensure that all types of GDPR infringements are met with suitable penalties, and to maintain transparency and oversight by requiring notification to the European Commission.

what_it_covers: Establishment of penalties for GDPR infringements not subject to administrative fines under Article 83
Notification of penalty provisions and amendments to the European Commission

who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Within the territory of each EU Member State

what_it_does_not_cover: Infringements already subject to administrative fines under Article 83
Penalties outside the scope of the GDPR

mandatory_obligations: Member States SHALL lay down rules on penalties applicable to infringements of this Regulation not subject to administrative fines pursuant to Article 83
Member States SHALL take all measures necessary to ensure that such penalties are implemented
Penalties SHALL be effective, proportionate and dissuasive
Each Member State SHALL notify to the Commission the provisions of its law adopted pursuant to paragraph 1 by 25 May 2018
Each Member State SHALL notify without delay any subsequent amendment affecting such provisions
prohibited_actions: Failing to establish penalties for infringements not covered by Article 83
Failing to notify the Commission of penalty provisions or amendments
conditional_requirements: Notification of amendments is required only if and when amendments are made

reporting_requirements: Notification to the European Commission of adopted penalty provisions by 25 May 2018
Notification to the European Commission of any subsequent amendments without delay

Ongoing: Without delay for any subsequent amendments

general_restrictions: Penalties must not be ineffective, disproportionate, or non-dissuasive
operational_restrictions: Member States are restricted from leaving infringements unpenalized if not covered by Article 83
geographic_restrictions: Applies only within the jurisdiction of EU Member States

general_exceptions: Infringements already subject to administrative fines under Article 83 are excluded

organizational_measures: Establishment and implementation of national penalty regimes for GDPR infringements not covered by Article 83

enforcement.regulatory_authority: National authorities designated by each EU Member State; oversight by the European Commission regarding notification

penalties.financial_penalties: Determined by Member States for infringements not subject to Article 83; must be effective, proportionate, and dissuasive
penalties.administrative_penalties: Possible, depending on national law
penalties.reputational_consequences: Possible public disclosure of penalties or non-compliance

enforcement_mechanisms: European Commission oversight of notification and compliance

Ensure penalties are effective, proportionate, and dissuasive

Establish procedures to promptly notify the Commission of any amendments

key_definitions.Penalties: Sanctions or punishments imposed for violations of the GDPR, other than administrative fines under Article 83.

key_definitions.Member States: Countries that are members of the European Union.

cleaned_regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation), Article 85 â€“ Processing and freedom of expression and information

description.brief_summary: Article 85 of the GDPR requires EU Member States to reconcile data protection rights with freedom of expression and information, mandating exemptions or derogations for processing carried out for journalistic, academic, artistic, or literary purposes, and notification of such measures to the European Commission.
description.detailed_explanation: This article obliges Member States to ensure that their national laws balance the right to data protection with the right to freedom of expression and information. Specifically, it requires that, where processing is carried out for journalistic, academic, artistic, or literary purposes, Member States must provide for exemptions or derogations from certain GDPR provisions if necessary to reconcile these rights. The article also requires Member States to notify the European Commission of the relevant legal provisions and any amendments.
description.purpose: To ensure that the fundamental rights to data protection and freedom of expression/information are balanced, particularly in contexts such as journalism, academia, art, and literature.
description.legislative_intent: Lawmakers intended to prevent data protection laws from unduly restricting freedom of expression and information, especially in sectors where these freedoms are essential, by allowing Member States to create necessary exemptions or derogations.

what_it_covers: Reconciliation of data protection rights with freedom of expression and information
Processing of personal data for journalistic purposes
Processing of personal data for academic purposes
Processing of personal data for artistic purposes
Processing of personal data for literary purposes
Exemptions or derogations from GDPR Chapters II, III, IV, V, VI, VII, and IX

target_entities: Organizations and individuals engaged in journalistic, academic, artistic, or literary activities
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Entities operating within EU Member States

what_it_does_not_cover: Processing not related to journalistic, academic, artistic, or literary expression
Exemptions or derogations not necessary to reconcile data protection with freedom of expression/information

mandatory_obligations: Member States shall by law reconcile the right to the protection of personal data pursuant to this Regulation with the right to freedom of expression and information.

Member States shall provide for exemptions or derogations from GDPR Chapters II, III, IV, V, VI, VII, and IX for processing carried out for journalistic, academic, artistic, or literary purposes if necessary.
Each Member State shall notify to the Commission the provisions of its law adopted pursuant to paragraph 2 and, without delay, any subsequent amendment law or amendment affecting them.
prohibited_actions: Member States must not fail to provide necessary exemptions or derogations where required to reconcile rights.
conditional_requirements: Exemptions or derogations from GDPR chapters apply only if they are necessary to reconcile the right to data protection with freedom of expression and information.
documentation_requirements: Member States must document and notify the European Commission of the legal provisions and amendments adopted under this article.
reporting_requirements: Notification to the European Commission of adopted provisions and amendments.
timeline_requirements: Notification to the Commission must be made 'without delay' after adoption or amendment.

general_restrictions: Exemptions or derogations are limited to what is necessary to reconcile data protection with freedom of expression/information.
data_restrictions: Exemptions or derogations may apply to data processing principles, data subject rights, controller/processor obligations, data transfers, supervisory authorities, cooperation/consistency, and specific data processing situations, but only for journalistic, academic, artistic, or literary purposes.
operational_restrictions: Exemptions or derogations cannot be broader than necessary.
geographic_restrictions: Applies only within EU Member States

individual_rights: Right to freedom of expression and information
Right to protection of personal data
organizational_rights: Right to process personal data for journalistic, academic, artistic, or literary purposes under national exemptions or derogations
how_to_exercise_rights: Through national laws providing for exemptions or derogations as notified to the European Commission

general_exceptions: Exemptions or derogations from GDPR Chapters II, III, IV, V, VI, VII, and IX for processing for journalistic, academic, artistic, or literary purposes
conditional_exemptions: Exemptions or derogations apply only if necessary to reconcile data protection with freedom of expression/information

organizational_measures: Member States must establish legal frameworks for exemptions or derogations

enforcement.regulatory_authority: National supervisory authorities in each Member State; European Commission (for notification purposes)

related_articles: GDPR Chapter III (Rights of the data subject)
GDPR Chapter V (Transfers of personal data to third countries or international organisations)
GDPR Chapter IX (Specific data processing situations)

implementation_steps: Review national laws to ensure reconciliation of data protection and freedom of expression/information.
Draft and adopt legal provisions for necessary exemptions or derogations.
Notify the European Commission of adopted provisions and any amendments.
Ensure that exemptions or derogations are limited to what is necessary.
common_violations: Failure to provide necessary exemptions or derogations.
Overly broad or insufficiently justified exemptions.
Failure to notify the European Commission of adopted provisions or amendments.
best_practices: Conduct impact assessments to determine necessity of exemptions.
Consult with stakeholders in journalism, academia, arts, and literature.
Maintain clear documentation of legal provisions and notifications.
compliance_checklist: Are national laws in place to reconcile data protection and freedom of expression/information?
Do exemptions/derogations apply only where necessary?
Have all relevant provisions and amendments been notified to the European Commission?
Are the exemptions/derogations limited to the specified GDPR chapters?

key_definitions.processing: Any operation or set of operations which is performed on personal data or on sets of personal data, whether or not by automated means.
key_definitions.journalistic purposes: Processing of personal data for the purpose of journalism, including news reporting and media activities.
key_definitions.exemption: A provision that releases an entity from a legal requirement under specified conditions.
key_definitions.derogation: A partial suppression or relaxation of a law or regulation under specific circumstances.

cleaned_regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation), Article 86

industry_sectors: Private Sector (when performing public interest tasks)

description.brief_summary: Article 86 of the GDPR governs the processing and public access to official documents containing personal data, requiring that such disclosure be reconciled with data protection rights and be in accordance with Union or Member State law.
description.detailed_explanation: This regulation allows public authorities, public bodies, and private bodies performing tasks in the public interest to disclose personal data contained in official documents, but only if such disclosure is permitted by Union or Member State law. The regulation seeks to balance the public's right to access official documents with the individual's right to data protection as established by the GDPR. The provision recognizes that transparency and access to information are important public interests but must be reconciled with privacy rights.
description.purpose: To ensure that the disclosure of personal data in official documents for public access is conducted lawfully and in a manner that balances transparency with data protection.
description.legislative_intent: Lawmakers intended to provide a legal basis for public access to official documents while safeguarding the fundamental right to personal data protection, allowing Member States to legislate the reconciliation of these interests.

what_it_covers: Disclosure of personal data in official documents
Processing of personal data by public authorities and bodies
Processing by private bodies performing public interest tasks
Reconciliation of public access and data protection rights

target_entities: Private bodies performing public interest tasks
entity_types: Private companies (when acting in public interest)
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Entities subject to Union or Member State law

what_it_does_not_cover: Disclosure not permitted by Union or Member State law
Processing by private entities not performing public interest tasks
Documents not held by public authorities or bodies

mandatory_obligations: Disclosure of personal data in official documents must be in accordance with Union or Member State law
Disclosure must reconcile public access with the right to data protection pursuant to the GDPR
prohibited_actions: Disclosure of personal data in official documents outside the scope of Union or Member State law
Disclosure that does not consider the right to data protection
conditional_requirements: Disclosure is permitted only if it is for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest
Disclosure must be subject to the specific laws applicable to the public authority or body

general_restrictions: Disclosure is restricted to what is allowed under Union or Member State law
data_restrictions: Personal data may only be disclosed if it is necessary to reconcile public access with data protection rights
operational_restrictions: Disclosure must be for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest
geographic_restrictions: Applies only within the jurisdiction of the Union or relevant Member State

individual_rights: Right to protection of personal data pursuant to the GDPR
organizational_rights: Right of public authorities and bodies to disclose personal data in official documents, subject to law
how_to_exercise_rights: Individuals may challenge unlawful disclosure under GDPR complaint mechanisms
Organizations must follow applicable Union or Member State law for disclosure

general_exceptions: Disclosure not permitted if not in accordance with Union or Member State law
conditional_exemptions: Member States may provide specific exemptions or conditions for disclosure in their national laws
public_interest_exceptions: Disclosure is permitted for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest

penalties.administrative_penalties: Orders to cease unlawful processing, corrective orders

Ensure reconciliation of public access and data protection rights in each disclosure

Failing to consider data protection rights when granting access to official documents
best_practices: Consult legal counsel before disclosing personal data in official documents
Document the legal basis for each disclosure
Train staff on the intersection of data protection and public access laws
compliance_checklist: Is the disclosure permitted by Union or Member State law?
Is the disclosure necessary for a task in the public interest?
Have data protection rights been considered and reconciled?
Are procedures in place to document and review disclosures?

key_definitions.personal data: Any information relating to an identified or identifiable natural person
key_definitions.official documents: Documents held by a public authority or body in the course of its official duties
key_definitions.public authority: A government or administrative body subject to Union or Member State law
key_definitions.public interest: Tasks or activities carried out for the benefit of the general public

cleaned_regulations.regulation_name: General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) Article 87 â€“ Processing of the national identification number

industry_sectors: All sectors processing personal data, including public sector, private sector, financial services, healthcare, telecommunications, education, government

description.brief_summary: This article allows EU Member States to set specific conditions for processing national identification numbers or similar identifiers, provided that such processing is subject to appropriate safeguards for data subjectsâ€™ rights and freedoms under the GDPR.
description.detailed_explanation: GDPR Article 87 recognizes that national identification numbers and other general identifiers are particularly sensitive and may require additional protection. It grants Member States the authority to establish specific rules or conditions for processing these identifiers. However, any such processing must always be accompanied by safeguards that protect the rights and freedoms of the data subject, as required by the GDPR. The article ensures a harmonized baseline of protection while allowing for national variations in the handling of identifiers.
description.purpose: To protect individuals from misuse of national identification numbers and similar identifiers by ensuring their processing is subject to both national rules and GDPR safeguards.
description.legislative_intent: To balance the need for national flexibility in handling sensitive identifiers with the overarching requirement to protect data subjectsâ€™ rights and freedoms under EU law.

Processing of any other identifier of general application
Setting of specific national conditions for such processing
Requirement for appropriate safeguards for data subjects

what_it_does_not_cover: Processing of identifiers not of general application
Processing outside the scope of GDPR or outside EU/EEA jurisdiction

mandatory_obligations: Member States MAY determine specific conditions for processing national identification numbers or other general identifiers
National identification numbers or other general identifiers SHALL be used only under appropriate safeguards for the rights and freedoms of the data subject pursuant to the GDPR
prohibited_actions: Processing national identification numbers or other general identifiers without appropriate safeguards

data_restrictions: Identifiers of general application must be processed in accordance with safeguards for data subjectsâ€™ rights and freedoms

organizational_measures: Implement appropriate safeguards for processing national identification numbers or general identifiers
security_measures: Safeguards must protect the rights and freedoms of data subjects

penalties.administrative_penalties: Orders to cease processing, corrective orders, warnings, reprimands
penalties.reputational_consequences: Public disclosure of infringements by DPAs

cleaned_regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation), Article 88 â€“ Processing in the context of employment

industry_sectors: All sectors employing individuals within the EU

description.brief_summary: Article 88 of the GDPR permits EU Member States to introduce more specific rules regarding the processing of employees' personal data in the employment context, provided these rules safeguard employees' rights and freedoms.
description.detailed_explanation: This article recognizes the need for tailored data protection rules in the employment context due to the unique nature of employer-employee relationships. It allows Member States to legislate or use collective agreements to set more specific requirements for processing employees' personal data, especially for recruitment, contract performance, legal obligations, workplace management, equality, diversity, health and safety, property protection, exercise of employment rights, and termination. Such rules must include suitable and specific measures to protect human dignity, legitimate interests, and fundamental rights, with a focus on transparency, intra-group data transfers, and workplace monitoring. Member States must notify the European Commission of these rules and any amendments by 25 May 2018 or without delay thereafter.
description.purpose: To ensure that employees' personal data is processed in a manner that protects their rights and freedoms, taking into account the specificities of the employment relationship.
description.legislative_intent: To provide flexibility for Member States to address national employment practices and legal frameworks while maintaining a high standard of data protection for employees.

what_it_covers: Processing of employees' personal data in the context of employment
Recruitment
Performance of the contract of employment
Discharge of obligations laid down by law or collective agreements
Management, planning, and organisation of work
Equality and diversity in the workplace
Health and safety at work
Protection of employer's or customer's property
Exercise and enjoyment of rights and benefits related to employment
Termination of the employment relationship

who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Entities operating within EU Member States

what_it_does_not_cover: Processing of personal data outside the context of employment
Processing not related to the listed employment purposes

mandatory_obligations: Member States may provide more specific rules by law or collective agreements for processing employees' personal data.
Such rules must include suitable and specific measures to safeguard the data subject's human dignity, legitimate interests, and fundamental rights.

Particular regard must be given to transparency of processing, transfer of personal data within a group of undertakings or enterprises engaged in a joint economic activity, and monitoring systems at the workplace.
Each Member State shall notify to the Commission those provisions of its law which it adopts pursuant to paragraph 1, by 25 May 2018 and, without delay, any subsequent amendment affecting them.
conditional_requirements: Rules may be provided by law or by collective agreements.
Notification to the Commission is required only for provisions adopted pursuant to paragraph 1.
documentation_requirements: Member States must document and notify the Commission of the relevant legal provisions and any amendments.
reporting_requirements: Notification to the European Commission of adopted provisions and amendments.
timeline_requirements: Notification to the Commission by 25 May 2018 for initial provisions.
Notification to the Commission without delay for any subsequent amendments.

general_restrictions: Any specific rules must safeguard human dignity, legitimate interests, and fundamental rights.
data_restrictions: Particular regard must be given to transparency of processing.
Restrictions on transfer of personal data within groups of undertakings or enterprises engaged in joint economic activity.
Restrictions on monitoring systems at the workplace.
operational_restrictions: Rules must address management, planning, and organisation of work in a manner that protects employee rights.
geographic_restrictions: Applies only within EU Member States.

individual_rights: Right to protection of personal data in the employment context.
Right to human dignity, legitimate interests, and fundamental rights in relation to data processing.
Right to transparency regarding processing of personal data.
Rights regarding monitoring systems at the workplace.

By seeking redress under GDPR or national data protection authorities if rights are infringed.

organizational_measures: Implementation of suitable and specific measures to safeguard data subject's rights, especially regarding transparency, intra-group data transfers, and workplace monitoring.

enforcement.regulatory_authority: National Data Protection Authorities in each EU Member State; European Commission (for notification purposes)
enforcement_mechanisms: Oversight by national data protection authorities
European Commission monitoring of Member State notifications

dates.compliance_deadline: 25 May 2018 (for initial notification); without delay for subsequent amendments

related_articles: GDPR Article 9 (Processing of special categories of personal data)
GDPR Article 88 (Processing in the context of employment)
complementary_regulations: National data protection laws implementing GDPR
Collective agreements as recognized by national law

Implement suitable and specific measures to safeguard employee rights, focusing on transparency, intra-group transfers, and workplace monitoring.
Notify the European Commission of any such provisions and amendments.
common_violations: Failure to implement specific safeguards for employee data.
Lack of transparency in processing employee data.
Failure to notify the Commission of relevant national provisions.
best_practices: Engage with employee representatives when drafting data processing rules.
Ensure clear documentation and communication of data processing practices to employees.
Regularly review and update policies in line with national and EU requirements.

Do these rules include suitable and specific safeguards for employee rights?

key_definitions.processing: Any operation or set of operations which is performed on personal data or on sets of personal data, whether or not by automated means.
key_definitions.personal data: Any information relating to an identified or identifiable natural person.
key_definitions.collective agreement: An agreement between employers and employees (or their representatives) concerning working conditions and terms of employment.
key_definitions.data subject: An identified or identifiable natural person whose personal data is processed.

cleaned_regulations.regulation_name: General Data Protection Regulation (EU) 2016/679, Article 89: Safeguards and derogations relating to processing for archiving purposes in the public interest, scientific or historical research purposes or statistical purposes

industry_sectors: Any organization processing data for these purposes

description.brief_summary: Article 89 of the GDPR establishes the conditions, safeguards, and possible derogations for processing personal data for archiving in the public interest, scientific or historical research, or statistical purposes, including requirements for technical and organizational measures and the possibility to restrict certain data subject rights.
description.detailed_explanation: This article requires that processing of personal data for archiving in the public interest, scientific or historical research, or statistical purposes must be subject to appropriate safeguards for the rights and freedoms of data subjects, in accordance with the GDPR. These safeguards must include technical and organizational measures, particularly to ensure data minimization. Pseudonymisation is suggested as one such measure, provided the purposes can be fulfilled in that manner. Where the purposes can be achieved without identifying data subjects, processing must be done in a way that does not permit identification. The article allows Union or Member State law to provide for derogations from certain data subject rights (Articles 15, 16, 18, 19, 20, and 21) if exercising those rights would render impossible or seriously impair the achievement of the purposes, and only if such derogations are necessary and subject to safeguards. Derogations only apply to processing for these specific purposes, not for other concurrent purposes.
description.purpose: To balance the need for processing personal data for important public, scientific, historical, or statistical purposes with the protection of data subject rights, by requiring safeguards and allowing limited derogations where strictly necessary.
description.legislative_intent: Lawmakers intended to enable and facilitate research, archiving, and statistical activities that serve the public interest, while ensuring that data subject rights are not unduly compromised and that appropriate safeguards are always in place.

what_it_covers: Processing of personal data for archiving purposes in the public interest
Processing for scientific research purposes
Processing for historical research purposes
Processing for statistical purposes

target_entities: Any data controllers/processors engaged in such processing
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Entities established in the EU or processing data of data subjects in the EU

what_it_does_not_cover: Processing for purposes other than archiving in the public interest, scientific or historical research, or statistical purposes
Processing not subject to Union or Member State law providing for derogations

mandatory_obligations: Implement appropriate safeguards for the rights and freedoms of data subjects
Ensure technical and organizational measures are in place, particularly to ensure data minimisation
Fulfill purposes by processing that does not permit identification of data subjects where possible
Apply pseudonymisation where purposes can be fulfilled in that manner
prohibited_actions: Do not process personal data in a manner that identifies data subjects if the purposes can be fulfilled without such identification
conditional_requirements: Derogations from data subject rights may only be provided by Union or Member State law
Derogations must be subject to the conditions and safeguards referred to in paragraph 1
Derogations apply only if rights are likely to render impossible or seriously impair the achievement of the specific purposes and are necessary for the fulfilment of those purposes
Derogations apply only to processing for the specified purposes, not for other concurrent purposes

general_restrictions: Derogations from data subject rights are limited to what is necessary for the specific purposes
Derogations only apply to processing for archiving, scientific, historical, or statistical purposes

Processing should not permit identification of data subjects if not necessary

Right to erasure (Article 17, not explicitly mentioned in this section)
Right to notification (Article 19)
Right to data portability (Article 20)
