general_exceptions: Derogations from data subject rights apply only if exercising those rights would render impossible or seriously impair the achievement of the specific purposes and are necessary for the fulfilment of those purposes
conditional_exemptions: Derogations are subject to the conditions and safeguards referred to in paragraph 1
public_interest_exceptions: Processing for archiving purposes in the public interest may be subject to derogations

technical_measures: Pseudonymisation where possible
Other technical measures to ensure data minimisation
organizational_measures: Organizational measures to ensure respect for data minimisation and other safeguards
security_measures: Appropriate safeguards for the rights and freedoms of data subjects

enforcement.regulatory_authority: Supervisory authorities designated under GDPR in each Member State

penalties.financial_penalties: Administrative fines as per GDPR Article 83 (up to â‚¬20 million or 4% of annual global turnover, whichever is higher, depending on the infringement)
penalties.administrative_penalties: Orders to cease processing, corrective orders, reprimands
penalties.reputational_consequences: Public disclosure of infringements, possible reputational damage

related_articles: Article 5 (Principles relating to processing of personal data)
Article 9 (Processing of special categories of personal data)
Articles 15, 16, 18, 19, 20, 21 (Data subject rights referenced for derogations)
complementary_regulations: National data protection laws implementing GDPR derogations

implementation_steps: Identify processing activities for archiving, scientific, historical, or statistical purposes
Assess necessity for derogations from data subject rights
Implement technical and organizational safeguards (e.g., pseudonymisation, data minimisation)
Document justification for any derogations applied
Ensure derogations are only applied to relevant processing activities
Monitor compliance with safeguards and derogations
common_violations: Failure to implement adequate safeguards
Applying derogations without legal basis
Processing data in identifiable form when not necessary
Applying derogations to processing for other purposes
best_practices: Use pseudonymisation and anonymisation wherever possible
Regularly review necessity and proportionality of derogations
Maintain clear documentation of safeguards and justifications
Train staff on specific requirements for research/statistical processing
compliance_checklist: Are appropriate technical and organizational safeguards in place?
Is data minimisation ensured?
Are derogations only applied where strictly necessary and legally permitted?
Is processing for other purposes excluded from derogations?
Is documentation maintained for all decisions and safeguards?

key_definitions.pseudonymisation: The processing of personal data in such a manner that the personal data can no longer be attributed to a specific data subject without the use of additional information, provided that such additional information is kept separately and is subject to technical and organisational measures.
key_definitions.data minimisation: The principle that personal data must be adequate, relevant and limited to what is necessary in relation to the purposes for which they are processed.
key_definitions.derogation: A partial suppression of a law or regulation; in this context, an exception to certain data subject rights under specific conditions.

cleaned_regulations.source_section: ## Safeguards and derogations relating to processing for archiving purposes in the public interest, scientific or historical research purposes or statistical purposes

cleaned_regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation), Article 54(2) â€“ Rules on the establishment of supervisory authorities

industry_sectors: Any sector with professional secrecy obligations

description.brief_summary: This regulation allows EU Member States to adopt specific rules governing the powers of supervisory authorities over controllers or processors subject to professional secrecy, provided such rules are necessary and proportionate to reconcile data protection rights with secrecy obligations.
description.detailed_explanation: Member States may establish specific rules that define how supervisory authorities can exercise their powers (as set out in Article 58(1)(e) and (f) of the GDPR) over data controllers or processors who are bound by professional secrecy or equivalent obligations under Union or Member State law, or by rules from national competent bodies. These rules must be necessary and proportionate to balance the right to data protection with the obligation of secrecy. The rules only apply to personal data obtained in the course of activities covered by the secrecy obligation. Member States must notify the European Commission of these rules by 25 May 2018 and promptly notify any subsequent amendments.
description.purpose: To ensure that the exercise of supervisory authority powers does not unjustifiably infringe on professional secrecy, while still upholding data protection rights.
description.legislative_intent: To provide a mechanism for Member States to reconcile the enforcement of data protection laws with existing legal obligations of professional secrecy, ensuring both are respected and balanced.

what_it_covers: Adoption of specific rules by Member States regarding supervisory authority powers
Controllers or processors subject to professional secrecy or equivalent obligations
Personal data received or obtained in activities covered by secrecy obligations

who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Entities operating within EU Member States

what_it_does_not_cover: Personal data not obtained in the context of activities covered by secrecy obligations
Entities not subject to professional secrecy or equivalent obligations

mandatory_obligations: Member States MAY adopt specific rules regarding supervisory authority powers over entities bound by secrecy obligations, where necessary and proportionate.
Such rules SHALL apply only to personal data obtained in activities covered by secrecy obligations.
Each Member State SHALL notify the Commission of rules adopted pursuant to this section by 25 May 2018.
Member States SHALL notify the Commission without delay of any subsequent amendments affecting these rules.
prohibited_actions: Applying adopted rules to personal data not obtained in the context of secrecy obligations
conditional_requirements: Adoption of rules is permitted only where necessary and proportionate to reconcile data protection rights with secrecy obligations.
documentation_requirements: Documentation of rules adopted under this section
Documentation of amendments to such rules
reporting_requirements: Notification to the European Commission of adopted rules by 25 May 2018
Notification to the European Commission of any subsequent amendments without delay
timeline_requirements: Initial notification deadline: 25 May 2018
Ongoing: Notification of amendments without delay

general_restrictions: Rules adopted by Member States must be necessary and proportionate to reconcile data protection rights with secrecy obligations.
data_restrictions: Rules apply only to personal data received or obtained in activities covered by secrecy obligations.
operational_restrictions: Supervisory authority powers may be limited by Member State rules in the context of professional secrecy.
geographic_restrictions: Rules apply within the jurisdiction of the adopting Member State

individual_rights: Right to protection of personal data, balanced with secrecy obligations
organizational_rights: Right for controllers/processors to have secrecy obligations considered in supervisory authority actions
how_to_exercise_rights: Through the application of Member State rules adopted under this section

general_exceptions: Rules do not apply to personal data not obtained in the context of secrecy obligations
conditional_exemptions: Rules may only be adopted where necessary and proportionate

organizational_measures: Establish procedures for identifying data covered by secrecy obligations
Implement processes for notification to the Commission

enforcement.regulatory_authority: Supervisory authorities designated under GDPR in each Member State; European Commission (for notification compliance)
enforcement_mechanisms: Monitoring of Member State compliance with notification requirements by the European Commission

dates.compliance_deadline: 25 May 2018 (for initial notification); ongoing for amendments

complementary_regulations: Sector-specific EU or Member State laws

implementation_steps: Identify controllers/processors subject to secrecy obligations
Draft and adopt necessary and proportionate rules if required
Ensure rules only apply to relevant personal data
Notify the European Commission of adopted rules by the deadline
Establish process for prompt notification of amendments
common_violations: Failure to notify the Commission of adopted rules or amendments
Applying rules to data not covered by secrecy obligations
Adopting rules that are not necessary or proportionate
best_practices: Maintain clear documentation of all rules and amendments
Regularly review the necessity and proportionality of adopted rules
Train staff on the scope and application of secrecy-related rules
compliance_checklist: Have all relevant rules been adopted and documented?
Was the Commission notified by 25 May 2018?
Are all amendments promptly notified?
Do rules only apply to data obtained under secrecy obligations?
Are rules necessary and proportionate?

key_definitions.professional secrecy: A legal obligation for certain professionals (e.g., lawyers, doctors, bankers) to keep information obtained in the course of their work confidential.
key_definitions.supervisory authority: An independent public authority established by a Member State under Article 51 of the GDPR, responsible for monitoring the application of the GDPR.
key_definitions.controller: The natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which, alone or jointly with others, determines the purposes and means of the processing of personal data.
key_definitions.processor: A natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which processes personal data on behalf of the controller.

cleaned_regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation), Article 91 â€“ Existing data protection rules of churches and religious associations

description.brief_summary: Allows churches and religious associations in EU Member States to continue applying their own comprehensive data protection rules if these are aligned with the GDPR, and requires their supervision by an independent authority.
description.detailed_explanation: Article 91 of the GDPR recognizes that, at the time the GDPR enters into force, some churches and religious associations or communities in EU Member States may already have comprehensive rules for the protection of natural persons regarding data processing. These rules may continue to be applied, provided they are brought into compliance with the GDPR. Furthermore, such churches and religious associations must be supervised by an independent supervisory authority, which may be a specific authority for the religious entity, as long as it meets the requirements set out in Chapter VI of the GDPR (regarding independence, powers, and tasks of supervisory authorities).
description.purpose: To respect the autonomy of churches and religious associations with existing comprehensive data protection frameworks, while ensuring alignment with the GDPR and effective oversight.
description.legislative_intent: To provide continuity for established data protection regimes within religious entities, provided they meet GDPR standards, and to ensure these entities are subject to appropriate independent supervision.

what_it_covers: Continued application of existing comprehensive data protection rules by churches and religious associations or communities
Requirement for alignment of such rules with the GDPR
Supervision of these entities by an independent supervisory authority

who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Entities established in EU Member States

what_it_does_not_cover: Entities without comprehensive data protection rules at the time of GDPR entry into force
Non-religious organizations
Churches and religious associations outside the EU

mandatory_obligations: Existing comprehensive data protection rules must be brought into line with the GDPR
Churches and religious associations must be subject to supervision by an independent supervisory authority
The supervisory authority may be specific to the religious entity but must fulfill the conditions of Chapter VI of the GDPR
prohibited_actions: Applying existing data protection rules that are not aligned with the GDPR
conditional_requirements: Existing rules may continue to apply only if they are comprehensive and brought into line with the GDPR
timeline_requirements: Alignment with the GDPR required as of the entry into force of the Regulation

general_restrictions: Continued application of existing rules is restricted to those that are comprehensive and aligned with the GDPR
data_restrictions: Data processing must comply with GDPR-aligned rules
operational_restrictions: Supervision must be by an independent authority meeting GDPR Chapter VI requirements
geographic_restrictions: Applies only within EU Member States

organizational_rights: Right for churches and religious associations to continue applying their own comprehensive data protection rules, subject to alignment with the GDPR

general_exceptions: Non-comprehensive or non-aligned data protection rules cannot continue to apply
conditional_exemptions: Churches and religious associations may have a specific supervisory authority, provided it fulfills Chapter VI conditions

organizational_measures: Establish or maintain comprehensive data protection rules aligned with the GDPR
Ensure supervision by an independent authority meeting GDPR Chapter VI

enforcement.regulatory_authority: Independent supervisory authority (may be specific to the religious entity, must fulfill GDPR Chapter VI)
enforcement_mechanisms: Supervision by an independent authority as per GDPR Chapter VI

dates.compliance_deadline: At the time of entry into force of the GDPR (25 May 2018)

related_articles: GDPR Chapter VI (Articles 51-59) â€“ Supervisory Authorities

implementation_steps: Review existing data protection rules for comprehensiveness
Align existing rules with GDPR requirements
Establish or confirm supervision by an independent authority meeting Chapter VI criteria
common_violations: Failure to align existing rules with GDPR
Lack of independent supervisory authority or non-compliance with Chapter VI
best_practices: Conduct a gap analysis between existing rules and GDPR
Engage with supervisory authorities early to ensure compliance
compliance_checklist: Are existing rules comprehensive?
Are they aligned with GDPR?
Is there an independent supervisory authority?
Does the authority meet Chapter VI requirements?

key_definitions.comprehensive rules: Rules that cover all aspects of data protection for natural persons with regard to processing
key_definitions.independent supervisory authority: A body established to monitor the application of data protection law, which acts with complete independence and fulfills the requirements of GDPR Chapter VI

cleaned_regulations.source_section: ## Existing data protection rules of churches and religious associations

cleaned_regulations.regulation_id: Article on Exercise of Delegation (referenced in Article 12(8) and Article 43(8))
cleaned_regulations.regulation_name: Rules on the Exercise of Delegated Powers by the European Commission

industry_sectors: All sectors subject to EU law

description.brief_summary: This regulation governs the conditions and procedures under which the European Commission may exercise delegated powers to adopt delegated acts, including the duration, revocation, notification, and entry into force of such acts.
description.detailed_explanation: The section sets out the legal framework for the Commission's exercise of delegated powers as referred to in Article 12(8) and Article 43(8). It specifies that the power is conferred on the Commission subject to the conditions in this article, is granted for an indeterminate period from 24 May 2016, and may be revoked at any time by the European Parliament or the Council. Revocation takes effect the day after publication in the Official Journal or a later specified date and does not affect the validity of already adopted acts. The Commission must notify the European Parliament and the Council as soon as it adopts a delegated act. Such acts only enter into force if neither institution objects within three months of notification, with a possible three-month extension.
description.purpose: To ensure transparent, accountable, and controlled exercise of delegated legislative powers by the European Commission, with oversight by the European Parliament and the Council.
description.legislative_intent: To provide a clear, legally binding process for the adoption, oversight, and potential revocation of delegated acts by the Commission, safeguarding institutional balance and democratic control.

what_it_covers: Adoption of delegated acts by the European Commission
Conditions for exercise of delegated powers
Duration of delegation
Revocation of delegation
Notification of adopted acts
Entry into force of delegated acts
Objection period and process

who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: European Union

what_it_does_not_cover: Substantive content of delegated acts
Procedures for adoption of non-delegated acts
Delegations outside Article 12(8) and Article 43(8)

mandatory_obligations: The Commission must exercise delegated powers only under the conditions laid down in this Article.
Delegation of power is conferred for an indeterminate period from 24 May 2016.
The Commission must notify the European Parliament and the Council simultaneously as soon as it adopts a delegated act.
prohibited_actions: The Commission must not exercise delegated powers outside the conditions of this Article.
The Commission must not bring a delegated act into force if an objection is raised by either the European Parliament or the Council within the objection period.
conditional_requirements: Delegated acts enter into force only if no objection is expressed by either the European Parliament or the Council within three months of notification, or if both institutions inform the Commission that they will not object before the expiry of that period.
The three-month objection period may be extended by three months at the initiative of the European Parliament or the Council.
documentation_requirements: Publication of revocation decisions in the Official Journal of the European Union.
reporting_requirements: Notification of adopted delegated acts to the European Parliament and the Council.
timeline_requirements: Delegation is effective from 24 May 2016 for an indeterminate period.
Objection period for delegated acts is three months from notification, extendable by three months.
Revocation takes effect the day after publication in the Official Journal or at a later specified date.

general_restrictions: Delegated powers may be revoked at any time by the European Parliament or the Council.
operational_restrictions: Delegated acts cannot enter into force if an objection is raised within the objection period.

organizational_rights: The European Parliament and the Council have the right to revoke the delegation of power at any time.
The European Parliament and the Council have the right to object to delegated acts within the specified period.
how_to_exercise_rights: Revocation is exercised by decision and published in the Official Journal.
Objection is exercised by notification to the Commission within the objection period.

general_exceptions: Revocation does not affect the validity of delegated acts already in force.

organizational_measures: Establish procedures for timely notification of adopted delegated acts.
Maintain records of revocation decisions and notifications.

enforcement.regulatory_authority: European Parliament and Council of the European Union

penalties.administrative_penalties: Revocation of delegation of power; prevention of entry into force of delegated acts.
penalties.reputational_consequences: Publication of revocation decisions in the Official Journal.

enforcement_mechanisms: Monitoring of Commission notifications by the European Parliament and the Council.

implementation_steps: Ensure Commission staff are aware of notification and objection procedures.
Monitor Official Journal for revocation decisions.
Track objection periods for each delegated act.
common_violations: Failure to notify the European Parliament and the Council upon adoption of a delegated act.
Bringing a delegated act into force before the objection period expires or despite an objection.
best_practices: Maintain clear records of all notifications and objections.
Establish internal deadlines to ensure timely compliance with notification and objection periods.
compliance_checklist: Was the delegated act notified to both the European Parliament and the Council?
Has the objection period expired without objection?
Was any revocation decision published and properly implemented?

key_definitions.delegated act: A non-legislative act adopted by the European Commission under powers delegated to it by the European Parliament and the Council, as specified in a legislative act.
key_definitions.revocation: The act of withdrawing the delegation of power from the Commission by the European Parliament or the Council.
key_definitions.objection period: The period (three months, extendable by three months) during which the European Parliament or the Council may object to a delegated act after notification.

cleaned_regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) No 182/2011 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 16 February 2011 laying down the rules and general principles concerning mechanisms for control by Member States of the Commissionâ€™s exercise of implementing powers

industry_sectors: All sectors subject to EU law

description.brief_summary: Regulation (EU) No 182/2011 sets out the procedures by which committees assist the European Commission in exercising implementing powers, including the advisory and examination procedures and the scrutiny procedure for certain acts.
description.detailed_explanation: Regulation (EU) No 182/2011 establishes the framework for how Member States control the Commissionâ€™s exercise of implementing powers through committees. It defines the types of committees, their composition, and the procedures (advisory, examination, and scrutiny) under which they operate. Article 5 details the examination procedure, which is used for most implementing acts, requiring a qualified majority of Member States to approve or reject a draft measure. Article 8, in conjunction with Article 5, sets out the scrutiny procedure, which applies to certain sensitive areas and allows the European Parliament and Council to object to draft implementing acts. The regulation ensures transparency, accountability, and Member State involvement in the adoption of implementing acts by the Commission.
description.purpose: To provide a clear, uniform, and transparent mechanism for Member States to oversee and control the Commissionâ€™s exercise of implementing powers via committees.
description.legislative_intent: To harmonize and clarify the procedures for committee involvement in the adoption of implementing acts, ensuring democratic oversight and effective participation of Member States in the EU legislative process.

what_it_covers: Procedures for committee assistance to the Commission
Examination procedure for implementing acts (Article 5)
Scrutiny procedure for implementing acts (Article 8 in conjunction with Article 5)
Definition and operation of committees within the meaning of Regulation (EU) No 182/2011

target_entities: Committees composed of Member State representatives
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: EU Member States

what_it_does_not_cover: Procedures outside the scope of implementing acts
Non-EU jurisdictions
Legislative acts (as opposed to implementing acts)

mandatory_obligations: The Commission must be assisted by a committee as defined in Regulation (EU) No 182/2011.
Where reference is made to the relevant paragraph, Article 5 (examination procedure) must be applied.
Where reference is made to the relevant paragraph, Article 8 (scrutiny procedure), in conjunction with Article 5, must be applied.
prohibited_actions: The Commission must not adopt implementing acts outside the procedures set by Regulation (EU) No 182/2011 when committee procedure is required.
conditional_requirements: Application of Article 5 or Article 8 is conditional upon explicit reference in the legal act.
documentation_requirements: Records of committee proceedings as required by Regulation (EU) No 182/2011.
Draft implementing acts and voting records.
reporting_requirements: Notification of draft implementing acts to the committee and, where applicable, to the European Parliament and Council.
timeline_requirements: Timelines for committee opinions and objections as set out in Regulation (EU) No 182/2011 (e.g., deadlines for Member States to deliver opinions, for Parliament/Council to object).

general_restrictions: Implementing acts may only be adopted following the procedures set out in Regulation (EU) No 182/2011 when committee procedure is invoked.
operational_restrictions: The Commissionâ€™s adoption of implementing acts is restricted by the requirement to follow the committee procedure.
geographic_restrictions: Procedures apply only within the EU legal framework.

organizational_rights: Member States have the right to participate in committee proceedings and to deliver opinions on draft implementing acts.
The European Parliament and Council have the right to scrutinize certain implementing acts under Article 8.
how_to_exercise_rights: Participation in committee meetings as designated representatives.
Submission of opinions and objections within prescribed timelines.

general_exceptions: Procedures do not apply where committee procedure is not invoked by the underlying legal act.
conditional_exemptions: Certain acts may be exempt from the scrutiny procedure if not specified in the basic act.

organizational_measures: Establishment and maintenance of committees as per Regulation (EU) No 182/2011.
Procedures for convening and conducting committee meetings.
audit_requirements: Record-keeping and possible audit of committee proceedings.

enforcement.regulatory_authority: European Commission, with oversight by the European Parliament and Council for scrutiny procedure.

penalties.administrative_penalties: Possible annulment or non-adoption of implementing acts if procedures are not followed.
penalties.reputational_consequences: Potential public and institutional criticism for procedural non-compliance.

enforcement_mechanisms: Judicial review by the Court of Justice of the European Union.
Objections by the European Parliament or Council under the scrutiny procedure.

dates.compliance_deadline: Immediate upon entry into force for all new implementing acts requiring committee procedure.

related_regulations.parent_legislation: Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU), Article 291

implementation_steps: Identify when committee procedure is required by the basic act.
Establish or designate the appropriate committee.
Follow the examination or scrutiny procedure as referenced.
Maintain records of committee opinions and decisions.
Notify the European Parliament and Council as required.
common_violations: Failure to convene the committee as required.
Adopting implementing acts without following the correct procedure.
Not respecting timelines for committee opinions or objections.
best_practices: Ensure legal acts clearly reference the applicable procedure.
Provide timely and complete information to committee members.
Document all proceedings and decisions for audit purposes.
compliance_checklist: Is the committee established as per Regulation (EU) No 182/2011?
Is the correct procedure (examination or scrutiny) referenced and followed?
Are all notifications and records maintained as required?
Are timelines for opinions and objections respected?

key_definitions.committee: A body composed of representatives of Member States that assists the Commission in the adoption of implementing acts, as defined in Regulation (EU) No 182/2011.
key_definitions.examination procedure: A procedure under Article 5 of Regulation (EU) No 182/2011 where a committee delivers an opinion on draft implementing acts, generally requiring a qualified majority.
key_definitions.scrutiny procedure: A procedure under Article 8 of Regulation (EU) No 182/2011, in conjunction with Article 5, allowing the European Parliament and Council to object to certain draft implementing acts.

cleaned_regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 of the European Parliament and of the Council (General Data Protection Regulation)

applicable_regions: European Economic Area (EEA) countries where applicable

description.brief_summary: This section repeals Directive 95/46/EC as of 25 May 2018, mandates that references to the repealed Directive are to be read as references to the GDPR, and replaces the Article 29 Working Party with the European Data Protection Board.
description.detailed_explanation: Directive 95/46/EC, which previously governed data protection in the EU, is formally repealed as of 25 May 2018. From this date, the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) is the primary legal framework for data protection in the EU. Any references in legal or regulatory documents to the repealed Directive must now be interpreted as references to the GDPR. Additionally, the Article 29 Working Party, which was the advisory body under the Directive, is replaced by the European Data Protection Board (EDPB), which assumes its functions under the GDPR.
description.purpose: To ensure legal clarity and continuity by formally repealing the previous data protection Directive and establishing the GDPR as the sole applicable regulation, while transferring advisory and oversight functions to the EDPB.
description.legislative_intent: Lawmakers intended to modernize and harmonize data protection laws across the EU, replace the outdated Directive with a directly applicable Regulation, and strengthen oversight by establishing the EDPB.

what_it_covers: Repeal of Directive 95/46/EC
Interpretation of references to the repealed Directive
Replacement of the Article 29 Working Party with the European Data Protection Board

who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Entities operating within the EU or processing data of EU residents

what_it_does_not_cover: Substantive data protection requirements (covered elsewhere in the GDPR)
Specific operational procedures of the EDPB (covered in other articles)

mandatory_obligations: Directive 95/46/EC must be considered repealed as of 25 May 2018
References to Directive 95/46/EC in legal texts must be interpreted as references to the GDPR
References to the Article 29 Working Party must be interpreted as references to the European Data Protection Board
prohibited_actions: Continued reliance on Directive 95/46/EC after 25 May 2018
conditional_requirements: Interpretation of references is conditional on the context of the reference (i.e., references to the Working Party are specifically redirected to the EDPB)
documentation_requirements: Update of legal and compliance documentation to reference the GDPR instead of Directive 95/46/EC
timeline_requirements: Repeal effective from 25 May 2018

general_restrictions: Directive 95/46/EC is no longer in force after 25 May 2018
operational_restrictions: Supervisory and advisory functions previously performed by the Article 29 Working Party must now be performed by the European Data Protection Board
geographic_restrictions: Applies within the EU and to entities subject to EU data protection law

organizational_rights: Right to rely on the GDPR as the applicable data protection law from 25 May 2018

organizational_measures: Update internal and external references from Directive 95/46/EC to the GDPR
Recognize the EDPB as the new advisory body

enforcement.regulatory_authority: European Data Protection Board (EDPB) and national supervisory authorities
enforcement_mechanisms: Legal invalidity of references to Directive 95/46/EC after 25 May 2018
Oversight by EDPB and national supervisory authorities

related_regulations.parent_legislation: Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU)

implementation_steps: Cease application of Directive 95/46/EC from 25 May 2018
Update all legal, compliance, and operational documents to reference the GDPR
Recognize the EDPB as the competent advisory body
Ensure all references in contracts, policies, and procedures are updated
common_violations: Failure to update references from Directive 95/46/EC to GDPR
Continued reliance on guidance from the Article 29 Working Party instead of the EDPB
best_practices: Conduct a comprehensive review of all documentation for outdated references
Train staff on the transition from the Directive to the GDPR
Monitor EDPB guidance for updates
compliance_checklist: All references to Directive 95/46/EC updated to GDPR
All references to Article 29 Working Party updated to EDPB
Internal policies reflect the repeal and new regulatory structure

key_definitions.Directive 95/46/EC: The former EU Data Protection Directive, repealed as of 25 May 2018.
key_definitions.Article 29 Working Party: The former advisory body on data protection under Directive 95/46/EC.
key_definitions.European Data Protection Board (EDPB): The new EU body established by the GDPR to ensure consistent application of data protection rules.

cleaned_regulations.regulation_name: Directive 2002/58/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 12 July 2002 concerning the processing of personal data and the protection of privacy in the electronic communications sector (Directive on privacy and electronic communications)

description.brief_summary: Directive 2002/58/EC sets out specific obligations for the processing of personal data and the protection of privacy in the electronic communications sector within the EU.
description.detailed_explanation: Directive 2002/58/EC, also known as the ePrivacy Directive, regulates the processing of personal data and the protection of privacy in the electronic communications sector. It establishes rules for confidentiality, security, and the handling of traffic and location data, as well as unsolicited communications. The Directive applies to providers of publicly available electronic communications services and networks within the EU.
description.purpose: To ensure the protection of fundamental rights and freedoms, particularly the right to privacy, in the electronic communications sector.
description.legislative_intent: To harmonize the laws of EU Member States regarding privacy and data protection in electronic communications, ensuring a high level of protection for individuals and legal certainty for service providers.

what_it_covers: Processing of personal data in connection with the provision of publicly available electronic communications services
Confidentiality of communications
Security of services
Traffic and location data
Unsolicited communications

target_entities: Providers of publicly available electronic communications services
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Entities operating within the European Union

what_it_does_not_cover: Processing activities outside the scope of publicly available electronic communications services
Matters not covered by specific obligations with the same objective under Directive 2002/58/EC

mandatory_obligations: Comply with specific obligations set out in Directive 2002/58/EC regarding processing of personal data in electronic communications
Ensure confidentiality and security of communications
prohibited_actions: Imposing additional obligations on processing activities already covered by Directive 2002/58/EC with the same objective
conditional_requirements: Obligations under this Regulation do not apply where Directive 2002/58/EC imposes specific obligations with the same objective

general_restrictions: This Regulation shall not impose additional obligations in areas already regulated by Directive 2002/58/EC with the same objective
operational_restrictions: No overlapping or duplicative obligations for processing activities covered by Directive 2002/58/EC
geographic_restrictions: Restriction applies within the European Union

organizational_rights: Right to be subject only to the obligations of Directive 2002/58/EC for covered processing activities, without additional obligations from this Regulation

general_exceptions: This Regulation does not apply to processing activities already subject to specific obligations with the same objective under Directive 2002/58/EC
conditional_exemptions: Exemption applies only where the obligations in Directive 2002/58/EC and this Regulation have the same objective

implementation_steps: Identify processing activities covered by Directive 2002/58/EC
Ensure compliance with obligations under Directive 2002/58/EC for those activities
Do not apply additional obligations from this Regulation to those activities
common_violations: Imposing duplicative or additional obligations on processing activities already regulated by Directive 2002/58/EC
best_practices: Map processing activities to applicable legal frameworks
Regularly review regulatory overlaps to avoid unnecessary compliance burdens
compliance_checklist: Confirm whether processing activity is covered by Directive 2002/58/EC
Verify that no additional obligations are imposed by this Regulation for those activities

key_definitions.publicly available electronic communicat: Services available to the public for the transmission of communications via electronic communications networks.
key_definitions.public communication networks: Electronic communications networks used wholly or mainly for the provision of publicly available electronic communications services.

cleaned_regulations.regulation_name: Provisions on the status of pre-existing international data transfer agreements under EU law

industry_sectors: All sectors handling personal data subject to EU law

description.brief_summary: This clause governs the continued validity of international agreements on personal data transfers concluded by EU Member States before 24 May 2016, provided they complied with then-applicable Union law.
description.detailed_explanation: International agreements involving the transfer of personal data to third countries or international organisations, which were concluded by Member States prior to 24 May 2016 and complied with Union law as it existed before that date, are allowed to remain in force. These agreements will continue to be valid until they are specifically amended, replaced, or revoked. This provision ensures legal continuity and stability for pre-existing agreements during the transition to new data protection frameworks, such as the GDPR.
description.purpose: To provide legal certainty and continuity for international data transfer agreements concluded before the introduction of new EU data protection laws.
description.legislative_intent: Lawmakers intended to avoid disruption of international data flows and legal uncertainty by allowing compliant pre-existing agreements to remain in force until formally changed.

what_it_covers: International agreements involving the transfer of personal data
Agreements concluded by EU Member States before 24 May 2016
Agreements with third countries or international organisations
Agreements compliant with Union law as applicable prior to 24 May 2016

target_entities: Public authorities involved in data transfer agreements
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: EU Member States

what_it_does_not_cover: Agreements concluded after 24 May 2016
Agreements not compliant with Union law as applicable prior to 24 May 2016
Domestic data transfers within the EU
Agreements that have already been amended, replaced, or revoked

mandatory_obligations: Pre-existing agreements must have complied with Union law as applicable prior to 24 May 2016 to remain in force
prohibited_actions: Cannot rely on pre-existing agreements that did not comply with Union law as applicable prior to 24 May 2016
conditional_requirements: Pre-existing agreements remain in force only until they are amended, replaced, or revoked
documentation_requirements: Evidence of compliance with Union law as applicable prior to 24 May 2016 for each agreement
timeline_requirements: Applies to agreements concluded before 24 May 2016
Agreements remain in force until amended, replaced, or revoked

general_restrictions: Only agreements compliant with Union law as applicable prior to 24 May 2016 are covered
data_restrictions: Applies only to personal data transfers under the scope of the agreements
geographic_restrictions: Applies to transfers to third countries or international organisations

organizational_rights: Right of Member States to continue relying on pre-existing compliant agreements
how_to_exercise_rights: Maintain and reference agreements as long as they are not amended, replaced, or revoked

general_exceptions: Agreements not compliant with Union law as applicable prior to 24 May 2016 are not covered
conditional_exemptions: Agreements lose this status if amended, replaced, or revoked

organizational_measures: Maintain records of pre-existing agreements and their compliance status
audit_requirements: Ability to demonstrate compliance with Union law as applicable prior to 24 May 2016

enforcement.regulatory_authority: National Data Protection Authorities (DPAs) and the European Commission
enforcement_mechanisms: Review of agreements by supervisory authorities

related_regulations.parent_legislation: EU Data Protection Law (pre-GDPR, e.g., Directive 95/46/EC)

implementation_steps: Identify all relevant international agreements concluded before 24 May 2016
Verify compliance of each agreement with Union law as applicable prior to 24 May 2016
Maintain documentation evidencing compliance
Monitor for any amendments, replacements, or revocations
common_violations: Relying on agreements that were not compliant with prior Union law
Failing to update records when agreements are amended, replaced, or revoked
best_practices: Regularly review the status of all pre-existing agreements
Document compliance assessments
Coordinate with legal and compliance teams to track changes
compliance_checklist: List of all relevant agreements
Compliance evidence for each agreement
Monitoring process for amendments/replacements/revocations

key_definitions.international agreement: A formal arrangement between an EU Member State and a third country or international organisation concerning the transfer of personal data.
key_definitions.third country: A country outside the European Union.
key_definitions.Union law as applicable prior to 24 May: The body of EU data protection law in force before the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) became applicable.

cleaned_regulations.regulation_name: General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) Article 97 â€“ Commission reports

applicable_regions: European Economic Area (EEA) countries where GDPR applies

industry_sectors: All sectors processing personal data within the EU/EEA

description.brief_summary: Article 97 of the GDPR requires the European Commission to periodically evaluate and review the Regulation, report to the European Parliament and Council, examine specific chapters on data transfers and cooperation, and propose amendments as necessary.
description.detailed_explanation: This article establishes a recurring obligation for the European Commission to submit public reports on the evaluation and review of the GDPR to the European Parliament and Council every four years, starting from 25 May 2020. The evaluation must specifically address the application and functioning of Chapter V (on international data transfers, including decisions under Article 45(3) and Article 25(6) of Directive 95/46/EC) and Chapter VII (on cooperation and consistency among supervisory authorities). The Commission is empowered to request information from Member States and supervisory authorities to support its review. The Commission must also consider the positions and findings of the European Parliament, Council, and other relevant bodies. If necessary, the Commission is required to propose amendments to the Regulation, particularly in response to technological developments and societal progress.
description.purpose: To ensure the GDPR remains effective, up-to-date, and responsive to technological and societal changes by mandating periodic review and public reporting.
description.legislative_intent: Lawmakers intended to create a mechanism for ongoing oversight, transparency, and adaptability of the GDPR, ensuring its continued relevance and effectiveness in protecting personal data.

what_it_covers: Periodic evaluation and review of the GDPR
Reporting to the European Parliament and Council
Public disclosure of evaluation reports
Examination of Chapter V (international data transfers)
Examination of Chapter VII (cooperation and consistency)
Requesting information from Member States and supervisory authorities
Consideration of input from relevant bodies
Proposal of amendments to the Regulation

who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Entities within the EU/EEA

what_it_does_not_cover: Direct obligations for private organizations or individuals
Specific data processing activities
Enforcement actions against data controllers or processors

mandatory_obligations: The Commission SHALL submit a report on the evaluation and review of this Regulation to the European Parliament and to the Council by 25 May 2020 and every four years thereafter.
The reports SHALL be made public.
The Commission SHALL examine, in particular, the application and functioning of Chapter V and Chapter VII.
The Commission SHALL take into account the positions and findings of the European Parliament, of the Council, and of other relevant bodies or sources.
The Commission SHALL, if necessary, submit appropriate proposals to amend this Regulation.
conditional_requirements: For the purpose of paragraph 1, the Commission MAY request information from Member States and supervisory authorities.
Amendments to the Regulation are required only IF NECESSARY, particularly in light of technological and societal developments.
documentation_requirements: Preparation of evaluation and review reports
Public disclosure of reports
reporting_requirements: Submission of evaluation and review reports to the European Parliament and Council every four years, starting 25 May 2020
Public availability of reports
timeline_requirements: First report due by 25 May 2020
Subsequent reports due every four years thereafter

general_restrictions: The Commission is limited to requesting information only for the purpose of evaluation and review as specified.
operational_restrictions: Evaluations and reviews must specifically examine the application and functioning of Chapter V and Chapter VII.
geographic_restrictions: Applies to the EU and EEA Member States

organizational_rights: The Commission may request information from Member States and supervisory authorities for the purpose of evaluation and review.

organizational_measures: Establish procedures for periodic evaluation and review of the Regulation
Mechanisms for requesting and collecting information from Member States and supervisory authorities
audit_requirements: Internal review and assessment of the Regulation's application and functioning

enforcement.regulatory_authority: European Commission

penalties.reputational_consequences: Reports are made public, which may have reputational implications for the Commission or Member States if deficiencies are identified.

enforcement_mechanisms: Oversight by the European Parliament and Council through receipt and review of Commission reports
Public scrutiny via publication of reports

dates.compliance_deadline: First report due by 25 May 2020; subsequent reports every four years
amendment_history: Supersedes Article 33 of Directive 95/46/EC regarding reporting and review

implementation_steps: Establish a schedule and process for periodic evaluation and review
Develop templates and procedures for reporting
Set up mechanisms to request and collect information from Member States and supervisory authorities
Engage with the European Parliament, Council, and other relevant bodies for input
Monitor technological and societal developments for potential amendments
common_violations: Failure to submit reports on time
Insufficient examination of required chapters and articles
Lack of public disclosure of reports
Failure to consider input from relevant bodies
best_practices: Maintain transparent and inclusive review processes
Engage stakeholders early in the evaluation process
Ensure comprehensive data collection from Member States and supervisory authorities
Regularly monitor developments in information technology and the information society
compliance_checklist: Has the Commission submitted the required report by the deadline?
Is the report publicly available?
Does the report specifically address Chapter V and Chapter VII?
Has information been requested from Member States and supervisory authorities as needed?
Have the positions and findings of the European Parliament, Council, and other bodies been considered?

key_definitions.Commission: The European Commission, the executive branch of the European Union responsible for proposing legislation, implementing decisions, and upholding EU treaties.
key_definitions.Member States: Countries that are members of the European Union.
key_definitions.Supervisory Authorities: Independent public authorities established by EU Member States responsible for monitoring the application of the GDPR.
key_definitions.Chapter V: Section of the GDPR concerning the transfer of personal data to third countries or international organisations.
key_definitions.Chapter VII: Section of the GDPR concerning cooperation and consistency among supervisory authorities.

cleaned_regulations.regulation_name: Review and Amendment of Union Legal Acts on Data Protection

industry_sectors: All sectors involving personal data processing by EU institutions, bodies, offices, and agencies

description.brief_summary: Empowers the European Commission to propose legislative amendments to other EU legal acts on personal data protection to ensure uniformity and consistency in protecting natural persons and facilitating free data movement.
description.detailed_explanation: This clause provides the European Commission with the authority to review and, if deemed appropriate, submit proposals for legislative amendments to existing Union legal acts that pertain to the protection of personal data. The primary focus is to harmonize and standardize the level of protection afforded to natural persons across all Union institutions, bodies, offices, and agencies, and to ensure that the free movement of such data is not hindered by inconsistent rules. The clause specifically highlights the need for uniformity in the rules governing data processing by EU-level entities.
description.purpose: To ensure that all Union legal acts provide a consistent and uniform level of protection for natural persons regarding the processing of personal data, and to support the free movement of such data within the EU.
description.legislative_intent: Lawmakers intend to eliminate discrepancies and inconsistencies in data protection standards across various Union legal acts, particularly those affecting EU institutions and agencies, thereby strengthening the overall data protection framework and facilitating data flows.

what_it_covers: Review of existing Union legal acts on data protection
Submission of legislative proposals to amend such acts
Ensuring uniform and consistent protection of natural persons with regard to data processing
Rules relating to data processing by Union institutions, bodies, offices, and agencies
Facilitation of the free movement of personal data within the Union

who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Entities operating within the European Union

what_it_does_not_cover: Processing of personal data by private companies or non-EU bodies
National-level data protection laws not subject to Union legal acts
Data processing outside the scope of Union institutions, bodies, offices, and agencies

mandatory_obligations: The Commission shall, if appropriate, submit legislative proposals to amend other Union legal acts on data protection to ensure uniform and consistent protection.
conditional_requirements: Submission of legislative proposals is conditional upon the Commission deeming it appropriate.

general_restrictions: Legislative proposals to amend Union legal acts are limited to situations where the Commission finds it appropriate.
data_restrictions: Focus is on the protection of natural persons with regard to processing by Union institutions, bodies, offices, and agencies.
geographic_restrictions: Applies within the European Union

individual_rights: Right to uniform and consistent protection of personal data when processed by Union institutions, bodies, offices, and agencies

conditional_exemptions: The obligation to submit legislative proposals applies only if the Commission deems it appropriate.

enforcement.regulatory_authority: European Commission (for proposing amendments); enforcement of amended acts would fall to relevant EU authorities

related_regulations.parent_legislation: General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) and other Union legal acts on data protection

implementation_steps: Commission reviews existing Union legal acts on data protection
Commission assesses appropriateness of amendments
Commission drafts and submits legislative proposals as needed
best_practices: Regular review of Union legal acts for consistency
Stakeholder consultation before proposing amendments
compliance_checklist: Ensure all Union legal acts provide consistent protection for natural persons
Verify that rules for Union institutions, bodies, offices, and agencies are harmonized

key_definitions.Union legal acts: Legislation enacted by the European Union, including regulations, directives, and decisions.
key_definitions.natural persons: Individuals (as opposed to legal persons such as companies or organizations).
key_definitions.processing: Any operation or set of operations performed on personal data, whether or not by automated means.
